class=\"section-jump-link__link-wrap\">\r\n\r\n                <a class=\"js-jumplink scrollTo\" href=\"#203530368\">ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</a>\r\n            </div>\r\n        </li>\r\n        <li LIKELIHOOD COMPUTATION REGION CHOICE</a>\r\n            </div>\r\n        </li>\r\n        <li class=\"section-jump-link head-2\" link-destination=\"203530390\">\r\n            <div   </div>\r\n        </li>\r\n        <li class=\"section-jump-link head-2\" link-destination=\"203530393\">\r\n            <div class=\"section-jump-link__link-wrap\">\r\n\r\n                <a <div class=\"section-jump-link__link-wrap\">\r\n\r\n                <a class=\"js-jumplink scrollTo\" href=\"#203530403\">APPENDIX F: SUMMARY OF UNCERTAINTY BUDGET AND SYSTEMATIC CHECKS</a>\r\n            </div>\r\n        </li>\r\n        <li class=\"section-jump-link head-2\" link-destination=\"203530407\">\r\n            <div class=\"section-jump-link__link-wrap\">\r\n\r\n                <a $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleLinks widget-instance-OUP_Article_Links_Widget\">\n         \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-body data-reveal><i class=\"icon-read-more\"></i><span>Cite</span></a>\r\n\r\n<div id=\"getCitation\" class=\"reveal-modal\" data-reveal>\r\n    <h3 class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>A J Shajib, S Birrer, T Treu, A Agnello, E J Buckley-Geer, J H H Chan, L Christensen, C Lemon, H Lin, M Millon, J Poh, C E Rusu, D Sluse, C Spiniello, G C-F Chen, T Collett, F Courbin, C D Fassnacht, J Frieman, A Galan, D Gilman, A More, T Anguita, M W Auger, V Bonvin, R McMahon, G Meylan, K C Wong, T M C Abbott, J Annis, S Avila, K Bechtol, D Brooks, D Brout, D L Burke, A Carnero\u00a0Rosell, M Carrasco\u00a0Kind, J Carretero, F J Castander, M Costanzi, L N da\u00a0Costa, J De\u00a0Vicente, S Desai, J P Dietrich, P Doel, A Drlica-Wagner, A E Evrard, D A Finley, B Flaugher, P Fosalba, J Garc\u00eda-Bellido, D W Gerdes, D Gruen, R A Gruendl, J Gschwend, G Gutierrez, D L Hollowood, K Honscheid, D Huterer, D J James, T Jeltema, E Krause, N Kuropatkin, T S Li, M Lima, N MacCrann, M A G Maia, J L Marshall, P Melchior, R Miquel, R L C Ogando, A Palmese, F Paz-Chinch\u00f3n, A A Plazas, A K Romer, A Roodman, M Sako, E Sanchez, B Santiago, V Scarpine, M Schubnell, D Scolnic, S Serrano, I Sevilla-Noarbe, M Smith, M Soares-Santos, E Suchyta, G Tarle, D Thomas, A R Walker, Y Zhang,  STRIDES: a 3.9 per cent measurement of the Hubble constant from the strong lens system DES J0408\u22125354, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 494, Issue 4, June 2020, Pages 6072\u20136102, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/staa828\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/staa828</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"citation-download-wrap\">\r\n        <form action=\"/Citation/Download\" method=\"get\" id=\"citationModal\">\r\n            <input type=\"hidden\" name=\"resourceId\" value=\"5813265\" />\r\n            <input type=\"hidden\" href=\"https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=OUP&amp;publication=1365-2966&amp;title=STRIDES%3A%20a%203.9%20per%20cent%20measurement%20of%20the%20Hubble%20constant%20from%20the%20strong%20lens%20system%20DES%20J0408%E2%88%925354&amp;publicationDate=2020-03-28&amp;volumeNum=494&amp;issueNum=4&amp;author=Shajib%2C%20A%20J%3B%20Birrer%2C%20S&amp;startPage=6072&amp;endPage=6102&amp;contentId=10.1093%2Fmnras%2Fstaa828&amp;oa=&amp;copyright=Oxford%20University%20Press&amp;orderBeanReset=True\"                    <li class=\"dropdown-institution-signout\">\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                </li>\r\n                            <li class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f494%2f4%2f6072%2f5813265\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n        </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\"                      <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203530178 id=\"203530178\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present a blind time-delay cosmographic analysis for the lens system DES J0408\u22125354. This system is extraordinary for the presence of two sets of multiple images at different redshifts, which provide the opportunity to obtain more information at the cost of increased modelling complexity with respect to previously analysed systems. We perform detailed modelling of the mass distribution for this lens system using three band <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> imaging. We combine the measured time delays, line-of-sight central velocity dispersion of the deflector, and statistically constrained external convergence with our lens models to estimate two cosmological distances. We measure the \u2018effective\u2019 time-delay distance corresponding to the redshifts of the deflector and the lensed quasar <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\Delta t}^{\\rm eff}=$|</span><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3382_{-115}^{+146}$|</span>\u2009Mpc and the angular diameter distance to the deflector <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> = <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1711_{-280}^{+376}$|</span>\u2009Mpc, with covariance between the two distances. From these constraints on the cosmological distances, we infer the Hubble constant <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>= <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$74.2_{-3.0}^{+2.7}$|</span>\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121\u2009</sup>Mpc<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup> assuming a flat \u039bCDM cosmology and a uniform prior for \u03a9<sub>m</sub> as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Omega _{\\rm m} \\sim \\mathcal {U}(0.05, 0.5)$|\u2060</span>. This measurement gives the most precise constraint on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> to date from a single lens. Our measurement is consistent with that obtained from the previous sample of six lenses analysed by the <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> Lenses in COSMOGRAIL\u2019s Wellspring (H0LiCOW) collaboration. It is also consistent with measurements of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> based on the local distance ladder, reinforcing the tension with the inference from early Universe probes, for example, with 2.2\u03c3 discrepancy from the cosmic microwave background measurement.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;cosmological parameters&quot;\">cosmological parameters</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;distance scale&quot;\">distance scale</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;cosmology: observations&quot;\">cosmology: observations</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203530180 id=\"203530180\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The concordance \u039b cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) cosmology explains the accelerated expansion of the Universe by incorporating the cosmological constant \u039b (Riess et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Perlmutter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>). The \u039bCDM model is very successful in predicting observations covering a large range of physical scales \u2013 from the scale of sound horizon at the recombination epoch, down to the structure formation at the megaparsec scale (e.g. Alam et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Planck Collaboration VI <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The Hubble constant, <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, plays a central role in cosmology, including in the \u039bCDM model. The Hubble constant is not only crucial to determine the age of the Universe, it also normalizes the distances to distant galaxies. As a result, a precise understanding of the galaxy formation and evolution, and the Universe as a whole, closely depends on the precise knowledge of the Hubble constant.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Recently, a significant tension has been reported between the measurements of the Hubble constant using early-Universe and late-Universe probes (e.g. Planck Collaboration VI <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Riess et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). Among others, the most precise constraints on the Hubble constant come from extrapolating the cosmic microwave background (CMB) observation at the early-Universe, and from the measurement based on the cosmic distance ladder calibrated with parallax distances, Cepheids, and type Ia supernovae (SNIae). Assuming a \u039bCDM cosmology, the <em>Planck</em> measurement gives <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 67.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.5\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>(Planck Collaboration VI <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The Supernovae, <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, for the Equation of State of dark energy (SH0ES) team measures <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 74.03\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.42\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup> by calibrating the SNIa distance ladder using Cepheids and parallax distances (Riess et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). These two measurements are at 4.4\u03c3 tension. A cosmic distance ladder measurement from the Carnegie\u2013Chicago Hubble project calibrated by the tip of the red giant branch (TRGB) stars reports <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 69.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.9\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>, consistent with both of the above values on opposite sides (Freedman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). However, the SH0ES team finds <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 72.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.9\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>using the TRGB stars to calibrate the SNIae distance ladder (Yuan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib130\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib130\" data-open=\"bib130\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Additional probes, all consistent with the tension at varying degrees of significance are summarized by Verde, Treu &amp; Riess (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). This tension between the early-Universe and the late-Universe probes can be due to unknown systematics in any or all of the probes. However, if systematics can be ruled out as the source of this tension, then this tension would require extension of the \u039bCDM model. In order to reach a conclusion on the tension and whether new physics is needed, it is paramount to have multiple independent measurements of the Hubble constant, each with sufficient precision on its own to resolve the discrepancy (&lt;2 per cent). In parallel it is also crucial to investigate in detail all possible sources of systematic uncertainties in each method.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Time-delay cosmography measures <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> and other cosmological parameters independently of both the CMB or other high-redshift observations and the local probes such as the ones using the cosmic distance ladder (Refsdal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>). The time-delay between the arrival time of photons at multiple images of a strong-lensing system (hereafter, lens) depends on the three angular diameter distances \u2013 between the observer and the deflector, between the deflector and the source, and between the observer and the source. A combination of these three angular diameter distances gives the so-called \u2018time-delay distance\u2019 (Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). This time-delay distance is inversely proportional to <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> and thus measuring this distance directly constrains <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To measure the time delay between the arrivals of photon at different lensed images that were emitted at the same time, we require a time-variable source. Although Refsdal (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>) originally proposed using strongly lensed supernovae as a time-variable source to measure the time-delay, only a few such supernovae have been discovered so far (e.g. Kelly et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Goobar et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Grillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Even though the number of lensed supernova is still too small to be a competitive cosmological probe, the re-appearance of supernova Refsdal as predicted provides an important validation of the method (Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strongly lensed quasars have provided time-variable sources in larger numbers. As a result, these objects have been predominantly used to measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> from their time-delays (e.g. Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Treu &amp; Koopmans <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Although some of the early measurements had shortcomings in the data quality or the analysis technique, both of these aspects have tremendously improved over the past decade (for a review with historical perspective, see Treu &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib121\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib121\" data-open=\"bib121\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The key breakthroughs in the past two decades have been: (i) high cadence monitoring to determine the time delays (e.g. Fassnacht et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Tewes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib114\" data-open=\"bib114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), (ii) high resolution images of the lensed arcs from the quasar host galaxy and pixel-based lens modelling to constrain the lens mass distribution (Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), (iii) adding stellar kinematics of the deflector (Treu &amp; Koopmans <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), and (iv) statistical analysis of the line of sight to constrain the external convergence (Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Greene et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Implementing these improvements, the <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> Lenses in COSMOGRAIL\u2019s Wellspring (H0LiCOW) collaboration measure <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$H_{0} = 73.3_{-1.8}^{+1.7}$|</span>\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup> using six lens systems (Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>; Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To reach 1 per cent precision in the Hubble constant with time-delay cosmography, a sample of \u223c40 lenses is necessary (Shajib, Treu &amp; Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). To have such a large sample of strongly lensed quasars available in the first place, the STRong-lensing Insights into Dark Energy Survey collaboration (STRIDES; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib119\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib119\" data-open=\"bib119\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) has discovered numerous new lenses from the Dark Energy Survey (DES) footprint, in cases combining data from other large-area sky surveys (e.g. Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015b</a>; Nord et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>; Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). The STRIDES is an external collaboration of the DES. The DES data are particularly useful in discovering new lenses due to its combination of uniform depth and coverage of area in the Southern hemisphere that is not covered by the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). Additionally, thanks to new data mining and machine learning based techniques, new lenses have been discovered also from other photometric surveys \u2013 such as the VLT Survey Telescope-ATLAS (VST-ATLAS), Kilo-Degree Survey Strongly lensed Quasar Detection project (KiDS-SQuaD) (e.g. Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>; Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we present a blind analysis of the lens system DES J0408\u20135354 and infer <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> from its time delays (Courbin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). This lens was discovered in the DES footprint (Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Lin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). This paper sets down two goals underlying our analysis. First, we aim to increase the statistical precision of the <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> determination by presenting results from the analysis of a new lens system. Secondly, this system is being analysed independently and in parallel by two teams using two different codes in order to estimate potential systematics arising from modelling choices and software. This paper presents the first of these two independent and blind analyses for DES J0408\u20135354. To facilitate meaningful comparison between independent modelling teams, the participating teams agreed beforehand on a set of baseline models with minimal but sufficient specifications. The teams are free to extend on the baseline models for exploring different sources of systematics as they see fit. This additional exploration by a team proceeds independently while keeping the cosmographic inferences blind. In this way, we aim to check on systematics that can potentially arise from different codes through comparison of the baseline models from different teams, and also from different model choices within one team\u2019s analysis. In this paper, we infer <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> using the lens modelling software <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstronomy</span>, which is publicly available online at GitHub<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn487\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn487\" data-open=\"fn487\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> (Birrer, Amara &amp; Refregier <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Birrer &amp; Amara <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). A second independent team uses the software <span class=\"small-caps\">glee</span> to analyse the same lens system (Suyu &amp; Halkola <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). In a future paper, cosmographic inference based on this second analysis and a comparison between the two analyses will be presented (Y\u0131ld\u0131r\u0131m et\u00a0al., in preparation). Both of the independent modelling works use the results from a companion paper, which analyses the lens environment to detect galaxy groups and estimate the external convergence using the DES data, and measure the stellar kinematics of the central deflector galaxy from spectroscopic observations (Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our concerted effort to analyse a system independently but based on the same data, and with some overlap in modelling choices, is an important step forward in estimating the modelling errors with respect to previous works. Previous efforts by the H0LiCOW and Strong-lensing High Angular Resolution Programme (SHARP) collaborations took some step in this direction by assigning different lead investigators and softwares to the analysis of the six lenses (Lagattuta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The lens systems B1608+656, RXJ1131\u20131231, HE 0435\u20131223, WFI2033\u20134723, and PG 1115+080 were analysed using the lens modelling software <span class=\"small-caps\">glee</span>, whereas the systems RXJ1131\u20131231 and SDSS 1206+4332 were analysed using the software <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstronomy</span> (Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Birrer, Amara &amp; Refregier <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). In total, four different lead investigators modelled these six lenses, even though there was overlap between the team members. The two softwares used in the modelling differ in various aspects. For example, <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstronomy</span> performs source-reconstruction using a basis set of shapelets, whereas <span class=\"small-caps\">glee</span> performs a pixelized source-reconstruction with regularization. <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstronomy</span> is a publicly available open-source software, whereas <span class=\"small-caps\">glee</span> is not.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to preserve the blindness of the analysis, this paper and the companion describing the analysis of the environment and line of sight used to compute the external convergence were internally reviewed by the STRIDES collaboration and the DES strong-lensing working group before unblinding. Once both the analyses and manuscripts met the approval of the internal reviewers and co-authors, unblinding happened on 2019 September 25. After unblinding, the only changes to the manuscript were the addition of the unblinded measurements, discussion on the unblinded results in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7</a>, minor editing for clarity, grammar, and typos after the DES collaboration-wide review, and the addition of the plot showing the galaxy group\u2019s convergence described in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec10\">C</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we lay out the necessary formalism and describe the analysis framework. We present the data sets used in our analysis in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>. Next in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, we describe the different mass and light profiles that are used in the lens modelling. We present the various lens model choices in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>. We report the results from the lens modelling and the cosmographic inference in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>. Finally, we discuss the results and summarize the paper in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7</a>. We provide summaries of the uncertainty budget in our inferred <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, systematic checks, adopted models, and parameter priors in Appendices \u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec13\">F</a> and\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec14\">G</a>. The reported uncertainties in this paper are computed from 16th and 84th percentiles of the posterior probability distribution.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203530191 id=\"203530191\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 FRAMEWORK OF THE COSMOGRAPHIC ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we outline our cosmographic analysis using strong-lensing time delays. We briefly lay out the strong-lensing time-delay formalism in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1</a>, discuss the lensing degeneracies in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a>, present an overview of the kinematic analysis in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.3</a>, describe the cosmological analysis in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.4</a>, and formalize the underlying Bayesian inference framework of our analysis in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-5\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.5</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530193 id=\"203530193\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Strong-lensing time delay</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The framework described in this subsection was developed in previous studies \u2013 e.g. see Schneider, Ehlers &amp; Falco (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>), Blandford &amp; Narayan (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>) \u2013 and was applied in previous studies to the measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> from time delays (e.g. Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The time delay \u0394<em>t</em><sub>XY</sub> between arrival of photons at two images, indexed with X and Y, of a multiply-imaged quasar by a single deflector is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\Delta t_{\\rm XY} &amp;=&amp; \\frac{1+z_{\\rm d}}{c} \\frac{D_{\\rm d}D_{\\rm s}}{D_{\\rm ds}} \\bigg[ \\frac{(\\theta _{\\rm X} - \\beta)^2}{2} - \\frac{(\\theta _{\\rm Y} - \\beta)^2}{2} \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp; -\\, \\psi (\\theta _{\\rm X}) + \\psi (\\theta _{\\rm Y}) \\bigg].\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>Here, the three angular diameter distances are <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>: between the observer and the deflector, <em>D</em><sub>s</sub>: between the observer and the source, and <em>D</em><sub>ds</sub>: between the deflector and the source. Additionally, <em>z</em><sub>d</sub> is the deflector redshift, <em>c</em> is the speed of light, \u03b8 is the image position, \u03b2 is the source position, and \u03c8 is the deflection potential. The deflection potential is defined such that its gradient gives the deflection field \u03b1 \u2261 \u2207\u03c8. Then, the deflection potential relates to the convergence \u03ba as \u03ba = \u2207<sup>2</sup>\u03c8/2. We define the Fermat potential \u03d5 as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\phi (\\theta) \\equiv \\frac{(\\theta - \\beta)^2}{2} - \\psi (\\theta),\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>and the time-delay distance as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nD_{\\Delta t}\\equiv (1+z_{\\rm d}) \\frac{D_{\\rm d}D_{\\rm s}}{D_{\\rm ds}}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>Then, we can express equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>) in a more compact form as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\Delta t_{\\rm XY} = \\frac{D_{\\Delta t}}{c} \\left(\\phi (\\theta _{\\rm X}) - \\phi (\\theta _{\\rm Y}) \\right) \\equiv \\frac{D_{\\Delta t}}{c} \\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY} .\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">If multiple deflectors are present at close angular proximity at different redshifts, then we need to use the multilens-plane formalism to describe the lensing effect with sufficient accuracy. The time delay between two images for the case of lensing with <em>P</em> lens planes can be obtained by tracing the lensed light-ray backward from the image plane to the source plane as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\Delta t_{\\rm XY} &amp;=&amp; \\sum _{i=1}^P \\frac{D_{\\Delta t, i,i+1}}{c} \\bigg[ \\frac{(\\theta _{{\\rm X},i} - \\theta _{{\\rm X},i+1})^2}{2} - \\frac{(\\theta _{{\\rm Y},i} - \\theta _{{\\rm Y},i+1})^2}{2}\\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;-\\, \\zeta _{i,i+1} \\left\\lbrace \\psi _{i}(\\theta _{{\\rm X},i}) - \\psi _{i}(\\theta _{{\\rm Y}, i}) \\right\\rbrace \\bigg]\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div>(cf. equation 9.17 of Schneider et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>). Here, the first lens plane is the nearest to the observer and the (<em>P</em> + 1)-th plane refers to the source plane. The time-delay distance <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t, i, j</em></sub> between a pair of planes is defined as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nD_{\\Delta t,i,j} \\equiv \\frac{1 + z_{i}}{c}\\frac{D_i D_j}{D_{ij}}, \\quad i \\lt j,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div>where <em>D<sub>i</sub></em> is the angular diameter distance from the observer to the <em>i</em>th plane and <em>D<sub>ij</sub></em> is the angular diameter distance between the <em>i</em>th and <em>j</em>th planes. The rescaling factor \u03b6<sub><em>i, j</em></sub> is defined as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ7\" content-id=\"equ7\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\zeta _{i, j} \\equiv \\frac{D_{ij}D_{\\rm s}}{D_j D_{i{\\rm s}}}, \\quad i \\lt j.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(7)</span></div>In this multilens-plane case, we can define the time-delay distance between the central deflector plane and the source plane as the effective time-delay distance <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\Delta t}^{\\rm eff} \\equiv D_{\\Delta t,{\\rm d},{\\rm s}}$|</span> that normalizes the multilens-plane time delay as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ8\" content-id=\"equ8\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\Delta t_{\\rm XY} &amp;=&amp; \\frac{D_{\\Delta t}^{\\rm eff}}{c} \\sum _{i=1}^P \\frac{1+z_i}{1+z_{\\rm d}} \\frac{D_i D_{i+1} D_{\\rm ds}}{D_{\\rm d} D_{\\rm s}D_{i\\ i+1} } \\bigg[ \\frac{(\\theta _{{\\rm X},i} - \\theta _{{\\rm X},i+1})^2}{2}\\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;-\\, \\frac{(\\theta _{{\\rm Y},i} - \\theta _{{\\rm Y},i+1})^2}{2} - \\zeta _{i,i+1} \\left\\lbrace \\psi _{i}(\\theta _{{\\rm X},i}) - \\psi _{i}(\\theta _{{\\rm Y}, i}) \\right\\rbrace \\bigg]\\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;=&amp; \\frac{D_{\\Delta t}^{\\rm eff}}{c} \\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(8)</span></div>Here, we defined the effective Fermat potential for the multilens-plane case as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ9\" content-id=\"equ9\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\phi ^{\\rm eff} (\\theta) \\equiv \\sum _{i=1}^{P} \\frac{1+z_i}{1+z_{\\rm d}} \\frac{D_i D_{i+1} D_{\\rm ds}}{D_{\\rm d} D_{\\rm s}D_{i\\ i+1} } \\left[ \\frac{(\\theta _{i} - \\theta _{ i+1})^2}{2} - \\zeta _{i,i+1} \\psi _{i}(\\theta _{i}) \\right]. \\nonumber \\\\\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(9)</span></div>In equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ8\"></span><a href=\"#equ8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">8</a>), the effective Fermat potential difference <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\phi ^{\\rm eff}_{\\rm XY}$|</span> only contains the distance ratios. Thus, this term does not depend on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>. However, the distance ratios weakly depend on the relative expansion history, thus on the density parameter \u03a9 in the context of \u039bCDM. Only the effective time-delay distance <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\Delta t}^{\\rm eff}$|</span> depends on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> in equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ8\"></span><a href=\"#equ8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">8</a>). For the single lens plane case with <em>P</em> = 1, the effective Fermat potential \u03d5<sup>eff</sup> and the effective time-delay distance <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\Delta t}^{\\rm eff}$|</span> naturally take the form of their single-lens-plane equivalents \u03d5 and <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> from equations\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ2\"></span><a href=\"#equ2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>) and (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ3\"></span><a href=\"#equ3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>), respectively.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530197 id=\"203530197\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Mass-sheet degeneracy</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">For lensing, the imaging observables such as the flux ratios and the relative astrometry are invariant with respect to the mass-sheet transformation (MST; Falco, Gorenstein &amp; Shapiro <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1985</a>). If we transform the convergence and the source plane as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ10\" content-id=\"equ10\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\begin{split} &amp;\\kappa (\\theta) \\rightarrow \\kappa _{\\vartheta } (\\theta) = \\vartheta \\kappa (\\theta) + 1 - \\vartheta , \\\\\r\n&amp;\\beta \\rightarrow \\beta ^\\prime = \\vartheta \\beta , \\end{split}\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(10)</span></div>then the lensing observables except the time delay remain invariant. This invariance under the MST is called the mass-sheet degeneracy (MSD). Notably, the MST also rescales the magnification, thus the MSD can be broken with standard candles (Bertin &amp; Lombardi <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>).</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We can express the physically existent \u2018true\u2019 mass distribution as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ11\" content-id=\"equ11\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\kappa _{\\rm true} = \\kappa _{\\rm lens} + \\kappa _{\\rm ext} ,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(11)</span></div>where, \u03ba<sub>lens</sub> is the convergence of the central deflector including nearby satellites and perturbers, and \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> is the convergence from projecting all the line-of-sight inhomogeneities on to the lens plane. If we impose the condition lim<sub>\u03b8 \u2192 \u221e</sub>\u03ba<sub>lens</sub> = 0, then we have lim<sub>\u03b8 \u2192 \u221e</sub>\u03ba<sub>true</sub> = \u03ba<sub>ext</sub>. As a result, we can interpret the external convergence \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> as the convergence far from or \u2018external\u2019 to the central deflector. However, as we cannot constrain \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> only from the lensing observables due to the MSD, we aim to constrain a model <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\kappa _{\\rm model}^{\\prime }$|</span> that captures all the lensing effects of \u03ba<sub>true</sub>. By taking \u03d1 = 1/(1 \u2212 \u03ba<sub>ext</sub>) in equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ10\"></span><a href=\"#equ10\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">10</a>), we can obtain an MST of \u03ba<sub>true</sub> as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ12\" content-id=\"equ12\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\kappa _{\\vartheta } = \\frac{1}{1-\\kappa _{\\rm ext}}(\\kappa _{\\rm lens} + \\kappa _{\\rm ext}) - \\frac{\\kappa _{\\rm ext}}{1 - \\kappa _{\\rm ext}} = \\frac{\\kappa _{\\rm lens}}{1 - \\kappa _{\\rm ext}} = \\kappa ^{\\prime }_{\\rm model}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(12)</span></div>Here, we name this \u03ba<sub>\u03d1</sub> as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\kappa ^{\\prime }_{\\rm model}$|</span> because it captures all the lensing effect of \u03ba<sub>true</sub> by the virtue of MST. If we can constrain <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\kappa _{\\rm model}^{\\prime }$|\u2060</span>, then we can obtain \u03ba<sub>true</sub> simply through an MST with \u03d1 = 1 \u2212 \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> where \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> is separately constrained by studying the lens environment. However, the lens model \u03ba<sub>model</sub> that we actually constrain can potentially be an internal MST of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\kappa _{\\rm model}^{\\prime }$|</span> given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ13\" content-id=\"equ13\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\kappa _{\\rm model}^{\\prime } = \\vartheta _{\\rm int} \\kappa _{\\rm model} + 1 - \\vartheta _{\\rm int}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(13)</span></div>The internal MST factor \u03d1<sub>int</sub> only changes the shape of the mass profile, but it does not add any physical mass to the model within the Einstein radius. Note that both \u03ba<sub>model</sub> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\kappa ^{\\prime }_{\\rm model}$|</span> can satisfy lim<sub>\u03b8 \u2192 \u221e</sub>\u03ba = 0 by construction. In that case, \u03d1<sub>int</sub> is not a constant over the whole plane and we have the condition lim<sub>\u03b8 \u2192 \u221e</sub>\u03d1<sub>int</sub> = 1 (Schneider &amp; Sluse <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). This condition implies that \u03d1<sub>int</sub> does not physically add an infinite background-mass-sheet. With such a \u03d1<sub>int</sub>, both models \u03ba<sub>model</sub> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\kappa _{\\rm model}^{\\prime }$|</span> can reproduce the lensing observables that are indistinguishable within the noise level in the data. Finally, combining equations\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ11\"></span><a href=\"#equ11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">11</a>), (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ12\"></span><a href=\"#equ12\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">12</a>), and (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ13\"></span><a href=\"#equ13\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">13</a>), we write the relation between the \u2018true\u2019 convergence \u03ba<sub>true</sub> and the modelled convergence \u03ba<sub>model</sub> as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ14\" content-id=\"equ14\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\kappa _{\\rm true} = (1 - \\kappa _{\\rm ext}) \\left[\\vartheta _{\\rm int}\\kappa _{\\rm model} + 1 -\\vartheta _{\\rm int} \\right] + \\kappa _{\\rm ext}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(14)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using different but equally plausible model parametrizations \u2013 e.g. power-law profile, composite profile \u2013 we explore different model families related by equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ13\"></span><a href=\"#equ13\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">13</a>). To alleviate the MSD within a model family by constraining \u03d1<sub>int</sub>, we utilize non-lensing observables, e.g. kinematics of the deflector galaxy. Kinematics probes the 3D deprojection of \u03ba<sub>lens</sub> for a given combination of \u03ba<sub>model</sub> and \u03ba<sub>ext</sub>. Moreover, the addition of the kinematic information also constrains the angular diameter distance to the deflector <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> (Paraficz &amp; Hjorth <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Jee, Komatsu &amp; Suyu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). As a result, the uncertainty on the estimated <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> is improved by kinematics in two ways:</p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">by alleviating the MSD, and</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">by adding extra constraint on cosmology through <em>D</em><sub>d</sub></p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">(Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Jee et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Shajib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). In the next subsection, we outline the kinematic analysis framework.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530203 id=\"203530203\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 Kinematic analysis</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The kinematic observable is the luminosity-weighted line-of-sight stellar velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub>los</sub>. To model the 3D mass distribution consistent with the observed velocity dispersion, we adopt the spherical solution of the Jeans equations. Although the true mass distribution is non-spherical, the assumption of spherical symmetry is sufficient given the 10\u201325 per cent uncertainty in our kinematic data (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). We can express the spherical Jeans equation as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ15\" content-id=\"equ15\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\frac{\\mathrm{d}\\left(l(r)\\ \\sigma _{\\rm r}^2 \\right)}{\\mathrm{d}r} + \\frac{2 \\beta _{\\rm ani}\\ l(r) \\ \\sigma _{\\rm r}^2}{r} = - l(r)\\ \\frac{\\mathrm{d}\\Phi }{\\mathrm{d}r}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(15)</span></div>Here, <em>l</em>(<em>r</em>) is the 3D luminosity density of the stars, \u03c3<sub>r</sub> is the intrinsic radial velocity dispersion, and \u03b2<sub>ani</sub>(<em>r</em>) is the anisotropy parameter relating \u03c3<sub>r</sub> with the tangential velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub>t</sub> as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ16\" content-id=\"equ16\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\beta (r) \\equiv 1 - \\frac{\\sigma _{\\rm t}^2}{\\sigma _{\\rm r}^2}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(16)</span></div>By solving equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ15\"></span><a href=\"#equ15\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">15</a>), we can obtain the luminosity-weighted, line-of-sight velocity dispersion as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ17\" content-id=\"equ17\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\sigma _{\\rm los}^2(R) = \\frac{2G}{I(R)} \\int _R^{\\infty } \\mathcal {K}_{\\beta } \\left(\\frac{r}{R} \\right) \\frac{l(r)\\ M(r)}{r} \\ \\mathrm{d}r,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(17)</span></div>where <em>M</em>(<em>r</em>) is the enclosed mass within radius <em>r</em> (equation (A15)\u2013 (A16) of Mamon &amp; \u0141okas <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). Here, the function <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {K}_{\\beta }(\\varrho)$|</span> depends on the parametrization of \u03b2(<em>r</em>). We adopt the Osipkov\u2013Merritt parametrization of the anisotropy parameter given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ18\" content-id=\"equ18\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\beta _{\\rm ani}(r) = \\frac{r^2}{r^2 + r_{\\rm ani}^2},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(18)</span></div>where <em>r</em><sub>ani</sub> is the anisotropy scale radius (Osipkov <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>; Merritt <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1985a</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>). For this parametrization, the function <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {K}_{\\beta }$|</span> takes the form <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ19\" content-id=\"equ19\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\mathcal {K}_{\\beta } (u) &amp;=&amp; \\frac{u_{\\rm ani}^2 + 1/2}{(u_{\\rm ani}+1)^{3/2}} \\left(\\frac{u^2+u_{\\rm ani}^2}{u} \\right) \\tan ^{-1} \\left(\\sqrt{\\frac{u^2-1}{u^2_{\\rm ani}+1}} \\right) \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;-\\, \\frac{1/2}{u_{\\rm ani}^2 + 1} \\sqrt{1 - \\frac{1}{u^2}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(19)</span></div>where <em>u</em><sub>ani</sub> = <em>r</em><sub>ani</sub>/<em>R</em> (Mamon &amp; \u0141okas <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>).</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The enclosed mass <em>M</em>(<em>r</em>) is computed from the 3D mass profile. For the convergence and surface brightness profiles that cannot be straightforwardly deprojected into 3D, we decompose them into concentric Gaussian components (Bendinelli <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Emsellem et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>; Cappellari <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Shajib <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). We then deproject the Gaussian components into 3D Gaussians to compute the enclosed mass <em>M</em>(<em>r</em>) and 3D light density profile <em>l</em>(<em>r</em>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530206 id=\"203530206\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4>2.4 Cosmological distances</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In this section, we effectively follow Birrer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) to jointly infer <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>. From the modelled convergence profile <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\kappa _{\\rm model}^{\\prime }$|</span> of the deflector, we derive the time-delay distance <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\Delta t}^{\\prime }$|</span> particular to the deflector\u2019s line of sight. We need to correct <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\Delta t}^{\\prime }$|</span> for the external convergence \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> to obtain the true time-delay distance <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub>. From equations\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>) and (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ12\"></span><a href=\"#equ12\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">12</a>), we can express the true time-delay distance <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ20\" content-id=\"equ20\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nD_{\\Delta t}= \\frac{D_{\\Delta t}^{\\prime }}{1 - \\kappa _{\\rm ext}}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(20)</span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We can express \u03c3<sub>los</sub> in terms of parameters characterizing the 2D mass and light distributions and relevant angular diameter distances as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ21\" content-id=\"equ21\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\sigma _{\\rm los}^2 = \\frac{D_{\\rm s}}{D_{\\rm ds}}\\ c^2\\ J(\\xi _{\\rm lens},\\ \\xi _{\\rm light},\\ \\beta _{\\rm ani}),\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(21)</span></div>where \u03be<sub>lens</sub> is the set of mass parameters, \u03be<sub>light</sub> is the set of light distribution parameters, <em>c</em> is the speed of light, and the function <em>J</em> captures all the dependencies from the mass profile, the light profile, and the orbital anisotropy (Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The parameters in the argument of the function <em>J</em> are expressed in angular units, thus they do not depend on the cosmology. Then from equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>), we have <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ22\" content-id=\"equ22\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\frac{D_{\\rm d}D_{\\rm s}}{D_{\\rm ds}} = \\frac{c\\ \\Delta t_{\\rm XY}}{(1+z_{\\rm d})\\ \\Delta \\phi ^{\\rm eff}_{\\rm XY}(\\xi _{\\rm lens})} .\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(22)</span></div>Combining this equation with equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ21\"></span><a href=\"#equ21\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">21</a>), we can write <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ23\" content-id=\"equ23\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nD_{\\rm d}= \\frac{c^3\\ \\Delta t_{\\rm XY}\\ J(\\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\beta _{\\rm ani})}{(1+z_{\\rm d})\\ \\sigma _{\\rm los}^2\\ \\Delta \\phi ^{\\rm eff}_{\\rm XY}(\\xi _{\\rm lens}) }\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(23)</span></div>(Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). As a result, we can estimate the angular diameter distance <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> to the deflector by combining the kinematics with the lensing observables. Therefore, we can infer two cosmological distances, <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>, at specific redshifts relevant to the lens system. Thus, we can constrain the Hubble constant and other cosmological parameters from the distance\u2013redshift relation for a given cosmology. In the next section, we describe the combined Bayesian framework to infer the Hubble constant from the observables.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530209 id=\"203530209\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-5>2.5 Bayesian inference framework</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We tabulate the notations used in this section in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> as a quick reference for the readers. At the top level, the two cosmological distances <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> contain all the cosmographic information. We express the set of cosmological distances using the notation <em>D</em>, which is a function <em>D</em>(\u03c9; <em>C</em>) of the set of cosmological parameters \u03c9 for a given cosmology <em>C</em>. We denote the set containing all the observables as <em>O</em> \u2261 {<em>O</em><sub>img</sub>, <em>O</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub>, <em>O</em><sub>kin</sub>, <em>O</em><sub>env</sub>}, where <em>O</em><sub>img</sub> contains the imaging data of the lens system, <em>O</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> contains the observed time delays, <em>O</em><sub>kin</sub> contains the spectra of the deflector to estimate the kinematics, and <em>O</em><sub>env</sub> contains photometric and spectroscopic survey data of the lens environment to estimate the external convergence. Then from Bayes\u2019 theorem, we can write <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ24\" content-id=\"equ24\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\begin{split} p(\\omega \\mid O, C) &amp;\\propto p(O \\mid \\omega , C)\\ p(\\omega \\mid C) \\\\\r\n&amp;= p \\left(O \\mid D(\\omega ; C)\\right) \\ p(\\omega \\mid C), \\end{split}\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(24)</span></div>where the probability density <em>p</em>(\u03c9\u2223<em>O, C</em>) is called the posterior of \u03c9, the probability density <em>p</em>(<em>O</em>\u2223\u03c9, <em>C</em>) is called the likelihood of <em>O</em> given {\u03c9, <em>C</em>}, and the probability density <em>p</em>(\u03c9\u2223<em>C</em>) is called the prior for \u03c9. In the last line of the above equation, we have changed {\u03c9, <em>C</em>} into <em>D</em>(\u03c9; <em>C</em>) in the likelihood term, as it allows us to break down the computation of the likelihood into two steps. First, we compute the likelihood <em>p</em>(<em>O</em>\u2223<em>D</em>) of the observed data for given cosmological distances marginalizing over various model choices and their respective parameters. Then, we can fold in the prior of the cosmological parameters <em>p</em>(\u03c9\u2223<em>C</em>) to obtain the posterior <em>p</em>(\u03c9\u2223<em>O, C</em>). As the different pieces of the data in <em>O</em> are independent, we can breakup the likelihood into likelihoods of each observable type as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ25\" content-id=\"equ25\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\np(O \\mid D) = p(O_{\\rm img} \\mid D) \\ p(O_{\\Delta t} \\mid D) \\ p(O_{\\rm kin} \\mid D) \\ P(O_{\\rm env} \\mid D). \\nonumber \\\\\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(25)</span></div>When computing these likelihood functions, we adopt a combination of model choices. We denote the model choice containing the mass model parameters \u03be<sub>lens</sub> and deflector light model parameters \u03be<sub>light</sub> as <em>M</em>. In addition, we have to make specific choices for the parametrization \u03be<sub>source</sub> of the source light distribution and the parametrization \u03be<sub>pert</sub> of the mass profiles of the line-of-sight perturbers. We denote the model choice encompassing \u03be<sub>source</sub> and \u03be<sub>pert</sub> as <em>S</em>. We also marginalize over the external convergence \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> and the parameters \u03be<sub>\u03b2</sub> characterizing \u03b2<sub>ani</sub>. Adding it all together, we can marginalize all the specific model parameters to express the total likelihood given the distances as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ26\" content-id=\"equ26\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\np(O \\mid D, M) &amp;=&amp; \\int p(O_{\\rm img} \\mid \\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\xi _{\\rm source}, \\xi _{\\rm pert}, M, S) \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\times p(O_{\\Delta t} \\mid \\Delta t(\\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\xi _{\\rm pert}, \\kappa _{\\rm ext}; M, S)) \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\times \\, p(\\xi _{\\rm source}, \\xi _{\\rm pert} \\mid S)\\ p(S)\\ \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\times \\, p(O_{\\rm kin} \\mid \\sigma _{\\rm los} (\\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\kappa _{\\rm ext}, \\xi _{\\beta }; M))\\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\times \\, p(\\xi _{\\beta } \\mid \\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, M) \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\times \\, p(O_{\\rm env} \\mid \\kappa _{\\rm ext})\\ p(\\kappa _{\\rm ext}) \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\times \\, p(\\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light} \\mid M)\\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\times \\, \\mathrm{d}\\xi _{\\rm source}\\ \\mathrm{d}\\xi _{\\rm pert}\\ \\mathrm{d}S \\ \\mathrm{d}\\xi _{\\beta }\\ \\mathrm{d}\\kappa _{\\rm ext} \\ \\mathrm{d}\\xi _{\\rm lens} \\ \\mathrm{d}\\xi _{\\rm light}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(26)</span></div>Here, we omitted some model parameters and model specifications in the conditional statements of the likelihoods where the corresponding likelihood does not depend on them. Breaking up the likelihood as above allows us to partially separate the computation of the likelihoods for different observable types before marginalizing over the model parameters. We first describe the imaging likelihood and marginalization over relevant models and model parameters in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.5.1</a>, then we explain the derivation of the joint posterior combining time delay and kinematics likelihoods with the lens model posterior in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.5.2</a>.</div>                        <a id=\"203530211\" scrollto-destination=\"203530211\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">List of notations used in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-5\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.5</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Notation<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">List of notations used in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-5\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-5\" class=\"sectionLink
