The top row shows the observed RGB image, reconstructed RGB image, the convergence profile, and the magnification model in order from the left-hand side to the right-hand side. The next three rows show the observed image, the reconstructed image, the residual, the reconstructed source in order from the left-hand side to the right-hand side for each of the <em>HST</em> filters. The three filters are F160W (second row), F814W (third row), and F475X (fourth row). All the scale bars in each plot correspond to 1\u2009arcsec. The patchy or ring-like artefacts in the source reconstruction translate to lensed features below the noise level in the image, thus they do not affect our lens model.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530312 id=\"203530312\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-9>5.9 Dust extinction by the satellite G2</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The satellite G2 may cause differential dust extinction to the lensed light distribution near image C. Ignoring this differential extinction may produce poor fitting around image C in the modelling. To account for this effect, we multiply a differential extinction factor exp\u2009[ \u2212 \u03c4<sub>\u03bb</sub>(\u03b8<sub>1</sub>, \u03b8<sub>2</sub>)] to the lensed light distribution from the quasar host galaxy in all three bands. Here, \u03c4<sub>\u03bb</sub> is equivalent to an optical depth parameter. We set the differential extinction profile proportional to G2\u2019s IR surface brightness with a wavelength-dependent normalization. Therefore, we take <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\tau _{\\lambda }(\\theta _1, \\theta _2) = \\tau ^0_{\\lambda } I_{\\rm G2} (x, y)$|\u2060</span>, where <em>I</em><sub>G2</sub>(\u03b8<sub>1</sub>, \u03b8<sub>1</sub>) is G2\u2019s light distribution parametrized with a S\u00e9rsic profile as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.3</a>. Thus, we are only modelling the differential extinction effect by G2 and this extinction goes to zero far away from G2. We do not model the differential extinction effect for the central deflector G1 as elliptical galaxies like G1 are typically dust-poor. We connect the proportionality constant <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\tau _0^{\\lambda }$|</span> for each band using the differential extinction law of Cardelli, Clayton &amp; Mathis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>) with <em>R<sub>V</sub></em> = 3.1. As a result, we only have <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\tau ^0_{\\rm F814W}$|</span> as a non-linear parameter in our model. As a check, we run a lens model with the proportionality constant <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\tau ^0_{\\lambda }$|</span> in each band independent of each other and we find that the three constrained <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\tau ^0_{\\lambda }$|</span> parameters follow the extinction law from Cardelli et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>) for <em>R<sub>V</sub></em> \u223c3\u20135. The amplitudes of the quasar images are free parameters, therefore any possible differential extinction effect in the quasar image flux is already accounted for.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530314 id=\"203530314\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-10>5.10 Requirement for astrometric precision</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">For the lens system DES J0408\u20135354, a precision of 6\u2009mas is required in the estimated source position to match the precision of the most precise time delay, \u0394<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub> (Birrer &amp; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Given the magnification and the multiplicity of the images, this precision in the source position translates to an astrometric precision of approximately 40\u2009mas for each image position on the image plane under a fixed lens model. As we can constrain the image positions in our models within 10\u2009mas, we meet the requirement for astrometric precision. We expect any non-accounted astrometric uncertainty on the level of 10\u2009mas or below to be subdominant in the error budget and the systematic impact.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530316 id=\"203530316\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-11>5.11 Model choice combinations</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Assembling the different choices described above for various components in our models, we have the following options that we vary:</p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Central deflector G1\u2019s mass profile: power-law, composite,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Source <em>n</em><sub>max</sub>: {6, 3, 2},\u2009{7, 4, 2},\u2009{8, 5, 3},</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">S3 redshift: <em>z</em><sub>QSO</sub> = 2.375, <em>z</em><sub>S2</sub> = 2.28, and</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">G4\u2013G6 mass profile: SIS, NFW.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">Taking all possible combinations of these choices, we have 24 different models in total \u2013 12 for the power-law and 12 for the composite mass profiles. All the light profiles for lens and source light distribution form a linear basis set, thus all the amplitude parameters are linear (Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Birrer &amp; Amara <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We have 85\u2013137 linear parameters and 57\u201362 non-linear parameters in the 24 model setups with either power-law or composite mass profiles.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We can compare the number of chosen models in this study with the 128 model runs performed in the cosmographic analysis of SDSS 1206+4332 (Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Since Birrer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) performed two separate sampling runs for the same model, these authors adopt 64 different models in practice combining the power-law and composite mass profiles. As Birrer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) find that explicitly accounting for the non-linear components of the foreground shear has negligible impact in the cosmographic analysis, we choose not to include it in our analysis. Note, the linear components of the foreground shear is already accounted by the adopted external shear profile. Moreover, Birrer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) incorporate two different likelihood-computation region sizes in their model choices, whereas we do not vary it in our analysis as we show that our analysis is stable against different choices of the likelihood-computation region size (Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec9\">B</a>). As a result, the comparable number of models in Birrer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) is 16 to contrast with our adopted model number of 24. These numbers, although not identical, are comparable and difference between the exact number of chosen models to check systematics can arise naturally due to different complexity in different lens systems.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203530321 id=\"203530321\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 LENS MODELLING AND COSMOGRAPHIC INFERENCE</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we first present the lens modelling results (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.1</a>), combine the time-delay and kinematics likelihoods with the lens model posterior to produce the cosmological distance posterior (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.2</a>), and infer <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> from the distance posterior (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.3</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530323 id=\"203530323\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-1>6.1 Modelling workflow and results</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We simultaneously model the images from all three <em>HST</em> bands. For each model choice from Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-11\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.11</a>, we reconstruct the PSF for each <em>HST</em> band. Thus, a set of three reconstructed PSFs is part of the model choice <em>S</em> that we marginalize (cf. equation\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ27\"></span><a href=\"#equ27\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">27</a>). To initiate the PSF reconstruction, we take an initial PSF estimate by taking the median of a few (\u223c4\u20136) stars from each <em>HST</em> image and then re-centring the median PSF. At each iteration of the PSF reconstruction process, we first realign the IR band\u2019s coordinate system with the <em>UVIS</em> bands\u2019 coordinate system using the quasar image positions (Shajib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Then, we optimize the lens model given the PSF from the initial estimate or the previous iteration of PSF reconstruction. Finally, we subtract the extended host-galaxy and the lens-galaxy light from the image and optimize the PSF using the residual quasar images (see for details Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>, and for similar procedure Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). We use <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstronomy</span> for lens modelling and PSF reconstruction and the particle swarm optimization (PSO) routine of <span class=\"small-caps\">cosmohammer</span> for optimizing the model (Kennedy &amp; Eberhart <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>; Akeret et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Birrer &amp; Amara <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We repeat the set of the following three steps five times in total to reconstruct the PSF:</p><ol class=\"number\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">IR band image re-alignment,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">lens model optimization using PSO,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">PSF reconstruction.</p></li></ol><p class=\"chapter-para\">We check that the reconstructed PSF stabilizes after five such iterations as the PSFs from additional iterations do not lead to higher imaging likelihood.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">After the PSF reconstruction, we simultaneously sample from the lens model posterior and compute the model evidence <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {Z}$|</span> using the dynamic nested sampling algorithm (Skilling <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Higson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We use the nested sampling software <span class=\"small-caps\">dypolychord</span> (Handley, Hobson &amp; Lasenby <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Higson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). In Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec12\">E</a>, we describe the sampler settings, assess the numerical performance, and conclude that the choosen settings allow for sufficient exploration of the posterior space.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We perform our analysis while blinding <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> and other model parameters and lensing quantities directly related to <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, i.e. the model-predicted time delays. We also blind the mass profile slope \u03b3 of the power-law model after the initial exploration stage to find a stable preliminary lens model. In practice, the mean of the blinded quantities are always subtracted from the distribution within the analysis software, so that the printed values or plotted distributions are centred at zero. After all the co-authors had agreed during a teleconference on 2019 September 25 that sufficient amount of checks for modelling systematics were carried out, the analysis was frozen and the actual posterior distribution of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> was revealed for the first time. We report this <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> posterior in this paper without any further alteration.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> display the most likely models for the power-law and composite profiles, respectively. In addition to the lensed complex structures in the Einstein ring from the extended quasar host galaxy, the lensed arcs S2 and S3 are also reproduced very accurately. Moreover, the models reproduce the additional split image C2 on the other side of G2 from image C.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> tabulates the evidences for different model choices. We combine the model posteriors weighted by the evidence ratios within each lens model family \u2013 power-law or composite \u2013 to marginalize over the model choices. Previous studies \u2013 e.g. Birrer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), Chen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), Rusu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>) \u2013 use the Bayesian information criterion (BIC) as an estimate of the evidence for Bayesian model averaging (BMA; e.g. Madigan &amp; Raftery <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>; Hoeting et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>). Whereas BIC estimates the model evidence based on the maxima of the likelihood function under certain assumptions, nested sampling directly computes the model evidence by integrating over the whole prior space. Hence, the evidence obtained from nested sampling is more robust.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We account for sparse sampling from the model space by down-weighting the evidence ratios between the models. Effectively, we want to estimate the factor \u0394<em>S<sub>n</sub></em> in equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ30\"></span><a href=\"#equ30\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">30</a>) to account for sparse sampling. We estimate the sparsity of the sampled models by taking the variance of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}$|</span> between \u2018neighbouring\u2019 model pairs that differ in only one model setting. In this way, we are being conservative by accepting more variance in our lens model posterior to avoid any bias due to sparse sampling from the model space. For 12 models within each mass profile family, we then have 20 such \u2018neighbouring\u2019 models. We obtain <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}}^{\\rm model}$|</span> = 436 for the power-law models and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}}^{\\rm model}$|</span> = 1210 for the composite models. We follow Birrer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) to adjust the relative weights of the model by convolving the evidence ratios with a Gaussian kernel with standard deviation <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}} = ({{\\sigma _{\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}}^{\\rm model}}^2 + {\\sigma ^{\\rm numeric}_{\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}}}^2})^{1/2}$|\u2060</span>. Here, we take <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sigma ^{\\rm numeric}_{\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}}}=34$|</span> as explained in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec12\">E</a>. Following Birrer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), we first calculate the absolute weight <em>W</em><sub><em>n</em>, abs</sub> of the <em>n</em>th model by convolving the evidence uncertainty with the evidence ratio function <em>f</em>(<em>x</em>) as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ52\" content-id=\"equ52\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nW_{n, \\text{abs}} = \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2 \\pi } \\sigma _{\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}}} \\int _{-\\infty }^{\\infty } f(x) \\exp \\left[-\\frac{(\\log \\mathcal {Z}_n - x)^2}{2 \\sigma _{\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}}^2} \\right] \\mathrm{d} x,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(52)</span></div>where we define the evidence ratio function <em>f</em>(<em>x</em>) as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ53\" content-id=\"equ53\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nf(x) \\equiv \\left\\lbrace \\begin{array}{@{}l@{\\quad }l@{}}1 &amp;\\quad x \\ge \\mathcal {\\log Z}_{\\rm max}, \\\\\r\n\\ \\exp \\left(x - \\mathcal {\\log Z_{\\ \\rm max}} \\right) &amp;\\quad x \\lt \\mathcal {\\log Z}_{\\rm max}. \\ \\end{array}\\right.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(53)</span></div>We then obtain the relative weight <em>W</em><sub><em>n</em>, rel</sub> by simply normalizing the absolute weights by the maximum absolute weight as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ54\" content-id=\"equ54\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nW_{n, \\text{rel}} = \\frac{W_{n, \\text{abs}}}{\\max \\left(\\left\\lbrace W_{n, \\text{abs} } \\right\\rbrace \\right)}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(54)</span></div>In the limit of <em>n</em> \u2192 \u221e, we would have a perfect sampling of models from the model space. In that case, we have <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma ^{\\rm model}_{\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}} \\rightarrow 0$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}} \\rightarrow \\sigma _{\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}}^{\\rm numeric}$|\u2060</span>. Furthermore, if the evidence value is perfectly computed with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}}^{\\rm numeric}=0$|\u2060</span>, then the exponential function inside equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ52\"></span><a href=\"#equ52\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">52</a>) becomes a Dirac delta function. In that limit, the relative weight <em>W</em><sub><em>n</em>, rel</sub> approaches the evidence ratio as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ55\" content-id=\"equ55\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\lim _{\\sigma _{\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}} \\rightarrow 0} W_{n, \\text{rel}} = \\frac{\\mathcal {Z}_{n}}{\\mathcal {Z_{\\rm max}}}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(55)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, we compare the posteriors of important lens parameters between power-law and composite mass profiles after marginalizing over the model space using the adjusted evidence ratios as described above.</p>                        <a id=\"203530333\" scrollto-destination=\"203530333\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=naP1nZU8rXUafTSp~Y2wp5aO0YHQ4S5cQ6QEJwRv4W3z-4CfWYjwtzsHMBhKIfQQ3icEMJ0BhkomLN3PnWbqIBUy2EHJ7RiBYXj65jPpwQZwfgNHiu8cr0G3NE39HxeAahOgt-P41HJRYc1PtDTtZ9Xc~sRjFrTR0MDuv~tm9IYRmBelEC8VwLQP86Burm1YmKomj2PJGvle1dqLR6fWyW53R7GPa1MBtAh8W8o98nF0usqIOdiVscgyaACLkGkxYTN3MPzlF3sxeo~UfwBBIg3bkKyH1KbhAb3cLdrAGukyEC734XMFXrG3lBgvPd~fGOQtUuyAQvjG4Sj6pjILpg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the lensing properties between the power-law and composite mass models. The posteriors are weighted combinations of 12 models for each mass model family. Here, $\\tilde{\\theta }_{\\rm E}$ is the Einstein radius defined to contain mean convergence of 1, and the profile slope $\\tilde{\\gamma }$ is defined as the derivative of the convergence profile at $\\tilde{\\theta }_{\\rm E}$. We blind the profile-slope and the effective Fermat potential differences by subtracting the mean and then normalize it with the mean to show relative offsets in percentage.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530333/staa828fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530333\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=H7tkRFtJicI6oadh2BzF9qymoGeBS7h6U3bpf~j-W98todPXVC7bZDlAYSQhgdN1EFHdoS3r4CH4JVD2jJjC~M2lpT3zVAN1hOWmSVw86L1EfwUskVW9vAxbdwnnV7Pgmu33sgy50gOUqDO5eWM7DrosRRVrWfAzo8Y6DYZ-Xv2P5nM0MRIt1QK4EFJRrTtTW7yCl5K4zHBAlmG1KiyICsHEifq7YXKlPOAic4Q50tPJ1KGmLr13kIPjPQEkfgM-FoD350B-VSfvzDCNVCJDS2iz8qLS7HmRsXcI7ycp3zuvKbeA9FwofrGHZY~b1nQTWv2mtv3wM2HSTd3uu2nzyA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530333&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the lensing properties between the power-law and composite mass models. The posteriors are weighted combinations of 12 models for each mass model family. Here, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\tilde{\\theta }_{\\rm E}$|</span> is the Einstein radius defined to contain mean convergence of 1, and the profile slope <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\tilde{\\gamma }$|</span> is defined as the derivative of the convergence profile at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\tilde{\\theta }_{\\rm E}$|\u2060</span>. We blind the profile-slope and the effective Fermat potential differences by subtracting the mean and then normalize it with the mean to show relative offsets in percentage.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=naP1nZU8rXUafTSp~Y2wp5aO0YHQ4S5cQ6QEJwRv4W3z-4CfWYjwtzsHMBhKIfQQ3icEMJ0BhkomLN3PnWbqIBUy2EHJ7RiBYXj65jPpwQZwfgNHiu8cr0G3NE39HxeAahOgt-P41HJRYc1PtDTtZ9Xc~sRjFrTR0MDuv~tm9IYRmBelEC8VwLQP86Burm1YmKomj2PJGvle1dqLR6fWyW53R7GPa1MBtAh8W8o98nF0usqIOdiVscgyaACLkGkxYTN3MPzlF3sxeo~UfwBBIg3bkKyH1KbhAb3cLdrAGukyEC734XMFXrG3lBgvPd~fGOQtUuyAQvjG4Sj6pjILpg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the lensing properties between the power-law and composite mass models. The posteriors are weighted combinations of 12 models for each mass model family. Here, $\\tilde{\\theta }_{\\rm E}$ is the Einstein radius defined to contain mean convergence of 1, and the profile slope $\\tilde{\\gamma }$ is defined as the derivative of the convergence profile at $\\tilde{\\theta }_{\\rm E}$. We blind the profile-slope and the effective Fermat potential differences by subtracting the mean and then normalize it with the mean to show relative offsets in percentage.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530333/staa828fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530333\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=H7tkRFtJicI6oadh2BzF9qymoGeBS7h6U3bpf~j-W98todPXVC7bZDlAYSQhgdN1EFHdoS3r4CH4JVD2jJjC~M2lpT3zVAN1hOWmSVw86L1EfwUskVW9vAxbdwnnV7Pgmu33sgy50gOUqDO5eWM7DrosRRVrWfAzo8Y6DYZ-Xv2P5nM0MRIt1QK4EFJRrTtTW7yCl5K4zHBAlmG1KiyICsHEifq7YXKlPOAic4Q50tPJ1KGmLr13kIPjPQEkfgM-FoD350B-VSfvzDCNVCJDS2iz8qLS7HmRsXcI7ycp3zuvKbeA9FwofrGHZY~b1nQTWv2mtv3wM2HSTd3uu2nzyA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530333&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the lensing properties between the power-law and composite mass models. The posteriors are weighted combinations of 12 models for each mass model family. Here, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\tilde{\\theta }_{\\rm E}$|</span> is the Einstein radius defined to contain mean convergence of 1, and the profile slope <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\tilde{\\gamma }$|</span> is defined as the derivative of the convergence profile at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\tilde{\\theta }_{\\rm E}$|\u2060</span>. We blind the profile-slope and the effective Fermat potential differences by subtracting the mean and then normalize it with the mean to show relative offsets in percentage.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530334 id=\"203530334\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2>6.2 Combining the time delays, kinematics, and external convergence information</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To combine the time-delay likelihood with the lens imaging likelihood, we importance sample from the lens model posterior weighted by the joint time-delay and kinematics likelihood (Lewis &amp; Bridle <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.2.1</a>, we fold in the time-delay and kinematic likelihoods into the lens model posterior. Then in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.2.2</a>, we add the external convergence distribution to the cosmological distance posteriors. Finally in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.2.3</a>, we check the impact of microlensing time-delay on our inference of the effective time-delay distance.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203530336 id=\"203530336\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2-1>6.2.1 Combining time-delay and kinematics likelihoods</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The posterior samples from nested sampling carry weights proportional to their contribution to the posterior mass. We obtain 10\u2009000 equally weighted posterior samples through weighted random sampling from the nested sampling chain for each lens model setup. To combine distance posteriors from different lens model setups, we randomly sample a number of points from the lens model posterior for each setup within a mass-model family, where the sampled number is proportional to the relative weight computed from the adjusted evidence ratio (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). We then uniformly sample 4000 points of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(D^{\\rm eff}_{\\Delta t},\\ D_{\\rm s}/D_{\\rm ds})$|</span> for each lens model sample from [0, 2.15]<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\Delta t}^{\\rm eff,fiducial}\\ \\times$|</span> [0.35, 1.35](<em>D</em><sub>s</sub>/<em>D</em><sub>ds</sub>)<sup>fiducial</sup>. The chosen boundaries fully contain (&gt;5\u03c3) the distance posteriors and they also encompass the range allowed by the priors <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> \u2208 [0, 150] km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup> and \u03a9<sub>m</sub> \u2208 [0.05, 0.5], given our fiducial cosmology. This procedure effectively gives us 4000\u00d7 <em>N</em><sub>sample</sub> points from the joint space combining the lens model parameters and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(D^{\\rm eff}_{\\Delta t},\\ D_{\\rm s}/D_{\\rm ds})$|\u2060</span>, where <em>N</em><sub>sample</sub> is the number of lens model samples. We then importance sample from these 4000\u00d7 <em>N</em><sub>sample</sub> points weighted by the joint time-delay and kinematic likelihood to obtain the marginalized posterior distribution of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(D^{\\rm eff}_{\\Delta t},\\ D_{\\rm s}/D_{\\rm ds})$|\u2060</span>. We only consider \u0394<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub> and \u0394<em>t</em><sub>AD</sub> in the time-delay likelihood as \u0394<em>t</em><sub>BD</sub> is not independent of the others. We then transform the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(D^{\\rm eff}_{\\rm \\Delta t},\\ D_{\\rm s}/D_{\\rm ds})$|</span> distribution into the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(D^{\\rm eff}_{\\rm \\Delta t}, \\ D_{\\rm d})$|</span> distribution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since there are four observing setup for G1\u2019s central line-of-sight velocity dispersion, we compute four line-of-sight velocity dispersions for each sample from the lens model posterior. We account for covariance between these four measurements in the kinematic likelihood (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a> for covariance matrix definition). We choose a uniform prior for the anisotropy scale radius as <em>r</em><sub>ani</sub> \u223c <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal{U}$|</span>(0.5\u03b8<sub>hl</sub>, 5\u03b8<sub>hl</sub>), where \u03b8<sub>hl</sub> is the half-light radius in the F160W band. As we model the deflector light distribution using a double S\u00e9rsic profile, we numerically compute the radius of the circular aperture that contains half of the total flux from the double S\u00e9rsic profile.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203530339 id=\"203530339\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2-2>6.2.2 Adding the external convergence distribution into the cosmological distance posterior</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We apply a selection criterion on the <em>P</em>(\u03ba<sub>ext</sub>) estimated in Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>) by requiring that the selected lines of sight also correspond to the external shear values predicted by our lens models. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, we show the probability distribution of \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> for the fiducial choice of constraints explored in Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>), and the two \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> distributions consistent with the external shear values for the power-law and composite mass profiles [see Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>) for further details].</p>                        <a id=\"203530341\" scrollto-destination=\"203530341\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=uiNCan66IUz15UKlfv4JAmVYWUVpGowmwKX09ujxdxsjq62GmnDYdcnkKii98vFIOc-GX-LrVX652JUcsQMLi7gE3GywVnjzh05iBIumRjT~dOF8wyzbu1yALhlI5-N95iGQom5zmVdtlpoZyRYZTDuuBmz~~-cgYGYLY~HEiSzlEqA8YuWFAyA4-tYilGCpV2BTretzto4RS~rx8m7YntaOzXYemLwV-I3u~33iAT5iNH7~bycI2ujwwTQeG7yQFjJGhgvGd8kEPOR8vQz3XI~POoYavSpD~bi5ZPGztV-GZZCcU9QtYBKEcwrhL7yLfn41bpq02SLqNyK86TtWFQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of external convergence \u03baext. The red and blue lines show the distributions with shear constraints from the power-law and the composite mass models, respectively.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=uiNCan66IUz15UKlfv4JAmVYWUVpGowmwKX09ujxdxsjq62GmnDYdcnkKii98vFIOc-GX-LrVX652JUcsQMLi7gE3GywVnjzh05iBIumRjT~dOF8wyzbu1yALhlI5-N95iGQom5zmVdtlpoZyRYZTDuuBmz~~-cgYGYLY~HEiSzlEqA8YuWFAyA4-tYilGCpV2BTretzto4RS~rx8m7YntaOzXYemLwV-I3u~33iAT5iNH7~bycI2ujwwTQeG7yQFjJGhgvGd8kEPOR8vQz3XI~POoYavSpD~bi5ZPGztV-GZZCcU9QtYBKEcwrhL7yLfn41bpq02SLqNyK86TtWFQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of external convergence \u03baext. The black line shows the \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> distribution from Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>) without imposing any shear constraint. The red and blue lines show the distributions with shear constraints from the power-law and the composite mass models, respectively.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We simple-sample from the external convergence distribution corresponding to each mass profile.We correct the distance posterior using the sampled external convergence according to equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ20\"></span><a href=\"#equ20\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">20</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> shows the comparison of distance posteriors between the mass model families and between different settings within a mass model family. The distance posteriors are consistent between different model setups. From the combined distance posterior from all the models, we obtain the 1D marginalized constraints for the effective time delay distance <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\Delta t}^{\\rm eff}=$|</span><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3382_{-115}^{+146}$|</span> Mpc and the angular diameter distance <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> = <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1711_{-280}^{+376}$|</span> Mpc (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"203530344\" scrollto-destination=\"203530344\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=MIrh52I~MBI3fbdFW7vElmwEEEIbyF1QVpyOvbmK1PbFivX~t~chqGG4haO-qscyUrIqUyMLf3yyQok3F2bWMxBAHZq8P6XT~shxIjveij4d-OvFZyI1Mie~vLBVDaxYDrul25omsz6eIxwSCGNehwdRhs7VModHNrad5CJESbdkBEyC~69rxD0kRDQAj9ElkasicUHf3vFY2ZcWh-Tt~O-4mV2x3MjzQwc4soaJ8SzH78zuyIzheYaRUkmSz7Z-vGX8Zpkkc81bV4s53EJIy~kt7OD-tAeeJmViT3EAbSG6nR4BTT4xLq3zUkXebRa3oRXoX7MmpzHfyrIPnszJWw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the distance posteriors between choices of the lens model setups for the power-law models (top row) and the composite models (bottom row). One of the posteriors mean is subtracted from all them and then they are normalized by the mean to get the relative shifts in percentage. The distance posteriors from different models are consistent.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=MIrh52I~MBI3fbdFW7vElmwEEEIbyF1QVpyOvbmK1PbFivX~t~chqGG4haO-qscyUrIqUyMLf3yyQok3F2bWMxBAHZq8P6XT~shxIjveij4d-OvFZyI1Mie~vLBVDaxYDrul25omsz6eIxwSCGNehwdRhs7VModHNrad5CJESbdkBEyC~69rxD0kRDQAj9ElkasicUHf3vFY2ZcWh-Tt~O-4mV2x3MjzQwc4soaJ8SzH78zuyIzheYaRUkmSz7Z-vGX8Zpkkc81bV4s53EJIy~kt7OD-tAeeJmViT3EAbSG6nR4BTT4xLq3zUkXebRa3oRXoX7MmpzHfyrIPnszJWw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the distance posteriors between choices of the lens model setups for the power-law models (top row) and the composite models (bottom row). The distance posteriors are weighted combinations of different runs with one common model setting as specified. One of the posteriors mean is subtracted from all them and then they are normalized by the mean to get the relative shifts in percentage. Left-hand panel: the distance posteriors for different settings of the source components\u2019 nmax. Centre: the distance posteriors for different redshifts of S3. Right-hand panel: the distance posteriors for SIS and NFW mass profiles for the line-of-sight galaxies. The distance posteriors from different models are consistent.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530344/staa828fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530344\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=4x45vCCII~EzlYPk49HGhcQbO-SptkgCVX0f4kIJMbKwSUp25hzZ--UVBwLEsVfzRJuZW2kCfqAqNgPgsuju8Rb8b2YEMS2iaaXOROTEbduSfkzOLwSxCOhKgxMv6xn1wbxdNZJ401d5nLHEjwiwuOdA0v~lU0YzxJ3tg-PP6TUiStZ4t9j4KywjDntNkYTK3uh8hD1Leg2cX5qhrD7aAZlhPKS40B-SgQ9ACQPEoXmQ2bLwz00I5wb~UxeYkdlbMeq98K-Dz-TRT3tzJFiXjD1~6notvbXG3Eisi-AXiXvrjVLiOvREZqD75izZLP43ie2BTiOROQ~F9stEcUPSzw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530344&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the distance posteriors between choices of the lens model setups for the power-law models (top row) and the composite models (bottom row). The distance posteriors are weighted combinations of different runs with one common model setting as specified. One of the posteriors mean is subtracted from all them and then they are normalized by the mean to get the relative shifts in percentage. Left-hand panel: the distance posteriors for different settings of the source components\u2019 <em>n</em><sub>max</sub>. Centre: the distance posteriors for different redshifts of S3. Right-hand panel: the distance posteriors for SIS and NFW mass profiles for the line-of-sight galaxies. The distance posteriors from different models are consistent.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"203530345\" scrollto-destination=\"203530345\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=KyDqLOWOFTeXxTdUlhRHbfsZx3lVp4nkEKGfd4t50TNV9fO8A3NXymtozOJwTY74Jm8-JixNBA~EMRdeAkSnZMgYvkmUvymJ0oull4qPF11CTpvXhTmgotusZ72TMaYy~7NLXTAvz93AnOfXqdeldJKNR2kHWpGf3~i7kyIwvEVeXyrBK~UiP6QCbd~IF7sk7cdGiX6PLeXqEP01Uy9AyjaokgVnpKRkke5S~iDOYwEOjHV~3iJj4bN6W3EjFClnHeTXwzvAA88tsQxlxx071FCroDpkDVp9pxMU41jrAW2BVuWcqN-iLYGQSzTFjGULo8kqUlJD5yEr6QiyNDebBg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cosmological distance posteriors for power-law (red) and composite mass-profile families (blue), and for all models combined (purple). All the models are combined within each categories weighted by their adjusted evidence ratios (Table\u00a04). The solid contours for the power-law and composite mass profiles are without accounting for the microlensing time-delay effect (MTDE), and the corresponding dashed contours show the ones with the MTDE. The MTDE is negligible in our analysis and we do not incorporate this effect in the final distance posterior (purple contours) combining all the models.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530345/staa828fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530345\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=2zfiVOEsgPfvE1MrdKl5RYY89w41jWMj1UGNS9Ys2HHn4STwOvyc1vqnNHO3Y6rtSgizvoGI7JeDxay~hcAVNLULu5DOWHCXA7f7~RPpoZdB6dXQVpwotwRGtu5vv6NktuP10IFT5q-N~H2lmKBCxWGlmX42mn6xCvwk8Rj~ix78FamcwZXPKbwJZJRoGjEk85q8v4eyRMl2u7f4GKcG-8c3WKDG1Hl7DGrVFBD~EoCJpLJuM-Pji2-wBRVZUqLcyPZkM2ggHpuvV8ZSEeoH-C3LRcES5rbv3yVsK0Jrjl1rfNr4AWkHkLWRJtVX8GqyBULLlh~-qLvgNiEkN9pQ3w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530345&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cosmological distance posteriors for power-law (red) and composite mass-profile families (blue), and for all models combined (purple). All the models are combined within each categories weighted by their adjusted evidence ratios (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). The solid contours for the power-law and composite mass profiles are without accounting for the microlensing time-delay effect (MTDE), and the corresponding dashed contours show the ones with the MTDE. The MTDE is negligible in our analysis and we do not incorporate this effect in the final distance posterior (purple contours) combining all the models.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=KyDqLOWOFTeXxTdUlhRHbfsZx3lVp4nkEKGfd4t50TNV9fO8A3NXymtozOJwTY74Jm8-JixNBA~EMRdeAkSnZMgYvkmUvymJ0oull4qPF11CTpvXhTmgotusZ72TMaYy~7NLXTAvz93AnOfXqdeldJKNR2kHWpGf3~i7kyIwvEVeXyrBK~UiP6QCbd~IF7sk7cdGiX6PLeXqEP01Uy9AyjaokgVnpKRkke5S~iDOYwEOjHV~3iJj4bN6W3EjFClnHeTXwzvAA88tsQxlxx071FCroDpkDVp9pxMU41jrAW2BVuWcqN-iLYGQSzTFjGULo8kqUlJD5yEr6QiyNDebBg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cosmological distance posteriors for power-law (red) and composite mass-profile families (blue), and for all models combined (purple). All the models are combined within each categories weighted by their adjusted evidence ratios (Table\u00a04). The solid contours for the power-law and composite mass profiles are without accounting for the microlensing time-delay effect (MTDE), and the corresponding dashed contours show the ones with the MTDE. The MTDE is negligible in our analysis and we do not incorporate this effect in the final distance posterior (purple contours) combining all the models.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530345/staa828fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530345\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=2zfiVOEsgPfvE1MrdKl5RYY89w41jWMj1UGNS9Ys2HHn4STwOvyc1vqnNHO3Y6rtSgizvoGI7JeDxay~hcAVNLULu5DOWHCXA7f7~RPpoZdB6dXQVpwotwRGtu5vv6NktuP10IFT5q-N~H2lmKBCxWGlmX42mn6xCvwk8Rj~ix78FamcwZXPKbwJZJRoGjEk85q8v4eyRMl2u7f4GKcG-8c3WKDG1Hl7DGrVFBD~EoCJpLJuM-Pji2-wBRVZUqLcyPZkM2ggHpuvV8ZSEeoH-C3LRcES5rbv3yVsK0Jrjl1rfNr4AWkHkLWRJtVX8GqyBULLlh~-qLvgNiEkN9pQ3w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530345&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cosmological distance posteriors for power-law (red) and composite mass-profile families (blue), and for all models combined (purple). All the models are combined within each categories weighted by their adjusted evidence ratios (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). The solid contours for the power-law and composite mass profiles are without accounting for the microlensing time-delay effect (MTDE), and the corresponding dashed contours show the ones with the MTDE. The MTDE is negligible in our analysis and we do not incorporate this effect in the final distance posterior (purple contours) combining all the models.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203530346 id=\"203530346\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2-3>6.2.3 Microlensing time-delay effect</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We check the impact of microlensing by the deflector galaxy\u2019s stars on the measured time-delays in our analysis (Tie &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Note, this microlensing time-delay from Tie &amp; Kochanek (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) is based on the lamp-post model for the AGN accretion disc (Shakura &amp; Sunyaev <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1973</a>). This effect will not necessarily exist for other disc models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We generate the microlensing time-delay maps following Bonvin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) and Chen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The estimated microlensing time-delay depends on the magnification of the lens model, on the stellar contribution at the image position, and on the properties of the black hole\u2019s accretion disc</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We estimate the black hole mass using the scaling relation <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ56\" content-id=\"equ56\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\log _{10} \\left ( \\frac{M_{\\rm BH,Mg\\,{\\small II}}}{M_{\\odot }} \\right ) = b + m\\,\\log _{10}\\left ( \\frac{\\rm EW_{\\rm Mg\\,{\\small II}}}{\\mathring{\\rm A}} \\right ) \\nonumber\\\\\r\n+\\,2\\,\\log _{10} \\left(\\frac{\\rm FWHM_{Mg\\,{\\small II}}}{\\rm km\\,s^{-1}} \\right)\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(56)</span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">between the black hole mass <em>M</em><sub>BH, vir</sub>, and the rest-frame full width at half-maximum (FWHM) and equivalent width (EW) of the Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> broad line. This equation is equivalent to the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm BH} \\propto R_{\\rm BLR} \\sigma _{\\rm BLR}^2$|\u2060</span>, where <em>R</em><sub>BLR</sub> is the radius of the broad-line region and \u03c3<sub>BLR</sub> is the velocity dispersion of the broad-line region. Here, we used the EW as a proxy for <em>R</em><sub>BLR</sub> and the FWHM as a proxy for \u03c3<sub>BLR</sub> [cf. equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ2\"></span><a href=\"#equ2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>) of Shen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>)]. We estimate the parameters of this scaling relation using the SDSS quasars from the catalogue provided by Shen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) as <em>b</em> = 2.71 and <em>m</em> = \u22120.61. We only take the quasars with non-zero entries for <em>M</em><sub>BH, vir</sub>, FWHM<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{\\rm Mg\\,{\\small II}}$|\u2060</span>, and EW<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{\\rm Mg\\,{\\small II}}$|\u2060</span>. Moreover, we only select the quasars within 1300\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> &lt; FWHM<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{\\rm Mg\\,{\\small II}}$|</span> &lt; 30\u2009000\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> to remove the quasars creating stripe-like features at the boundaries of the <em>M</em><sub>BH, vir</sub>\u2013FWHM<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{\\rm Mg\\,{\\small II}}$|</span> scatter plot. As a result, we have 85\u2009038 selected quasars to fit the above scaling relation. We obtain the rest-frame FWHM and EW of the Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> line from the quasar spectra at image B and image D from Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) as FWHM<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{\\rm Mg\\,{\\small II}}^{\\rm B}$|</span> = 3413\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, EW<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{\\rm Mg\\,{\\small II}}^{\\rm D}$|</span> = 37.3\u2009\u00c5, FWHM<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{\\rm Mg\\,{\\small II}}^{\\rm D}$|</span> = 2952\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, EW<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{\\rm Mg\\,{\\small II}}^{\\rm B}$|</span> = 30.5\u2009\u00c5. We apply a magnification correction to the estimated black hole mass from each image as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ57\" content-id=\"equ57\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\log _{10} \\left(\\frac{M_{\\rm BH}}{M_{\\odot}} \\right) = \\log _{10} \\left(\\frac{M_{\\rm BH, Mg\\,{\\small II}}}{M_{\\odot }} \\right) - g \\log _{\\rm 10} \\mu ,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(57)</span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">where we take the calibration factor <em>g</em> = 0.5 (Vestergaard &amp; Peterson <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). We also add 0.25 dex uncertainty to the estimated black hole mass to account for the limitation of using Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> to measure it (Woo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Averaging over the estimates from image B and D, we obtain the black hole mass of the quasar as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log _{10} \\left(M_{\\rm BH,vir}^{\\rm J0408}/M_{\\odot }\\right) = 8.41 \\pm 0.27$|\u2060</span>. We also estimate the Eddington ratio using the scaling relation <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ58\" content-id=\"equ58\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\log _{\\rm 10} \\left(\\frac{L_{\\rm bol}^\\prime }{L_{\\rm Edd}^\\prime } \\right) = b + m\\log _{10} \\left(\\frac{M_{\\rm BH, Mg\\,{\\small II}}}{M_{\\odot }} \\right).\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(58)</span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We estimate <em>m</em> = \u22120.33, <em>b</em> = 2.2 with an intrinsic scatter of 0.64\u2009dex by fitting the relation to the same objects selected from Shen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>)\u2019s catalogue. We also apply a magnification correction on the Eddington ratio obtained for each image as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ59\" content-id=\"equ59\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\log _{\\rm 10} \\left(\\frac{L_{\\rm bol}}{L_{\\rm Edd}} \\right) = \\log _{\\rm 10} \\left(\\frac{L_{\\rm bol}^\\prime }{L_{\\rm Edd}^\\prime } \\right) + (g-1) \\log _{10} \\mu\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(59)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">(Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). As a result, we obtain log<sub>10</sub>(<em>L</em><sub>bol</sub>/<em>L</em><sub>Edd</sub>) = \u22121.48\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.27 after averaging over the estimates from images B and D. The accretion disc size <em>R</em><sub>0</sub> is determined assuming a standard accretion disc model (Shakura &amp; Sunyaev <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1973</a>). In Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, we tabulate the values used to create the microlensing time delay maps shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>. We assumed Salpeter initial mass function (IMF) and ignored the uncertainty on the convergence and shear parameters. Shifting the stellar convergence \u03ba<sub>\u22c6</sub> by the typical uncertainty of 10 per cent or changing the IMF has negligible impact on the estimated microlensing time-delay distribution in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"203530354\" scrollto-destination=\"203530354\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=0TRxxce43NUa2SXwHHfZYLgjF4QUrrBs6MeEwGlnbUk9cphXrpspA8PKehNa4iBHTECa0iE1zCAXtpUBletWoyThW5rY2idtJlr3dHWjoLcZ0tj--joETjPtz9bTOa4McACobN6v~YOgL7wjNNWtKX7vFPxfIQj0SE2z5BhlOhtfQMku5SnZhjtggiIcwQORAXKGy3TYT5lUYc5wnIYTkGR5b2CWpA2vBFI8W4b04jp4Ik0yxuHXNbstrpj4ID5RddmQqdso8sGi8wMoQVsUQAm1J1cJXhJ5dLp4s-8G-U88HwnPlTx7K2s698jRuEebgm3LWLQzv~uPJnWWceom2A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Microlensing time-delay maps and the probability of microlensing time-delays for images A, B, and D. Each microlensing time-delay map on the left-hand column is created from the relevant image magnification, stellar contribution to the convergence at the image position, and the accretion disc properties of the black hole. The probability density function of the microlensing time-delay at each image position is shown in the right-hand column. The expected fluctuation in the measured time-delays is small relative to the measurement uncertainty.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530354/staa828fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530354\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=APhEwewJ8TNAuGIQtK-61B9FeOHTWVR02zD57Ruhn5cAZSDqzRCsua7pcV9-a-UH829ivRa5O0Hw1Yme4XDhP9uYccrU6c2JRDSwq0bTH1kGPGbpYxmT15i7HTIffT2Gg9wf7Qubm-HBPzTA1xhWIBpHmL1KDd3uHXkTZsZBk4PZMaseaeePawVQ4kaSN1BdBmwxI5zeY9XQv9tSRrnSsd77yjyKdpIkTcvztxR0cHrfaL2JHBH5AP8KrVjPP7xWWnnqVD61s4D9loiZar2NsiJJxTHHgLxWnSV8~Lbp-LhpsdbIiwsrVSASwOgOz-eFwu55eK9YwIUPCLrK-M8dvw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530354&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Microlensing time-delay maps and the probability of microlensing time-delays for images A, B, and D. Each microlensing time-delay map on the left-hand column is created from the relevant image magnification, stellar contribution to the convergence at the image position, and the accretion disc properties of the black hole. The probability density function of the microlensing time-delay at each image position is shown in the right-hand column. The expected fluctuation in the measured time-delays is small relative to the measurement uncertainty.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=0TRxxce43NUa2SXwHHfZYLgjF4QUrrBs6MeEwGlnbUk9cphXrpspA8PKehNa4iBHTECa0iE1zCAXtpUBletWoyThW5rY2idtJlr3dHWjoLcZ0tj--joETjPtz9bTOa4McACobN6v~YOgL7wjNNWtKX7vFPxfIQj0SE2z5BhlOhtfQMku5SnZhjtggiIcwQORAXKGy3TYT5lUYc5wnIYTkGR5b2CWpA2vBFI8W4b04jp4Ik0yxuHXNbstrpj4ID5RddmQqdso8sGi8wMoQVsUQAm1J1cJXhJ5dLp4s-8G-U88HwnPlTx7K2s698jRuEebgm3LWLQzv~uPJnWWceom2A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Microlensing time-delay maps and the probability of microlensing time-delays for images A, B, and D. Each microlensing time-delay map on the left-hand column is created from the relevant image magnification, stellar contribution to the convergence at the image position, and the accretion disc properties of the black hole. The probability density function of the microlensing time-delay at each image position is shown in the right-hand column. The expected fluctuation in the measured time-delays is small relative to the measurement uncertainty.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530354/staa828fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530354\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=APhEwewJ8TNAuGIQtK-61B9FeOHTWVR02zD57Ruhn5cAZSDqzRCsua7pcV9-a-UH829ivRa5O0Hw1Yme4XDhP9uYccrU6c2JRDSwq0bTH1kGPGbpYxmT15i7HTIffT2Gg9wf7Qubm-HBPzTA1xhWIBpHmL1KDd3uHXkTZsZBk4PZMaseaeePawVQ4kaSN1BdBmwxI5zeY9XQv9tSRrnSsd77yjyKdpIkTcvztxR0cHrfaL2JHBH5AP8KrVjPP7xWWnnqVD61s4D9loiZar2NsiJJxTHHgLxWnSV8~Lbp-LhpsdbIiwsrVSASwOgOz-eFwu55eK9YwIUPCLrK-M8dvw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530354&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Microlensing time-delay maps and the probability of microlensing time-delays for images A, B, and D. Each microlensing time-delay map on the left-hand column is created from the relevant image magnification, stellar contribution to the convergence at the image position, and the accretion disc properties of the black hole. The probability density function of the microlensing time-delay at each image position is shown in the right-hand column. The expected fluctuation in the measured time-delays is small relative to the measurement uncertainty.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"203530355\" scrollto-destination=\"203530355\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing quantities at the image positions used to create the microlensing time-delay map. The total convergence \u03ba, the stellar convergence \u03ba<sub>\u22c6</sub>, the shear \u03b3<sub>shear</sub>, and the magnification \u03bc are obtained from the best-fitting composite model. As the local slope of the composite model at the image positions can deviate from the 3D slope \u03b3 = 2 of an isothermal profile, \u03ba and \u03b3<sub>shear</sub> are not necessarily identical.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>TImage<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03ba<span .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b3<sub>shear</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03bc<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>A\u00a0</td><td>0.46\u00a0</td><td>0.03\u00a0</td><td>0.19\u00a0</td><td>3.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B\u00a0</td><td>0.59\u00a0</td><td>0.06\u00a0</td><td>0.32\u00a0</td><td>15.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>D\u00a0</td><td>0.70\u00a0</td><td>0.13\u00a0</td><td>0.69\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.6\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>TImage<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03ba<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03ba<sub>\u22c6</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b3<sub>shear</sub><span class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/203530355\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing quantities at the image positions used to create the microlensing time-delay map. The total convergence \u03ba, the stellar convergence \u03ba<sub>\u22c6</sub>, the shear \u03b3<sub>shear</sub>, and the magnification \u03bc are obtained from the best-fitting composite model. As the local slope of the composite model at the image positions can deviate from the 3D slope \u03b3 = 2 of an isothermal profile, \u03ba and \u03b3<sub>shear</sub> are not necessarily identical.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>TImage<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03ba<span          .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>A\u00a0</td><td>0.46\u00a0</td><td>0.03\u00a0</td><td>0.19\u00a0</td><td>3.9\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B\u00a0</td><td>0.59\u00a0</td><td>0.06\u00a0</td><td>0.32\u00a0</td><td>15.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>D\u00a0</td><td>0.70\u00a0</td><td>0.13\u00a0</td><td>0.69\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.6\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div        </a></div></div></div>                        <a id=\"203530356\" scrollto-destination=\"203530356\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl6\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div
