graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/203530211\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203530212 id=\"203530212\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-5-1>2.5.1 Lens model posterior and evidence from imaging likelihood</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We can first obtain the posterior of the lens model parameters \u039e \u2261 {\u03be<sub>lens</sub>, \u03be<sub>light</sub>, \u03be<sub>source</sub>, \u03be<sub>pert</sub>} as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ27\" content-id=\"equ27\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\np(\\Xi \\mid O_{\\rm img}, M, S) = \\frac{p(O_{\\rm img} \\mid \\Xi , M, S)\\ p(\\Xi \\mid M, S)}{p(O_{\\rm img} \\mid M, S)}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(27)</span></div>Here, the term in the denominator <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {Z} \\equiv p(O_{\\rm img} \\mid M, S)$|</span> is the evidence for the imaging data <em>O</em><sub>img</sub> given the model {<em>M, S</em>}. We first change the variables <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lbrace \\xi _{\\rm lens},\\xi _{\\rm pert} \\rbrace \\rightarrow \\lbrace \\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\Delta \\phi ^{\\rm eff}_{\\rm XY} \\rbrace$|</span> in equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ27\"></span><a href=\"#equ27\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">27</a>) to be able to marginalize over parameters related to the line-of-sight galaxies while retaining their effect on the Fermat potential difference \u0394\u03d5<sub>XY</sub>. As the Jacobian determinant <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\vert \\mathrm{d}\\lbrace \\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff} \\rbrace / \\mathrm{d}\\lbrace \\xi _{\\rm lens},\\xi _{\\rm pert} \\rbrace \\vert$|</span> cancels out from both sides, we have <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ28\" content-id=\"equ28\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n&amp;&amp;p(\\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\xi _{\\rm source}, \\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff} \\mid O_{\\rm img}, M, S) \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\quad=\\ p(O_{\\rm img} \\mid \\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\xi _{\\rm source}, \\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff}, M, S) \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\qquad\\times \\frac{p(\\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\xi _{\\rm source}, \\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff} \\mid M, S)}{p(O_{\\rm img} \\mid M, S)}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(28)</span></div>We can marginalize this posterior over \u03be<sub>source</sub> and <em>S</em> as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ29\" content-id=\"equ29\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n&amp;&amp; p(\\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff} \\mid O_{\\rm img}, M) \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\quad = \\int p(\\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\xi _{\\rm source}, \\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff} \\mid O_{\\rm img}, S, M) \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\qquad \\times p(S)\\ \\mathrm{d}\\xi _{\\rm source} \\ \\mathrm{d}S.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(29)</span></div>Since the term inside the integral contains the evidence term <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {Z}$|\u2060</span>, the integral over the model space <em>S</em> automatically weights the models {<em>S</em>} according to their evidence ratios. As we can only discretely sample models {<em>S<sub>n</sub></em>} from the model space <em>S</em>, the integral in equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ27\"></span><a href=\"#equ27\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">27</a>) becomes a discrete sum as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ30\" content-id=\"equ30\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n&amp;&amp; p(\\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff} \\mid O_{\\rm img}, M) \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\quad = \\sum _{n} \\Delta S_n \\int p(\\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\xi _{\\rm source}, \\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff} \\mid O_{\\rm img}, S_n, M) \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\qquad \\times p(S_n)\\ \\mathrm{d}\\xi _{\\rm source}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(30)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, the term \u0394<em>S<sub>n</sub></em> can be interpreted as the model space volume represented by the model <em>S<sub>n</sub></em>, thus it can account for sparse sampling from the model space.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In our model, we have both linear and non-linear parameters. The linear parameters are the amplitudes of the surface brightness profiles that we treat with a basis set in our model (Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). We denote the linear parameters using the vector <strong>\u03bb</strong> and non-linear parameters using the set \u03bd. Hence, the lens model parameters can alternatively be expressed as \u039e \u2261 {\u03bd, <strong>\u03bb</strong>}. We can write the evidence integral as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ31\" content-id=\"equ31\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\mathcal {Z} = \\int p(O_{\\rm img} \\mid \\nu , \\boldsymbol\\lambda , M, S)\\ p(\\boldsymbol\\lambda \\mid M, S)\\ p(\\nu \\mid M, S)\\ \\mathrm{d}\\boldsymbol\\lambda \\ \\mathrm{d}\\nu . \\nonumber \\\\\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(31)</span></div>We can first marginalize over the linear parameters to get the likelihood <em>P</em>(<em>O</em><sub>img</sub>\u2223\u03bd, <em>M, S</em>) in terms of only the non-linear parameters as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ32\" content-id=\"equ32\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\np(O_{\\rm img} \\mid \\nu , M, S) = \\int p(O_{\\rm img} \\mid \\nu , \\boldsymbol\\lambda , M, S) \\ p(\\boldsymbol\\lambda \\mid M, S) \\ \\mathrm{d}\\boldsymbol\\lambda . \\nonumber \\\\\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(32)</span></div>If <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol {\\hat{\\lambda }}$|</span> is the maximum-likelihood estimator of <em>P</em>(<em>O</em><sub>img</sub>\u2223\u03bd, <strong>\u03bb</strong>, <em>M, S</em>) for given {\u03bd, <em>M, S</em>}, then we can approximate the likelihood using up to the second order terms in the Taylor expansion in the vicinity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol {\\hat{\\lambda }}$|</span> as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ33\" content-id=\"equ33\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\np(O_{\\rm img} \\mid \\nu , \\boldsymbol \\lambda , M, S) &amp;\\approx &amp;\\ p(O_{\\rm img} \\mid \\nu , \\boldsymbol {\\hat{\\lambda }}, M, S) \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp; \\times \\, \\exp \\left[ - \\frac{1}{2} \\Delta \\boldsymbol{\\lambda} ^{\\mathsf {T}} \\boldsymbol {\\mathsf {K}}_{\\boldsymbol{\\lambda \\lambda }}^{-1} \\Delta \\boldsymbol{\\lambda} \\right]\\!,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(33)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\boldsymbol{\\lambda} = \\boldsymbol {\\lambda} - \\boldsymbol {\\hat{\\lambda }}$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol {\\mathsf {K}}_{\\boldsymbol{\\lambda \\lambda }}$|</span> is the covariance matrix of <strong>\u03bb</strong> (equation [12] of Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). We can directly obtain <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{\\hat{\\lambda }}$|</span> given the set of non-linear parameters \u03bd by solving a set of linear equations. If we take a uniform prior <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal{U}(-\\boldsymbol {w}/2, \\boldsymbol {w}/2)$|</span> for <strong>\u03bb</strong>, then from equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ32\"></span><a href=\"#equ32\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">32</a>) we have <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ34\" content-id=\"equ34\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\np(O_{\\rm img} \\mid \\nu , M, S) \\approx p(O_{\\rm img} \\mid \\nu , \\boldsymbol{\\hat{\\lambda }}, M, S) \\frac{\\left[ (2\\pi)^n \\det \\left(\\boldsymbol {\\mathsf {K}}_{\\boldsymbol{\\lambda \\lambda }}\\right) \\right]^{1/2}}{\\prod _i^n w_i}, \\nonumber \\\\\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(34)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$n = \\dim (\\boldsymbol\\lambda)$|</span> is the number of linear parameters. Then, we can express the evidence as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ35\" content-id=\"equ35\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\mathcal {Z} \\approx \\frac{\\left[ (2\\pi)^n \\det \\left(\\boldsymbol {\\mathsf {K}}_{\\boldsymbol{\\lambda \\lambda }} \\right) \\right]^{1/2}}{\\prod _i^n w_i} \\!\\int \\! p(O_{\\rm img} \\mid \\nu , \\boldsymbol{\\hat{\\lambda }}, M, S)\\ p(\\nu \\mid M, S)\\ \\mathrm{d}\\nu . \\nonumber \\\\\r\n\\nonumber\\\\[-1.2pc]\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(35)</span></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203530216 id=\"203530216\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-5-2>2.5.2 Joint posterior combining time delay and kinematics likelihoods</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Next, we can fold in the time-delay likelihood to update the posterior and marginalize over the Fermat potential <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff}$|</span> as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ36\" content-id=\"equ36\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n&amp;&amp; p(D, \\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\kappa _{\\rm ext} \\mid O_{\\rm img}, O_{\\Delta t}, O_{\\rm env}, M) \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\quad\\propto \\int p(O_{\\Delta t} \\mid \\Delta t(D, \\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff}, \\kappa _{\\rm ext}; O_{\\rm img}, O_{\\rm env}, M))\\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\qquad \\times p(\\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff} \\mid O_{\\rm img}, M) \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp; \\qquad \\times p(\\kappa _{\\rm ext} \\mid O_{\\rm env}) \\ p(D) \\ \\mathrm{d}\\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(36)</span></div>Tie &amp; Kochanek (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) introduce a possible microlensing time-delay effect due to the asymmetric magnification of a quasar accretion disc \u2013 assuming the lamppost model (Shakura &amp; Sunyaev <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1973</a>) \u2013 due to microlensing by the foreground stars in the deflector galaxy. Note, the time-delay measurement from the quasar light curves accounts for the long-term variation in the microlensing magnification pattern. Tie &amp; Kochanek (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>)\u2019s microlensing time-delay effect is due to the non-uniform weighting of the quasar accretion disc brightness by the microlensing magnification pattern, thus this effect depends on the gradient of the magnification across the accretion disc. The long-term change in the magnification pattern is not necessarily correlated with the gradient of the magnification across the accretion disc. For the case that marginalizes over this microlensing time-delay effect, the above equation becomes <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ37\" content-id=\"equ37\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n&amp;&amp; p(D, \\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\kappa _{\\rm ext} \\mid O_{\\rm img}, O_{\\Delta t}, O_{\\rm env}, M) \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\quad \\propto \\int p(O_{\\Delta t} \\mid \\Delta t(D, \\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\xi _{\\rm micro}, \\kappa _{\\rm ext}, \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\qquad\\times \\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff}; O_{\\rm img}, O_{\\rm env}, M)) \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp; \\qquad \\times p(\\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff} \\mid O_{\\rm img}, M) \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp; \\qquad \\times p(\\kappa _{\\rm ext} \\mid O_{\\rm env})\\ p(\\xi _{\\rm micro}) \\ p(D) \\ \\mathrm{d}\\Delta \\phi _{\\rm XY}^{\\rm eff}\\ \\mathrm{d}\\xi _{\\rm micro},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(37)</span></div>where \u03be<sub>micro</sub> is the set of parameters relevant to the microlensing time-delay effect, e.g. parameters related to the properties of the black hole and the accretion disc (Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.2.3</a>).</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Then, we can update the posterior once again by folding in the kinematic likelihood as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ38\" content-id=\"equ38\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n&amp;&amp; p(D, \\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\kappa _{\\rm ext}, \\xi _{\\beta } \\mid O_{\\rm img}, O_{\\Delta t}, O_{\\rm kin}, O_{\\rm env}, M) \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\quad= p(O_{\\rm kin} \\mid \\sigma _{\\rm los}(D, \\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\kappa _{\\rm ext}, \\xi _{\\beta }; M)) \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\qquad \\times p(\\xi _{\\beta } \\mid \\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, M) \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\qquad \\times p(D, \\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\kappa _{\\rm ext} \\mid O_{\\rm img}, O_{\\Delta t}, M).\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(38)</span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Now, we can marginalize over the model parameters to obtain the posterior of the cosmological distances <em>D</em> as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ39\" content-id=\"equ39\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n&amp;&amp; p(D \\mid O, M) = p(D \\mid O_{\\rm img}, O_{\\Delta t}, O_{\\rm kin}, O_{\\rm env}, M) \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\quad= \\int p(D, \\xi _{\\rm lens}, \\xi _{\\rm light}, \\kappa _{\\rm ext}, \\xi _{\\beta } \\mid O_{\\rm img}, O_{\\Delta t}, O_{\\rm kin}, O_{\\rm env}, M) \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\qquad \\times \\mathrm{d}\\xi _{\\beta } \\ \\mathrm{d}\\kappa _{\\rm ext}\\ \\mathrm{d}\\xi _{\\rm lens} \\ \\mathrm{d}\\xi _{\\rm light}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(39)</span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Finally, we can marginalize over the deflector mass model choices as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ40\" content-id=\"equ40\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\np(D \\mid O) = \\sum _{M} p(D \\mid O, M)\\ p(M \\mid O).\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(40)</span></div>A particular choice of mass model <em>M</em> breaks the MSD (Schneider &amp; Sluse <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). However, we cannot ascertain that our adopted mass model choice represents the true mass distribution. As a result, we cannot weigh different mass models according to their evidence ratios as a higher evidence value may just be a fluke from breaking the MSD near a better fit of the data. Therefore, we take <em>p</em>(<em>M</em>\u2223<em>O</em>) = 1 to equally weight different deflector mass model choices.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">As the likelihood <em>p</em>(<em>O</em>\u2223<em>D</em>) follows the proportionality relation <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ41\" content-id=\"equ41\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\np(O \\mid D) \\propto \\frac{p(D \\mid O)}{p(D)},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(41)</span></div>we can then use the distance posterior <em>p</em>(<em>D</em>\u2223<em>O</em>) to obtain the posterior of the cosmological parameters <em>p</em>(\u03c9\u2223<em>O, C</em>) from equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ24\"></span><a href=\"#equ24\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">24</a>).</div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203530222 id=\"203530222\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 THE LENS SYSTEM AND DATA SETS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we perform cosmographic analyses of the lens systems DES J0408\u20135354. This lens was discovered and confirmed by Lin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) from a large sample of potential galaxy\u2013galaxy lenses in the DES footprint (Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) acquired follow-up data and modelled the system presenting evidence for a faint perturber G2 near one of the quasar images, which was later confirmed by the deeper and higher resolution imaging from the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>; Shajib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The necessary data sets and ancillary measurements for cosmographic analysis are</p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">high-resolution imaging of the lens system,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">spectroscopy of the lens components to measure redshifts,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">measured time-delays between the images,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">LOS velocity dispersion of the central deflector galaxy, and</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">estimate of the external convergence.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">Each type of data set or ancillary measurement is described in the following subsections.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530227 id=\"203530227\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 <em>HST</em> imaging of the lens system</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> Wide-Field Camera 3 (WFC3) imaging was obtained under the program GO-15320 (PI: Treu; Shajib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). The images were taken in three filters: F160W in infrared (IR), F814W and F475X in ultraviolet\u2013visual (<em>UVIS</em>). For each filter, four exposures \u2013 two short and two long \u2013 were taken to cover the large dynamic range in brightness encompassing the bright quasar images and the fainter extended host galaxy. For the IR band, we chose a 4-point dither pattern and STEP100 readout sequence for the MULTIACCUM mode. For the <em>UVIS</em> bands, we adopted a 2-point dither pattern. The total exposure times for the three filters are 2196.9\u00a0s in F160W, 1428\u00a0s in F814W, and 1348\u00a0s in F475X.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The data in each band were reduced with the standard <span class=\"small-caps\">astrodrizzle</span> package (Avila et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). The final pixel scale after drizzling is 0.08 arcsec in the IR band, and 0.04 arcsec in the <em>UVIS</em> band. We estimate the background level in the reduced image from each band using <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> and subtract it from the reduced image (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows the colour-composite image for the lens system and its surrounding. The central deflector galaxy G1 has a visible satellite galaxy G2. The four prominent nearby galaxies along the line of sight are marked with G3, G4, G5, and G6. Note that the naming convention of these galaxies is different in Lin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"203530231\" scrollto-destination=\"203530231\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=G~euS2vxC6J3Z8NKh6tVyO2Is-Th-lUXHpm1DJybzxHe-3nGhSje8WDig77CwXvSyg9cgzCuAgaDMj7gzdRWiCJosVfvf1TJRzsgzzdIYMWAEDgNRIfzXrj77nm5iuxdR-6bzt7MFyWKkHKBY1MTeQXHL00ajT2fyu4Klsvmgu90Id9fRxVUZ4nE4YacaScsICzYH5kPJt-~j3SbyAFjjQ-jPunSIw7jZL5M-K0xWB2utfwJh5SY5aRxVj71gf781blyb37ywg7f-UxfwYfIgkm9jjm~yU1nBeOi6HXkS6dFu9C~oxVrCATkgyeFQF6wLHUDmcP3eCYhTUKPbVxv8w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"RGB colour composite of the lens systems DES J0408\u20135354. The three HST filters used to create the RGB image are F160W (red), F814W (green), and F475X (blue). The relative amplitudes between the three filters are adjusted in this figure for better visualization by achieving a higher contrast. We label different components of the lens system. G1 is the main deflector galaxy and G2 is its satellite galaxy. In addition to the lensed arcs from the extended quasar host galaxy, this lens system has extra source components S2 and S3. The source component S2 is doubly imaged and forms an extended arc inside the Einstein radius. S3 forms another fainter extended arc on the North-East outside the Einstein radius without a noticeable counter-image. Four nearby perturbers G3\u2013G6 along the line of sight are marked with the dashed, white circles.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530231/staa828fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530231\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=fTzthzMINELINS~GfV8MLF4KkuHukSMEKZ~jb3JDgOjS5XGW06sYtLlG31li7AOPN-9Ixyq81bPAfzxN39dNbCSnvhBD1nC4wbK-1ubq6~Pfu3ixZOhNnxwgilRv9MBZYVl1ZASq3tW4KjGTryW-1idOcL38SRHQNtLtQsApI8paPct72~iULBf-GzyivYBtFGFp0roKRR9EWwUyivf1WjunEdn6cHBIzRz02ET2TRctWHV7jfJXkL8qcqPXMMO7~jO2KfcTRRhcoUKVKJp4~6~D3eDCCcVruaZh0J3JDpyi-jyTOLTWz7Z7I4rnJbPq9siLoQYiyLsGI2zYoILSWA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530231&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">RGB colour composite of the lens systems DES J0408\u20135354. The three <em>HST</em> filters used to create the RGB image are F160W (red), F814W (green), and F475X (blue). The relative amplitudes between the three filters are adjusted in this figure for better visualization by achieving a higher contrast. We label different components of the lens system. G1 is the main deflector galaxy and G2 is its satellite galaxy. In addition to the lensed arcs from the extended quasar host galaxy, this lens system has extra source components S2 and S3. The source component S2 is doubly imaged and forms an extended arc inside the Einstein radius. S3 forms another fainter extended arc on the North-East outside the Einstein radius without a noticeable counter-image. Four nearby perturbers G3\u2013G6 along the line of sight are marked with the dashed, white circles.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=G~euS2vxC6J3Z8NKh6tVyO2Is-Th-lUXHpm1DJybzxHe-3nGhSje8WDig77CwXvSyg9cgzCuAgaDMj7gzdRWiCJosVfvf1TJRzsgzzdIYMWAEDgNRIfzXrj77nm5iuxdR-6bzt7MFyWKkHKBY1MTeQXHL00ajT2fyu4Klsvmgu90Id9fRxVUZ4nE4YacaScsICzYH5kPJt-~j3SbyAFjjQ-jPunSIw7jZL5M-K0xWB2utfwJh5SY5aRxVj71gf781blyb37ywg7f-UxfwYfIgkm9jjm~yU1nBeOi6HXkS6dFu9C~oxVrCATkgyeFQF6wLHUDmcP3eCYhTUKPbVxv8w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"RGB colour composite of the lens systems DES J0408\u20135354. The three HST filters used to create the RGB image are F160W (red), F814W (green), and F475X (blue). The relative amplitudes between the three filters are adjusted in this figure for better visualization by achieving a higher contrast. We label different components of the lens system. G1 is the main deflector galaxy and G2 is its satellite galaxy. In addition to the lensed arcs from the extended quasar host galaxy, this lens system has extra source components S2 and S3. The source component S2 is doubly imaged and forms an extended arc inside the Einstein radius. S3 forms another fainter extended arc on the North-East outside the Einstein radius without a noticeable counter-image. Four nearby perturbers G3\u2013G6 along the line of sight are marked with the dashed, white circles.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530231/staa828fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530231\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=fTzthzMINELINS~GfV8MLF4KkuHukSMEKZ~jb3JDgOjS5XGW06sYtLlG31li7AOPN-9Ixyq81bPAfzxN39dNbCSnvhBD1nC4wbK-1ubq6~Pfu3ixZOhNnxwgilRv9MBZYVl1ZASq3tW4KjGTryW-1idOcL38SRHQNtLtQsApI8paPct72~iULBf-GzyivYBtFGFp0roKRR9EWwUyivf1WjunEdn6cHBIzRz02ET2TRctWHV7jfJXkL8qcqPXMMO7~jO2KfcTRRhcoUKVKJp4~6~D3eDCCcVruaZh0J3JDpyi-jyTOLTWz7Z7I4rnJbPq9siLoQYiyLsGI2zYoILSWA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530231&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">RGB colour composite of the lens systems DES J0408\u20135354. The three <em>HST</em> filters used to create the RGB image are F160W (red), F814W (green), and F475X (blue). The relative amplitudes between the three filters are adjusted in this figure for better visualization by achieving a higher contrast. We label different components of the lens system. G1 is the main deflector galaxy and G2 is its satellite galaxy. In addition to the lensed arcs from the extended quasar host galaxy, this lens system has extra source components S2 and S3. The source component S2 is doubly imaged and forms an extended arc inside the Einstein radius. S3 forms another fainter extended arc on the North-East outside the Einstein radius without a noticeable counter-image. Four nearby perturbers G3\u2013G6 along the line of sight are marked with the dashed, white circles.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The lens has multiple lensed arcs from additional source components, S2 and S3. The lensed arc S2 lies inside the Einstein radius and it has a noticeable counterimage on the North\u2013West of image B. Another faint lensed arc S3 lies on the East of image D. We could not identify the counterimage of S3 from visual inspection.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530233 id=\"203530233\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Spectroscopic observations of the lens components</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The central deflector G1 sits at the redshift <em>z</em><sub>d</sub> = 0.597 and the quasar sits at redshift <em>z</em><sub>QSO</sub> = 2.375 (Lin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>) measure redshifts for the nearby line-of-sight galaxies G3\u2013G6 from spectroscopic observations using the Magellan and the Gemini telescopes obtaining <em>z</em><sub>G3</sub> = 0.769, <em>z</em><sub>G4</sub> = 0.771, <em>z</em><sub>G5</sub> = 1.032, and <em>z</em><sub>G6</sub> = 0.594. The redshifts are precise up to the specified decimal point.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We measure the redshift of S2 <em>z</em><sub>S2</sub> = 2.228 from the integral-field spectroscopy observations of DES J0408\u20135354 with the Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE, on the ESO VLT UT4). The MUSE observations of the lens and its immediate neighbourhood, within approximately 45\u2009arcsec, were carried out in Period 102 during two nights on 2019 January 11 and 13 [run 0102.A-0600(E), PI Agnello]. The observations were executed in wide-field mode with adaptive-optics (AO) corrections, so that the multiple images and galaxies in this lens could be properly deblended. The AO wide field mode of MUSE results in a wavelength coverage from 4700 to 5803\u2009\u00c5; and 5966\u20139350\u2009\u00c5; at a spectral resolution of <em>R</em> \u223c 1700\u20133400. Each observation block contains four exposures, with the main target placed in four different quadrants of the instrument\u2019s field of view. An approximately 15\u2009arcsec \u00d7 15\u2009\u2009arcsec region centred on the lens was exposed for 4\u2009h, with a dither-and-rotation pattern that minimized artefacts due to the multiple instrument slicers and channels. We reduced the data cubes using the standard <span class=\"small-caps\">esorex</span> pipeline recipes and flux calibrated them using observations of standard stars obtained on the two nights. Offsets between 20 individual exposures were determined from cross-correlations of white light images created from individual data cubes. We cleaned strong sky-line residuals from the final combined data cube using <span class=\"small-caps\">zap</span> (Soto et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The setup results in a final data cube with a full field of view of 92\u2009arcsec \u00d7 95\u2009\u2009arcsec. For this work, we analysed a 8\u2009\u2009arcsec \u00d7 8\u2009\u2009arcsec \u2018mini-cube\u2019 centred around the lens. We use three stars in the field as reference point source function (PSF) cubes. We decompose the \u2018mini-cube\u2019 as a superposition of four Moffat profiles for the quasar images, and a convolved de Vaucouleurs profile for the deflector light distribution. By means of this procedure, all component spectra could be reliably separated and the quasar shot noise on the deflector spectra was minimized. We use Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> emission lines to measure S2\u2019s redshift and velocity dispersion. As S2 and the quasar are at different redshift, the quasar\u2019s Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> contamination does not overlap with S2\u2019s Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> lines. Also, given the large systematic uncertainty on the velocity dispersion described in the next paragraph, residual AGN contamination is not a dominant source of bias.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also measure the line-of-sight velocity dispersions of G3\u2013G6 and S2 from the MUSE spectra (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). We adopt an uncertainty of 20\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> on the measured velocity dispersion to account for the typical systematic uncertainty for kinematics extracted from MUSE spectra (Gu\u00e9rou et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The estimated PSF from the stars in the MUSE observation can be different than the PSF of the quasar due to different SED within a filter. However, the impact in the estimated velocity dispersion from this potential PSF mismatch is subdominant to this conservative estimate of the systematic uncertainty.</p>                        <a id=\"203530237\" scrollto-destination=\"203530237\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Redshift and stellar velocity dispersion for the line-of-sight galaxies G3\u2013G6 and S2. The relative offsets of the observed centroids for G3\u2013G6 are computed from the coordinate RA 04:08:21.71 and Dec \u221253:53:59.34. The tabulated uncertainties for the velocity dispersions are statistical uncertainties. However, we adopt a 20\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> uncertainty for each measurement to account for the typical systematic uncertainty for kinematics obtained from MUSE spectra (Gu\u00e9rou et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The redshifts are precise up to the specified decimal point.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Galaxy<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Galaxy<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394RA (arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394Dec (arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Redshift<span          .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>G3\u00a0</td><td>1.08\u00a0</td><td>\u22126.52\u00a0</td><td>0.769\u00a0</td><td>226\u00a0\u00b1\u00a07\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G4\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.40\u00a0</td><td>\u221213.58\u00a0</td><td>0.771\u00a0</td><td>153\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G5\u00a0</td><td>5.34\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.78\u00a0</td><td>1.032\u00a0</td><td>56\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G6\u00a0</td><td>10.90\u00a0</td><td>5.53\u00a0</td><td>0.594\u00a0</td><td>63\u00a0\u00b1\u00a07\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S2\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>2.228\u00a0</td><td>46\u00a0\u00b1\u00a09\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/203530237\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530238 id=\"203530238\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Time delays</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Courbin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) present the measured time delays between the images of DES J0408\u20135354. This system was monitored to obtain light-curves of the lensed images using the MPIA 2.2\u00a0m telescope at La Silla observatory between 2016 October 1 and 2017 April 8. The system was observed almost daily except for 14 consecutive nights between 2016 December 10 and 2016 December 24, and for one week in 2017 January due to bad weather and technical problems. Additional monitoring was carried out using the 1.2\u2009m the <em>Leonhard Euler</em> 1.2\u2009m Swiss Telescope (<em>Euler</em>) between 2016 July and 2017 April. The mean observation cadence with <em>Euler</em> is 5\u2009d. From these light-curves of the lensed images, the measured time delays are \u0394<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub> = \u2212112.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.1\u2009d, \u0394<em>t</em><sub>AD</sub> = \u2212155.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a012.8\u2009d, and \u0394<em>t</em><sub>BD</sub> = \u221242.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a017.6\u2009d (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> for the naming of the images). The time delays relative to image C could not be measured due the close proximity of a satellite galaxy as it is difficult to deblend the quasar flux from the satellite\u2019s in the ground-based monitoring data.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530240 id=\"203530240\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4>3.4 Velocity dispersion of the central deflector</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>) measure the velocity dispersion of G1. The velocity dispersion is measured with four different observing setups: two mask setups with the Magellan telescope, one with the Gemini telescope, and one with the MUSE spectra. The specifics and the measured values from these four setups are tabulated in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. We estimate the systematic uncertainty <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{\\sigma _{\\rm los}}^{\\rm sys}$|</span> in the measured velocity dispersion to add the reported statistical uncertainty <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{\\sigma _{\\rm los}}^{\\rm stat}$|\u2060</span>. We infer a systematic uncertainty of 17\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> from the variance in the estimated velocity dispersions when different settings \u2013 e.g. the stellar population library, the stellar templates, the wavelength region \u2013 are varied in the kinematic fitting. We form a covariance matrix for the velocity dispersion measurements with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${(\\sigma _{\\sigma _{\\rm los}}^{\\rm sys}})^2+({\\sigma _{\\sigma _{\\rm los}}^{\\rm stat}})^2$|</span> for the diagonal terms and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$({\\sigma _{\\sigma _{\\rm los}}^{\\rm sys}})^2$|</span> for off-diagonal terms, as the source of the systematic in the kinematic fitting is common between all the measurements.</p>                        <a id=\"203530242\" scrollto-destination=\"203530242\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measurements of velocity dispersion from three different setups from Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). The quoted uncertainties are only statistical, see Section\u00a0 \u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a> for the estimated systematic uncertainty.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Instrument and setup<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Aperture dimension (arcsec \u00d7 arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Aperture rotation (deg E of N)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Seeing (arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Moffat PSF exponent<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Velocity dispersion (km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Magellan mask A\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>99\u00a0</td><td>0.68\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.97\u00a0</td><td>230\u00a0\u00b1\u00a037\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Magellan mask B\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>99\u00a0</td><td>0.76\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.20\u00a0</td><td>236\u00a0\u00b1\u00a042\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Gemini mask A2\u00a0</td><td>0.75\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>0.52\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.06\u00a0</td><td>220\u00a0\u00b1\u00a021\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MUSE\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>0.61\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.55\u00a0</td><td>227\u00a0\u00b1\u00a09\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Instrument and setup<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Aperture dimension (arcsec \u00d7 arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Aperture rotation (deg E of N)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Seeing (arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Moffat PSF exponent<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Velocity dispersion (km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Magellan mask A\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>99\u00a0</td><td>0.68\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.97\u00a0</td><td>230\u00a0\u00b1\u00a037\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Magellan mask B\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>99\u00a0</td><td>0.76\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.20\u00a0</td><td>236\u00a0\u00b1\u00a042\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Gemini mask A2\u00a0</td><td>0.75\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>0.52\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.06\u00a0</td><td>220\u00a0\u00b1\u00a021\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MUSE\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>0.61\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.55\u00a0</td><td>227\u00a0\u00b1\u00a09\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/203530242\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measurements of velocity dispersion from three different setups from Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). The quoted uncertainties are only statistical, see Section\u00a0 \u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a> for the estimated systematic uncertainty.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Instrument and setup<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Aperture dimension (arcsec \u00d7 arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Aperture rotation (deg E of N)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Seeing (arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Moffat PSF exponent<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Velocity dispersion (km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display:
