A\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>99\u00a0</td><td>0.68\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.97\u00a0</td><td>230\u00a0\u00b1\u00a037\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Magellan mask B\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>99\u00a0</td><td>0.76\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.20\u00a0</td><td>236\u00a0\u00b1\u00a042\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Gemini mask A2\u00a0</td><td>0.75\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>0.52\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.06\u00a0</td><td>220\u00a0\u00b1\u00a021\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MUSE\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>0.61\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.55\u00a0</td><td>227\u00a0\u00b1\u00a09\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Instrument and setup<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Aperture dimension (arcsec \u00d7 arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Aperture rotation (deg E of N)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Seeing (arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Moffat PSF exponent<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Velocity dispersion (km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Magellan mask A\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>99\u00a0</td><td>0.68\u00a0</td><td>\u22122.97\u00a0</td><td>230\u00a0\u00b1\u00a037\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Magellan mask B\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>99\u00a0</td><td>0.76\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.20\u00a0</td><td>236\u00a0\u00b1\u00a042\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Gemini mask A2\u00a0</td><td>0.75\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>0.52\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.06\u00a0</td><td>220\u00a0\u00b1\u00a021\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MUSE\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>0.61\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.55\u00a0</td><td>227\u00a0\u00b1\u00a09\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/203530242\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530243 id=\"203530243\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-5>3.5 Estimate of the external convergence</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>) present the distribution of the external convergence \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> for DES J0408\u20135354. This analysis is based on the weighted galaxy number counts approach of Greene et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), which was further developed by Rusu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>) and Birrer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). In brief, weighted number counts are computed in 45\u2009arcsec- and 120\u2009arcsec-radii apertures centred on the lensing system, up to a depth of <em>I</em> = 22.5\u2009mag, using simple physical weights robust to measurement errors, such as the inverse of the distance to the lens and photometric/spectroscopic redshifts. Analogous number counts are computed in a large number of same-size apertures and depth in a cosmological survey, in this case DES, so as to measure the over/underdensity of the DES J0408\u20135354 line of sight relative to the median line of sight through the Universe, in terms of weighted number count ratios. In this case, the line of sight was found to be underdense, and a combination of weighted number count ratios was used as constraint to select statistically similar lines of sight from the Millennium Simulation (Springel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). Using the external convergence maps from Hilbert et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) corresponding to each Millennium Simulation line of sight, we construct a probability distribution function of \u03ba<sub>ext</sub>. This probability distribution function of \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> is provided in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.2.2</a> (specifically in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203530245 id=\"203530245\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 LENS MODEL INGREDIENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we describe the mass and light profiles used to construct the lens model in our analysis.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530247 id=\"203530247\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Central deflector\u2019s mass profiles</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To model the main deflector\u2019s mass distribution, we adopt two sets of profiles: (i) power-law, and (ii) composite mass profile.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203530249 id=\"203530249\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-1>4.1.1 Power-law mass profile</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We adopt the power-law elliptical mass distribution (Barkana <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>). This profile is described by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ42\" content-id=\"equ42\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\kappa _{\\rm PL}(\\theta _1, \\theta _2) = \\frac{3 - \\gamma }{2} \\left[ \\frac{\\theta _{\\rm E}}{\\sqrt{ q_{\\rm m} \\theta _1^2 + \\theta _2^2/q_{\\rm m} }} \\right]^{\\gamma - 1},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(42)</span></div>where \u03b3 is the power-law slope, \u03b8<sub>E</sub> is the Einstein radius, and <em>q</em><sub>m</sub> is the axial ratio. The coordinates (\u03b8<sub>1</sub>,\u2009\u03b8<sub>2</sub>) are in the frame that is aligned with the major and minor axes. This frame is rotated by a position angle \u03c6<sub>m</sub> from the frame of on-sky coordinates.</div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203530251 id=\"203530251\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-2>4.1.2 Composite mass profile</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the composite mass profile, we adopt separate mass profiles for the baryonic and the dark components of the mass distribution.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">For the dark component, we choose a Navarro\u2013Frenk\u2013White (NFW) profile with ellipticity defined in the potential. The spherical NFW profile in 3D is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ43\" content-id=\"equ43\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\rho _{\\rm NFW}(r) = \\frac{\\rho _s}{\\left(r/r_{\\rm s}\\right) \\left(1 + r/r_{\\rm s}\\right)^2},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(43)</span></div>where <em>r</em><sub>s</sub> is the scale radius, and \u03c1<sub>s</sub> is the normalization (Navarro, Frenk &amp; White <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>).</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">For the baryonic mass profile, we adopt the Chameleon convergence profile. The Chameleon profile approximates the S\u00e9rsic profile within a few per cent in the range 0.5\u20133<em>R</em><sub>eff</sub>, where <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> is the effective or half-light radius of the S\u00e9rsic profile. The Chameleon profile is the difference between two non-singular isothermal ellipsoids given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ44\" content-id=\"equ44\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\kappa _{\\rm Chm} (\\theta _1, \\theta _2) &amp;=&amp; \\frac{\\kappa _0}{1 + q_{\\rm m}} \\left[ \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{\\theta _1^2+\\theta _2^2/q_{\\rm m}^2 + 4w_{\\rm c}^2/(1+q_{\\rm m}^2)}} \\right. \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\left. - \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{\\theta _1^2+\\theta _2^2/q_{\\rm m}^2 + 4w_{\\rm t}^2/(1+q_{\\rm m}^2)}} \\right]\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(44)</span></div>(Dutton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). This profile is convenient to compute lensing properties using closed-form expressions.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">With each of these models, we include an external shear profile parametrized with the shear magnitude \u03b3<sub>ext</sub> and shear angle \u03c6<sub>ext</sub>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530256 id=\"203530256\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Central deflector\u2019s light profile</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the S\u00e9rsic profile and the Chameleon profile to model different light components of the lens system.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203530258 id=\"203530258\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2-1>4.2.1 S\u00e9rsic profile</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The S\u00e9rsic profile is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ45\" content-id=\"equ45\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nI_{\\rm{S{^{\\prime}{e}}rsic}} (\\theta _1, \\theta _2) = I_{\\rm eff} \\exp \\left[-b_n \\left\\lbrace \\left(\\frac{\\sqrt{\\theta _1^2 + \\theta _2^2/q_{\\rm L}^2}}{\\theta _{\\rm eff}} \\right)^{1/n_{\\rm s}} - 1 \\right\\rbrace \\right], \\nonumber \\\\\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(45)</span></div>where \u03b8<sub>eff</sub> is the effective radius, <em>I</em><sub>eff</sub> is the amplitude at \u03b8<sub>eff</sub>, and <em>n</em><sub>s</sub> is the S\u00e9rsic index (S\u00e9rsic <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1968</a>). The factor <em>b<sub>n</sub></em> normalizes the profile such that half of the total luminosity is contained within \u03b8<sub>eff</sub>.</div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203530260 id=\"203530260\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2-2>4.2.2 Chameleon profile</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the same Chameleon profile from equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ44\"></span><a href=\"#equ44\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">44</a>) to fit the central deflector\u2019s light profile by replacing the convergence amplitude \u03ba<sub>0</sub> with flux amplitude <em>I</em><sub>0</sub>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530262 id=\"203530262\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Quasar host galaxy\u2019s light profile</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We choose an elliptical S\u00e9rsic profile to model the smooth component of the quasar host galaxy\u2019s light distribution. Additionally, we use a basis set of shapelets to reconstruct the non-smooth features in the extended source light distribution (Refregier <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). The set of shapelets is characterized with a scale size \u03c2 and maximum polynomial order <em>n</em><sub>max</sub>. The order <em>n</em><sub>max</sub> determines the total number of shapelet components <em>n</em><sub>shapelet</sub> = (<em>n</em><sub>max</sub> + 1)(<em>n</em><sub>max</sub> + 2)/2.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We model the quasar images as point-sources on the image plane convolved with the reconstructed point spread function (PSF). We let the amplitudes of each quasar image free.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203530265 id=\"203530265\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 LENS MODEL SETUPS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we present the specific model choices for DES J0408\u20135354. Extending on the baseline models, we choose different options \u2013 that we consider equally viable \u2013 for some particular components of the model. A combination of these options then make up our model settings <em>S</em> for each mass profile family <em>M</em>. To be specific, the model settings <em>S</em> include the model components describing the source and the line-of-sight galaxies, and the model settings <em>M</em> include the mass and light profiles of the central deflector galaxy G1. We marginalize over these model settings <em>S</em> to account for any possible source of systematics that may be introduced from adopting only one specific choice. We first state the baseline models in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a>. Then, we elaborate on the different additional model choices in Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.2</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-9\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-9\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.9</a>, and we summarize the set of model settings <em>S</em> that we marginalize over in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-11\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.11</a>. A summary of the adopted models and the parameter priors are tabulated in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec14\">G</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530267 id=\"203530267\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Baseline models</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The specifics of the baseline models agreed by the participating independent modelling teams are:</p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Central deflector G1\u2019s mass profile: power-law profile and composite profile (elliptical NFW potential for the dark component, double Chameleon convergence for luminous component),</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Central deflectors G1\u2019s light profile:</p><ul class=\"alpha-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>For models with power-law mass profile:</em> double S\u00e9rsic profile in all three bands,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>For models with composite mass profile:</em> double Chameleon light profile in the F160W band linked with the double Chameleon mass profile, double S\u00e9rsic profiles in <em>UVIS</em> bands,</p></li></ul></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Satellite G2\u2019s mass profile: singular isothermal sphere (SIS) placed on G1\u2019s lens plane,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">External shear,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Explicit modelling of the line-of-sight galaxies G3\u2013G6, multilens-plane treatment for G3,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multisource-plane treatment for quasar host S1 and additional source component S2.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the next sections, we explain these model settings and further extend on some of these settings as we see fit.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530271 id=\"203530271\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Central deflector G1\u2019s mass and light profiles</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We choose two sets of mass profile for the central deflector G1: power-law mass profile and composite mass profile.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the corresponding light profile distribution of G1 with the power-law mass profile, we adopt a double S\u00e9rsic profile in the IR band, and a single S\u00e9rsic profile for each of the <em>UVIS</em> bands. Here, we deviated from the baseline model of double S\u00e9rsic profile for the <em>UVIS</em> bands, as we find a single S\u00e9rsic profile for each of the <em>UVIS</em> bands is sufficient and the posteriors of the lens model parameters are almost identical between the double S\u00e9rsic and single S\u00e9rsic profiles for the <em>UVIS</em> bands. Therefore, we adopt the single S\u00e9rsic profile for the <em>UVIS</em> bands to increase numerical efficiency by simplifying our model. However, we still use the double S\u00e9rsic profile in the IR band where the signal-to-noise ratio of the galaxy light is higher and thus more flexibility is needed to render it within the noise. The centroids are joint for all the S\u00e9rsic profiles between the bands. The axial ratio <em>q</em><sub>L</sub>, position angle \u03c6<sub>L</sub>, and the S\u00e9rsic index <em>n</em><sub>s</sub> are also joint between the <em>UVIS</em> bands. We let effective radius \u03b8<sub>eff</sub> and amplitude <em>I</em><sub>eff</sub> as free parameters independently for all bands to allow a colour gradient.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the composite mass profile, we model the dark matter distribution with a NFW profile with ellipticity parametrized in the potential. For the baryonic matter distribution, we adopt two concentric Chameleon profiles to model both the luminous mass distribution and the light distribution in the F160W band. We join the scaling and ellipticity parameters of each pairing of the Chameleon profiles between the baryonic mass distribution and the F160W light distribution. We do not fix the amplitude ratio between the two Chameleon profiles and this ratio is sampled as a non-linear parameter in our model. For each of the two <em>UVIS</em> bands, we adopt a single S\u00e9rsic profile. Similar to power-law profile, the S\u00e9rsic profile parameters except \u03b8<sub>eff</sub> and <em>I</em><sub>eff</sub> are joint between the <em>UVIS</em> bands and the centroids of the all the deflector light profiles are joint together. The amplitudes of the mass and light profiles are independent of each other, thus we allow the mass-to-light ratio (<em>M</em>/<em>L</em>) to be free. We adopt a Gaussian prior equivalent to 12.74\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.71\u2009arcsec for the NFW scale radius <em>r</em><sub>s</sub> based on the results of Gavazzi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) for the Sloan Lens ACS (SLACS) survey lenses (Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). G1\u2019s velocity dispersion and redshift are within the range of those from the SLACS lenses, thus SLACS is a representative sample of elliptical galaxies such as G1 (Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). Similar priors were adopted in previous H0LiCOW analyses of time-delay lenses (e.g. Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>).</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We find the half-light radius \u03b8<sub>eff</sub> of the S\u00e9rsic profiles to be degenerate with the S\u00e9rsic index <em>n</em><sub>s</sub> in our models and the models tend to optimize towards large values of \u03b8<sub>eff</sub> that is inconsistent with our observational prior. To prevent \u03b8<sub>eff</sub> from converging towards abnormally large values, we impose an empirical prior on \u03b8<sub>eff</sub>. We derive a scaling relation from the distribution of the central velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub>e/2</sub> measured within half of effective radius and <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> in physical unit for the lenses in the SLACS sample (Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). We account for intrinsic scatter in the derived scaling relation as we are ignoring the average surface brightness <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\overline{I}(R_{\\rm eff})$|</span> in the relation between the three quantities along the Fundamental Plane. Then, we derive a distribution for <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> for DES J0408\u20135354 for the given central velocity dispersion measurements from Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. In practice, we simultaneously sample <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$R^{\\rm J0408}_{\\rm eff}$|</span> and the parameters <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lbrace m, b, \\mathcal {S}\\rbrace$|</span> \u2013 for the scaling relation <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ46\" content-id=\"equ46\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\log _{\\rm 10} (\\sigma _{\\rm los}/{\\rm km\\ s^{-1}}) = m \\log _{\\rm 10} (R_{\\rm eff} / {\\rm kpc}) + b\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(46)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">with scatter <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {S}$|</span> \u2013 from a joint likelihood for the SLACS sample data and the measured velocity dispersions of DES J0408\u20135354. For each sampled <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$R_{\\rm eff}^{\\rm J0408}$|\u2060</span>, we transform the measured central velocity dispersions within each aperture into \u03c3<sub>e/2</sub> using the aperture correction formulae given by Jorgensen, Franx &amp; Kjaergaard (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>). We include the intrinsic scatter in the likelihood term for DES J0408\u20135354\u2019s velocity dispersions, thus the scatter in the scaling relation propagates into the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$R_{\\rm eff}^{\\rm J0408}$|</span> distribution. We estimate the scaling relation parameters as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$m=0.18^{+0.05}_{-0.04}$|\u2060</span>, <em>b</em> = 2.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {S}=1.53\\pm 0.05$|\u2060</span>. We convert the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$R_{\\rm eff}^{\\rm J0408}$|</span> distribution in physical unit into \u03b8<sub>eff</sub> distribution in angular unit using the angular diameter distance to DES J0408\u20135354 for our fiducial cosmology, however we add 10 per cent uncertainty to the distribution to remove any strong dependence on the choice of cosmology. We take a Gaussian prior with the same mean and standard deviation of the resultant \u03b8<sub>eff</sub> distribution from the SLACS lenses (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl10\" data-open=\"tbl10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">G2</a>). We adopt this prior only to prevent \u03b8<sub>eff</sub> from veering off to very large values. The adopted prior is broad enough not to bias the \u03b8<sub>eff</sub> posterior within the plausible range of values, including for the double S\u00e9rsic profile.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530277 id=\"203530277\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>5.3 Satellite G2\u2019s mass and light profile</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the power-law or composite mass profile for the central deflector, we add a singular isothermal sphere (SIS) profile for G2\u2019s mass distribution and a circular S\u00e9rsic profile for its light distribution. The S\u00e9rsic profile parameters except \u03b8<sub>eff</sub> are joint between all bands. We join the centroid between the SIS and S\u00e9rsic profiles. Although a deviation from the isothermal profile in G2\u2019s mass can potentially change the deflection potential at image C, such a change will be negligible in our inference of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> as time-delays with respect to image C are not used in our inference. The SIS profile is sufficient to capture the astrometric position of the image C in our modelling.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530279 id=\"203530279\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-4>5.4 Nearby line-of-sight galaxies</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We explicitly model the mass distributions of line-of-sight galaxies G3\u20136 to fully capture their higher than second-order lensing effects that cannot be accounted for by the external convergence and the external shear profiles. First in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.4.1</a>, we describe our selection criterion for the line-of-sight galaxies to explicitly include in our lens model. Then in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.4.2</a>, we explain the mutlilens-plane treatment of the line-of-sight galaxies. Lastly in Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.4.3</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-4-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.4.4</a>, we describe the mass profiles we adopt to model these line-of-sight galaxies.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203530281 id=\"203530281\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-4-1>5.4.1 Selection criterion of the line-of-sight galaxies for explicit modelling</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">To select the line-of-sight galaxies for explicit modelling, we first estimate the contribution in time-delays between the images from higher than second-order derivatives of the deflection potential of these galaxies. To quantify this effect, we set an SIS profile for each perturber with its Einstein radius corresponding to the estimated central velocity dispersion. We infer the velocity dispersion for all the line-of-sight galaxies from their stellar masses using two scaling relations \u2013 one from Auger et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and the other from Zahid et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib131\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib131\" data-open=\"bib131\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). To be conservative, we choose the upper limit of the 1\u03c3 confidence interval of the estimated stellar mass and choose the larger value of the velocity dispersions estimated from the two scaling relations (Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). We select the line-of-sight galaxies that may cause more than 1 per cent shift in the measured Hubble constant if higher than second-order derivatives of their deflection potential are ignored. The shift in the Hubble constant can be related to the relative astrometric shift \u03b4\u03b8<sub>AB</sub> between image A and B as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ47\" content-id=\"equ47\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\frac{\\delta {H_0}}{H_0} \\lesssim \\frac{D_{\\Delta t}}{c \\Delta t_{\\rm AB}} (\\theta _{\\rm A} - \\theta _{\\rm B}) \\cdot \\delta {\\theta _{\\rm AB}}\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(47)</span></div>(Birrer &amp; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). We take the relative astrometric shift <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\delta \\theta _{\\rm AB} = \\alpha _{\\rm A}^{(3)} - \\alpha _{\\rm B}^{(3)}$|\u2060</span>, where the term on the right-hand side is the relative deflection angle for third and higher order lensing effects from the SIS profile corresponding to each line-of-sight galaxy. Thus, we set the selection criterion <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ48\" content-id=\"equ48\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\frac{D_{\\Delta t}^{\\rm fiducial}}{c \\Delta t_{\\rm AB}} (\\theta _{\\rm A} - \\theta _{\\rm B}) \\cdot \\left(\\alpha _{\\rm A}^{(3)} - \\alpha _{\\rm B}^{(3)} \\right) \\ge 0.01.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(48)</span></div>This criterion selects G3\u2013G6 for explicit modelling. Note that the perturber selection criterion based on the \u2018flexion shift\u2019 \u0394<sub>3</sub><em>x</em> &gt; 10<sup>\u22124</sup> also selects G3\u2013G6 for explicit modelling (McCully et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>, Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>).</div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203530283 id=\"203530283\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-4-2>5.4.2 Multilens-plane modelling of the line-of-sight galaxies</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We model this lens system with a multilens-plane treatment by setting G3\u2019s lens plane at its own redshift <em>z</em><sub>G3</sub> = 0.769, as G3 is close enough to G0 to cause more than 1 per cent deviation in the computed time-delays if we place it on G0\u2019s lens plane. We place G4\u2013G6 on G0\u2019s lens plane as we assume that the deviation in computed time-delays due to this assumption is negligible given the combinations of their stellar masses and distances from G0.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Additionally, we model the mass profile of S2 at its redshift <em>z</em><sub>S2</sub> = 2.228. Therefore, we have three lens-planes in our model. We can express the effective Fermat potential for the triple-lens-plane case from equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ9\"></span><a href=\"#equ9\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">9</a>) as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ49\" content-id=\"equ49\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\phi ^{\\rm eff} (\\theta) &amp;=&amp; \\left[ \\frac{D_{\\rm G3} D_{\\rm G1,S1}}{D_{\\rm S1}D_{\\rm G1,G3} } \\frac{(\\theta _{\\rm G1} - \\theta _{\\rm G3})^2}{2} - \\psi _{\\rm G1}(\\theta _{\\rm G1}) \\right] \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;+\\, \\frac{1+z_{\\rm G3}}{1+z_{\\rm G1}}\\left[ \\frac{D_{\\rm G3} D_{\\rm S2} D_{\\rm G1,S1}}{D_{\\rm G1} D_{\\rm S1} D_{\\rm G3, S2}} \\frac{(\\theta _{\\rm G3} - \\theta _{\\rm S2})^2}{2} \\right. \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;\\left. -\\, \\frac{D_{\\rm G3} D_{\\rm G1,S1}}{D_{\\rm G1} D_{\\rm G3,S1} } \\psi _{\\rm G3}(\\theta _{\\rm G3}) \\right] \\nonumber\\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;+\\, \\frac{1+z_{\\rm S2}}{1+z_{\\rm G1}} \\frac{D_{\\rm S2} D_{\\rm G1,S1}}{D_{\\rm G1} D_{\\rm S2,S1} } \\left[ \\frac{(\\theta _{\\rm S2} - \\beta)^2}{2} - \\psi _{\\rm S2}(\\theta _{\\rm S2}) \\right].\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(49)</span></div>Here, \u03b8<sub>G</sub> is the quasar\u2019s image position on G\u2019s plane with G \u2208 {G1, G3, S2}, \u03c8<sub>G</sub> is the deflection potential of G, and \u03b2 is the quasar\u2019s position on the source-plane. We fix the distance ratios in the above equation in our modelling. We adopt the \u039bCDM cosmology with the cosmological density parameters \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.7 to obtain these distance ratios. The relevant distance ratios change by less than 1 per cent within 0.25 \u2272 \u03a9<sub>m</sub> \u2272 0.35 and \u22121.1 \u2272 <em>w</em> \u2272 \u22120.9 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). Therefore, adopting this fiducial cosmology is only a weak assumption in our analysis. Fixing these distance ratios does not linearly affect our inference of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, as the ratios do not depend on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>. However, there can potentially be a small non-linear shift in the inferred <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> from our analysis had we adopted a different set of values for \u03a9<sub>m</sub> and \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>. The non-linear effect on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> from fixing density parameters in the multilens-plane treatment was demonstrated to be less than 1 per cent for two previously analysed lens systems, HE 0435\u20131223 and WFI 2033\u20134723 (Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). In Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec8\">A</a>, we show that <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> shifts by less than 1 per cent if we change the matter density parameter to \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.1 and to \u03a9 = 0.45 within the \u039bCDM cosmology. This range in \u03a9<sub>m</sub> covers nearly the full range of our prior \u03a9<sub>m</sub> \u2208 [0.05, 0.5] for inferring <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> for the \u039bCDM cosmology. As a shift less than 1 per cent in <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> is much smaller than the typical precision on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> (\u223c5\u20138 per cent) allowed by the current data quality, we consider that the impact of fixing the distance ratios using a fiducial \u039bCDM cosmology has negligible impact in our analysis. However, we find that our inference of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> is sensitive to the dark energy equation of state parameter <em>w</em> in the <em>w</em>CDM cosmology. As we adopt a double source plane model \u2013 as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-6\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.6</a> \u2013 the distance ratios or the \u03b6 terms in equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ8\"></span><a href=\"#equ8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">8</a>) become sensitive to <em>w</em> (Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Collett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Collett &amp; Auger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Therefore, the distance posteriors from this analysis should not be used to infer <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> in extended cosmologies other than the \u039bCDM model. We postpone the derivation of a distance posterior in more general cosmologies to future work.</div>                        <a id=\"203530286\" scrollto-destination=\"203530286\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=uC7pgy-qLVPZBQjgs1wdTmz4b1g5eNMRHfGRNdtOntnQGCggbNyR4dhY2ZIbQua~8rF5T1lIIrAGLoRWcjmHS1aWaY4VT-JywRtZxureNCfeZ1ziiA0yoSfQh4g7dezCTv3j3PeGSuPehAPAy2698MvNrODMYcTD~bZeMmbepxkDsMkg6YUnDe8l5WWWZAEUDrLhuLXrKt~ECJBdyXc0Ve-pj235FH6FWYzy5z-Aly8Kz5USVKUKCdpE-ZgxBqAVBPMPQsWmcCNyCBAGo8EhdgxDuP1~2s5VYgperkIr0DxTxJ5kkoPerI0facGWy9-izbUW6QG6OeXgbjk9Z3YDEA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Impact of varying \u03a9m in the \u039bCDM cosmology on the angular diameter distance ratios between the lens and source planes. All the distance ratios except for the black line changes less than 1 per cent for a wide range of \u03a9m. The black line corresponds to the distance ratio involving S2\u2019s lens plane. As the S2\u2019s Einstein radius is small (\u223c0.002\u2009arcsec), the change in the black line only has a small effect on the effective Fermat potential [cf. equation\u00a0(49)]. Therefore, fixing the distance ratios for the fiducial cosmology with \u03a9m = 0.3 is not a strong assumption in our analysis. See Appendix\u00a0A for tests validating this point.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530286/staa828fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530286\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=zIJYVa43UXbmGrgrU1nZZB3kRk4mNDTJzCqQNf1Nh592jimg6RiwuOrrckCuzYuIZaGQ6swEi-etq5TdQuYKgHLgF63OK8mG1A6AbdA67bqaPiSDl1U6UR6TawV9lWP2Ll62klvg~mAtTvsOBD6NAcCzS9pj9qJdFkhoZ4obuda7S7PBkdzliWeMFG2mZSEJkUW2bKShdL9lOVjqSwMfaTw9ReCQ~DvR0LWsrNoJoaaTeDs2PuzdxUi19wEdZspwr6S-1PneUe94L5EzVJuP-NP2gL28zQmcOV8ZPlcmqKMVfvsqrSj~J1~qQrt42svIhysR2HAI-tju6OJW2ftB7g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530286&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Impact of varying \u03a9<sub>m</sub> in the \u039bCDM cosmology on the angular diameter distance ratios between the lens and source planes. All the distance ratios except for the black line changes less than 1 per cent for a wide range of \u03a9<sub>m</sub>. The black line corresponds to the distance ratio involving S2\u2019s lens plane. As the S2\u2019s Einstein radius is small (\u223c0.002\u2009arcsec), the change in the black line only has a small effect on the effective Fermat potential [cf. equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ49\"></span><a href=\"#equ49\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">49</a>)]. Therefore, fixing the distance ratios for the fiducial cosmology with \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.3 is not a strong assumption in our analysis. See Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec8\">A</a> for tests validating this point.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=uC7pgy-qLVPZBQjgs1wdTmz4b1g5eNMRHfGRNdtOntnQGCggbNyR4dhY2ZIbQua~8rF5T1lIIrAGLoRWcjmHS1aWaY4VT-JywRtZxureNCfeZ1ziiA0yoSfQh4g7dezCTv3j3PeGSuPehAPAy2698MvNrODMYcTD~bZeMmbepxkDsMkg6YUnDe8l5WWWZAEUDrLhuLXrKt~ECJBdyXc0Ve-pj235FH6FWYzy5z-Aly8Kz5USVKUKCdpE-ZgxBqAVBPMPQsWmcCNyCBAGo8EhdgxDuP1~2s5VYgperkIr0DxTxJ5kkoPerI0facGWy9-izbUW6QG6OeXgbjk9Z3YDEA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Impact of varying \u03a9m in the \u039bCDM cosmology on the angular diameter distance ratios between the lens and source planes. All the distance ratios except for the black line changes less than 1 per cent for a wide range of \u03a9m. The black line corresponds to the distance ratio involving S2\u2019s lens plane. As the S2\u2019s Einstein radius is small (\u223c0.002\u2009arcsec), the change in the black line only has a small effect on the effective Fermat potential [cf. equation\u00a0(49)]. Therefore, fixing the distance ratios for the fiducial cosmology with \u03a9m = 0.3 is not a strong assumption in our analysis. See Appendix\u00a0A for tests validating this point.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530286/staa828fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530286\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=zIJYVa43UXbmGrgrU1nZZB3kRk4mNDTJzCqQNf1Nh592jimg6RiwuOrrckCuzYuIZaGQ6swEi-etq5TdQuYKgHLgF63OK8mG1A6AbdA67bqaPiSDl1U6UR6TawV9lWP2Ll62klvg~mAtTvsOBD6NAcCzS9pj9qJdFkhoZ4obuda7S7PBkdzliWeMFG2mZSEJkUW2bKShdL9lOVjqSwMfaTw9ReCQ~DvR0LWsrNoJoaaTeDs2PuzdxUi19wEdZspwr6S-1PneUe94L5EzVJuP-NP2gL28zQmcOV8ZPlcmqKMVfvsqrSj~J1~qQrt42svIhysR2HAI-tju6OJW2ftB7g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530286&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Impact of varying \u03a9<sub>m</sub> in the \u039bCDM cosmology on the angular diameter distance ratios between the lens and source planes. All the distance ratios except for the black line changes less than 1 per cent for a wide range of \u03a9<sub>m</sub>. The black line corresponds to the distance ratio involving S2\u2019s lens plane. As the S2\u2019s Einstein radius is small (\u223c0.002\u2009arcsec), the change in the black line only has a small effect on the effective Fermat potential [cf. equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ49\"></span><a href=\"#equ49\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">49</a>)]. Therefore, fixing the distance ratios for the fiducial cosmology with \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.3 is not a strong assumption in our analysis. See Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec8\">A</a> for tests validating this point.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We model G3 and S2 with SIS profiles. We place G3 at it\u2019s \u2018true\u2019 position on its own lens plane by tracing back from its observed position accounting for the foreground deflectors. As we also model the flux distribution from S2, we join the centroid of S2\u2019s mass profile with its light centroid on its plane.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For G4\u2013G6, we fix their centroids at their observed position on the lens plane of G1. For the mass profiles of G4\u2013G6, we adopt two choices: the SIS profile and the spherical NFW profile. We choose the additional NFW model for G4\u2013G6 as the NFW scale radius estimated from each of their stellar masses is smaller than the distance between the galaxy and G0 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-4-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.4.4</a>). Thus, their mass profile slopes can potentially be different from the isothermal profile at the centre of G0. In Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.4.3</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-4-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.4.4</a>, we describe the priors for the SIS and NFW profile parameters, respectively, of the line-of-sight galaxies.</p>                        <a id=\"203530289\" scrollto-destination=\"203530289\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=hQICLL7WuAlyEDbxASRtFKMXwd4viqqLlvwoh3hnPln4UireNFG5WTruvX1lg7CAQ-NLkO61a89kuKZaz30Dg8yfZvlEMPkNmNaTPRCoDC0BOilFJ-KpBylviVmRHn01xy0YmDrljiGmcEzOqsuZ7dz9HDhsHlhMWlR--9Ef7lOkncg~fWhThzIQcYRym5pm5v8byyZCaa-QjTkc3Mgze8Nx390YQVwdg4tIWBmV5T0G-6DzfbRKji-YCa3GCwubrJuCu8y~FVFEwsB15cd3ik9fagXe04lKX~54dohNQyo0sY-pMp1gLEE4eBhc5TB-lvL~m~oDeBT7EtPiITMKDw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Observed and estimated properties of the line-of-sight galaxies G3\u2013G6. Top left: velocity dispersions derived from the MUSE integral field spectra. Top right: SIS Einstein radius distributions obtained from the observed velocity dispersions. Middle left: estimated stellar masses from Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (2020). Middle right: halo mass M200 inferred from the estimated stellar mass using the stellar mass\u2013halo mass relation from Behroozi et\u00a0al. (2019). Bottom left: halo concentration parameter c200 obtained using a halo mass\u2013concentration relation for our fiducial cosmology (Diemer &amp; Joyce 2019). Bottom right: scale radius of the NFW profile in angular unit for our fiducial cosmology from the M200 and c200 priors. The intrinsic scatter and uncertainties of the adopted scaling relations are accounted for at each conversion step. We use the SIS Einstein radius distributions as priors for the SIS model and the M200 and c200 distributions as priors for the NFW model for G4\u2013G6.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530289/staa828fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530289\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=YIkVv-YvrsseqcQHFhGycbEeeAkqlz0i25q0~~KvoBsxVkO96Twmx6-u2oFh2nL0jB09-JwsD0V-AEPnlf~j7nhhNkWhDdvORvhaHp9sn45Kregpmagi3lodruVWNVmGN-uat9FPBMk~-NCse3mgYfAP3Hmg-hWccxUZfdTpCc6L1JPYi0~ilnEHd7VIkCpjMs9xS-Vd-Cu3rYiQhcqT2ol9ZPYsyY9ZSE0cJLGyXM~q1NhIhYgydezhu0eE7MANAiurJMyqLUyS9X9nsx7GfJdri1F55ZBQ2vdH1ghLSXHvG~10UVx6nTlpIoDjwh4c~QTzDgdYzmt1wqGamrSPNQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530289&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observed and estimated properties of the line-of-sight galaxies G3\u2013G6. Top left: velocity dispersions derived from the MUSE integral field spectra. Top right: SIS Einstein radius distributions obtained from the observed velocity dispersions. Middle left: estimated stellar masses from Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). Middle right: halo mass <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> inferred from the estimated stellar mass using the stellar mass\u2013halo mass relation from Behroozi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Bottom left: halo concentration parameter <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> obtained using a halo mass\u2013concentration relation for our fiducial cosmology (Diemer &amp; Joyce <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). The intrinsic scatter and uncertainties of the adopted scaling relations are accounted for at each conversion step. We use the SIS Einstein radius distributions as priors for the SIS model and the <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> and <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> distributions as priors for the NFW model for G4\u2013G6.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=hQICLL7WuAlyEDbxASRtFKMXwd4viqqLlvwoh3hnPln4UireNFG5WTruvX1lg7CAQ-NLkO61a89kuKZaz30Dg8yfZvlEMPkNmNaTPRCoDC0BOilFJ-KpBylviVmRHn01xy0YmDrljiGmcEzOqsuZ7dz9HDhsHlhMWlR--9Ef7lOkncg~fWhThzIQcYRym5pm5v8byyZCaa-QjTkc3Mgze8Nx390YQVwdg4tIWBmV5T0G-6DzfbRKji-YCa3GCwubrJuCu8y~FVFEwsB15cd3ik9fagXe04lKX~54dohNQyo0sY-pMp1gLEE4eBhc5TB-lvL~m~oDeBT7EtPiITMKDw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Observed and estimated properties of the line-of-sight galaxies G3\u2013G6. Top left: velocity dispersions derived from the MUSE integral field spectra. Top right: SIS Einstein radius distributions obtained from the observed velocity dispersions. Middle left: estimated stellar masses from Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (2020). Middle right: halo mass M200 inferred from the estimated stellar mass using the stellar mass\u2013halo mass relation from Behroozi et\u00a0al. (2019). Bottom left: halo concentration parameter c200 obtained using a halo mass\u2013concentration relation for our fiducial cosmology (Diemer &amp; Joyce 2019). Bottom right: scale radius of the NFW profile in angular unit for our fiducial cosmology from the M200 and c200 priors. The intrinsic scatter and uncertainties of the adopted scaling relations are accounted for at each conversion step. We use the SIS Einstein radius distributions as priors for the SIS model and the M200 and c200 distributions as priors for the NFW model for G4\u2013G6.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530289/staa828fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530289\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=YIkVv-YvrsseqcQHFhGycbEeeAkqlz0i25q0~~KvoBsxVkO96Twmx6-u2oFh2nL0jB09-JwsD0V-AEPnlf~j7nhhNkWhDdvORvhaHp9sn45Kregpmagi3lodruVWNVmGN-uat9FPBMk~-NCse3mgYfAP3Hmg-hWccxUZfdTpCc6L1JPYi0~ilnEHd7VIkCpjMs9xS-Vd-Cu3rYiQhcqT2ol9ZPYsyY9ZSE0cJLGyXM~q1NhIhYgydezhu0eE7MANAiurJMyqLUyS9X9nsx7GfJdri1F55ZBQ2vdH1ghLSXHvG~10UVx6nTlpIoDjwh4c~QTzDgdYzmt1wqGamrSPNQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530289&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observed and estimated properties of the line-of-sight galaxies G3\u2013G6. Top left: velocity dispersions derived from the MUSE integral field spectra. Top right: SIS Einstein radius distributions obtained from the observed velocity dispersions. Middle left: estimated stellar masses from Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). Middle right: halo mass <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> inferred from the estimated stellar mass using the stellar mass\u2013halo mass relation from Behroozi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Bottom left: halo concentration parameter <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> obtained using a halo mass\u2013concentration relation for our fiducial cosmology (Diemer &amp; Joyce <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Bottom right: scale radius of the NFW profile in angular unit for our fiducial cosmology from the <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> and <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> priors. The intrinsic scatter and uncertainties of the adopted scaling relations are accounted for at each conversion step. We use the SIS Einstein radius distributions as priors for the SIS model and the <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> and <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> distributions as priors for the NFW model for G4\u2013G6.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203530290 id=\"203530290\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-4-3>5.4.3 SIS profile for the line-of-sight galaxies</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We estimate the SIS Einstein radius distribution from each galaxy\u2019s SIS velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub>SIS</sub> using the relation <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ50\" content-id=\"equ50\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\theta _{\\rm E, SIS} = 4 \\pi \\left(\\frac{\\sigma _{\\rm SIS}}{c} \\right)^2 \\frac{D_{{\\rm G},{\\rm S1}}}{D_{\\rm S1}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(50)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">where \u03b8<sub>E, SIS</sub> is the Einstein radius for an SIS profile, and <em>D</em><sub>G, S1</sub> is the angular diameter distance between a line-of-sight galaxy G \u2208 {G3, G4, G5, G6, S2} and S1. We calculate the distance ratio in the above equation using our fiducial cosmology. We do not need to add uncertainty to the fiducial cosmology used here as the distance ratios are independent of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u2009and a large shift (e.g. by 0.1) in \u03a9<sub>m</sub> changes them by negligible amount relative to the 20\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> uncertainty we adopted for the velocity dispersions.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">G4 and G6\u2019s observed morphologies indicate that they are elliptical galaxies. Therefore, we take their observed stellar velocity dispersions \u03c3<sub>ap</sub> as \u03c3<sub>SIS</sub> in equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ50\"></span><a href=\"#equ50\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">50</a>) to obtain these galaxies\u2019 Einstein radius prior distributions (Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). In contrast, G5\u2019s spectra contains bright [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission lines indicative of a star-forming galaxy. We also take S2 as a star-forming galaxy due to its blue colour in the <em>HST</em> three-band imaging (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). Therefore, we estimate the rotational velocities <em>v</em><sub>c</sub> of G5 and S2 from their observed \u2018aperture-averaged\u2019 velocity dispersions \u03c3<sub>ap</sub> using the scaling relation between <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v_{\\rm c}^2/\\sigma _{\\rm ap}^2$|</span> and S\u00e9rsic index <em>n</em><sub>s</sub> from Agnello, Evans &amp; Romanowsky (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). We obtain the S\u00e9rsic index of G5 <em>n</em><sub>s</sub> = 4 by fitting a S\u00e9rsic profile to its light distribution in the F814W band. From a preliminary lens model, we adopt S2\u2019s S\u00e9rsic index as <em>n</em><sub>s</sub> = 1.5. For these S\u00e9rsic indices, the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v_{\\rm c}^2/\\sigma _{\\rm ap}^2$|</span> ratios are approximately 2.5 and 2.2, respectively, for G5 and S2. We adopt a Gaussian uncertainty with standard deviation 0.2 for these ratios to account for the scatter observed in the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v_{\\rm c}^2/\\sigma _{\\rm ap}^2$|</span>\u2013<em>n</em><sub>s</sub> distribution (cf. fig. 6 of Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Then, to convert the estimated rotational velocity <em>v</em><sub>c</sub> into the corresponding SIS velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub>SIS</sub>, we use the relation <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ51\" content-id=\"equ51\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\sigma _{\\rm SIS}^2 = \\frac{G M(R)}{2 R} = \\frac{v_{\\rm c}(R)^2}{2},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(51)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">where <em>M</em>(<em>R</em>) is the enclosed 3D mass within a radius <em>R</em>. The estimated SIS velocity dispersions are <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{\\rm SIS}^{\\rm G5} = 62 \\pm 22$|</span>\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{\\rm SIS}^{\\rm S2} = 48 \\pm 11$|</span>\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. We parametrize the SIS Einstein radius distributions derived from the velocity dispersions as Gaussian priors for the SIS mass profiles of G3\u2013G6 and S2.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=203530295 id=\"203530295\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-4-4>5.4.4 NFW profile for the line-of-sight galaxies</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We parametrize the NFW profiles for G4\u2013G6 with the halo mass <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> and concentration <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>. We obtain the priors on the NFW profile parameters from the estimated stellar masses of G4\u2013G6 (Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). We derive the halo mass distribution from the stellar mass distribution using the stellar mass\u2013halo mass relation from Behroozi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) for the respective redshift of the line-of-sight galaxy. We weight the halo-mass distribution with the halo mass function for our fiducial cosmology and the relevant redshift from Tinker et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). We obtain the concentration distribution from the halo mass distribution for our fiducial cosmology using the <em>M</em>\u2013<em>c</em> relation from Diemer &amp; Joyce (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). We propagate the uncertainties and scatters in these relations when deriving one quantity from another. The <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> priors and <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> priors for G4\u2013G6 are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. We can also derive the NFW scale radius <em>r</em><sub>s</sub> = <em>R</em><sub>200</sub>/<em>c</em><sub>200</sub> in physical unit, and convert it to the scale radius \u03b8<sub>s</sub> in angular unit given our fiducial cosmology (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>). We do not use these scale radii as prior, we only show the distributions to motivate our choice of the NFW profile for the galaxies G4\u2013G6.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530297 id=\"203530297\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-5>5.5 Galaxy group containing G1</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We do not explicitly model the galaxy group that contains the central deflector G1 [Group 5 in Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>)]. The estimated flexion shift <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log _{10} \\Delta x_3 = -3.86^{+0.97}_{-0.72}$|</span> for this group is marginally above the conservative threshold \u0394<em>x</em><sub>3</sub> &gt; 10<sup>\u22124</sup> (Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). However, the larger end of the flexion shift is provided by the case where the group is centred near to the central deflector. In that case, the group\u2019s halo coincides with the deflector\u2019s halo, which is already accounted for in our lens models. However, if the group\u2019s centroid is offset from the central deflector, then the flexion shift becomes smaller. Then, the group\u2019s contribution can be considered only in the approximated convergence, as the external shear profile already captures the shear contribution from the group. In Appendix\u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec10\">C</a>, we show that the impact of the group\u2019s convergence, if explicitly accounted for, only shifts <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> by 0.4 per cent. This small shift justifies our choice of not including the group in our lens model.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530299 id=\"203530299\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-6>5.6 Source component light profiles</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We use an elliptical S\u00e9rsic light profile and a set of shapelets to reconstruct the quasar host S1\u2019s light profile. We join all the S\u00e9rsic profile parameters across the three bands. We join the shapelet scale size \u03c2 across the <em>UVIS</em> bands and leave \u03c2 in the IR band as a free parameter.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To reconstruct S2\u2019s light profile, we take a basis set of one elliptical S\u00e9rsic profile and multiple shapelets. We join the S\u00e9rsic profile parameters and the shapelet scale size \u03c2 across bands. For S3\u2019s light profile, we adopt only an elliptical S\u00e9rsic profile. All the profile parameters for this profile except the amplitude <em>I</em><sub>eff</sub> are joint across the three bands.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each model setup, we choose three fixed values of <em>n</em><sub>max</sub>: S1\u2019s <em>n</em><sub>max</sub> in the IR band, S1\u2019s <em>n</em><sub>max</sub> in the <em>UVIS</em> band, and S2\u2019s <em>n</em><sub>max</sub> common across the three bands. We adopt three different sets of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lbrace n^{\\rm S1,\\ IR}_{\\rm max}, n^{\\rm S1,\\ UVIS}_{\\rm max}, n^{\\rm S2}_{\\rm max}\\rbrace$|\u2060</span>: {6, 3, 2},\u2009{7, 4, 2},\u2009{8, 5, 3}. A minimum number of shapelets is necessary to sufficiently capture the complex structures in the lensed arcs, however we would start to fit the noise in the data by adopting too many more shapelets than necessary. We choose these values for <em>n</em><sub>max</sub> so that we hit a balance between these two scenarios. As we show in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, the model evidence peaks around these values leading to our choice of these <em>n</em><sub>max</sub> values. We check if the inferred <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> value from our analysis depends on the particular range of <em>n</em><sub>max</sub> values adopted above. We find that a set of larger <em>n</em><sub>max</sub> values {12, 9, 9, 4} and a set of smaller <em>n</em><sub>max</sub> values {2, 2, 2, 2} both infer <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> within the range spanned by the models with our adopted <em>n</em><sub>max</sub> values. Thus, our inference of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> is robust against the particular range of adopted <em>n</em><sub>max</sub> values.</p>                        <a id=\"203530303\" scrollto-destination=\"203530303\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Evidence for different lens model setups. The evidence ratio <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}$|</span> is calculated only within the particular mass profile family \u2013 power law or composite. The model setups are ordered from higher to lower evidence within each mass profile family. The relative weights for each model are obtained from the evidence ratios adjusted for sparse sampling from the model space as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.1</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Mass profile<span aria-hidden=\"true\" \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/203530303\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Evidence for different lens model setups. The evidence ratio <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\log \\mathcal {Z}$|</span> is calculated only within the particular mass profile family \u2013 power law or composite. The model setups are ordered from higher to lower evidence within each mass profile family. The relative weights for each model are obtained from the evidence ratios adjusted for sparse sampling from the model space as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" 2}\u00a0</td><td>2.375\u00a0</td><td>SIS\u00a0</td><td>\u221225155\u00a0</td><td>100\u00a0</td><td>0.93\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Composite\u00a0</td><td>{6, 3, 2}\u00a0</td><td>2.375\u00a0</td><td>NFW\u00a0</td><td>\u221225252\u00a0</td><td>197\u00a0</td><td>0.87\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Composite\u00a0</td><td>{6, 3, 2}\u00a0</td><td>2.375\u00a0</td><td>SIS\u00a0</td><td>\u221225292\u00a0</td><td>237\u00a0</td><td>0.85\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Composite\u00a0</td><td>{7, 4, 2}\u00a0</td><td>2.375\u00a0</td><td>NFW\u00a0</td><td>\u221225482\u00a0</td><td>427\u00a0</td><td>0.72\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Composite\u00a0</td><td>{6, 3, 2}\u00a0</td><td>2.228\u00a0</td><td>NFW\u00a0</td><td>\u221225985\u00a0</td><td>930\u00a0</td><td>0.44\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Composite\u00a0</td><td>{8, 5, 3}\u00a0</td><td>2.375\u00a0</td><td>NFW\u00a0</td><td>\u221226541\u00a0</td><td>1486\u00a0</td><td>0.22\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Composite\u00a0</td><td>{8, 5, 3}\u00a0</td><td>2.228\u00a0</td><td>NFW\u00a0</td><td>\u221227073\u00a0</td><td>2018\u00a0</td><td>0.09\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Composite\u00a0</td><td>{7, 4, 2}\u00a0</td><td>2.228\u00a0</td><td>NFW\u00a0</td><td>\u221228979\u00a0</td><td>3924\u00a0</td><td>0.00\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/203530303\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We place the additional source component S2 at the source plane with redshift <em>z</em><sub>S2</sub> = 2.228. As we do not know the redshift of S3, we adopt two choices for its redshift: <em>z</em><sub>QSO</sub> and <em>z</em><sub>S2</sub>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the model where we place S3 on S2\u2019s plane, we ignore the mass distribution of S3. From our lens model, we find that S3 is approximately twice further away from the quasar position on S2\u2019s plane than S2. We run a lens model ignoring S2\u2019s mass profile as well and find that the time-delay distance shifts by 0.94 per cent. The total flux from the reconstructed source light distribution of S2 and S3 are comparable after accounting for lensing magnification. If S2 and S3 are at a similar redshift, then they have similar total mass. If we assume SIS profile for S2 and S3, then the convergence of S3 at the quasar position would be approximately half of that from S2. We estimate that the time-delay distance will shift by \u22720.5 per cent due to ignoring S3\u2019s mass distribution, if it indeed lies at a similar redshift of S2. This shift is negligible compared to the typical uncertainty (5\u20138 per cent) on the estimated time-delay distance given the quality of the current data. Therefore, we do not include its mass distribution in our model as we do not know the true redshift of S3.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530306 id=\"203530306\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-7>5.7 Potential additional image C2 split from the image C</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A faint blob is noticeable on a few pixels toward North-East from the position of G2 in the F160W band. This blob can potentially be another quasar image C2 split off from the image C by the nearby satellite G2. This potential additional image is not noticeable in the <em>UVIS</em> bands, but this non-detection in the <em>UVIS</em> bands can be caused by differential extinction through G2. If such an additional image is predicted by the model, we allow the model to assign point-source-like flux at the position of the predicted additional image. Note that we do not impose the existence of this additional image in the model.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530308 id=\"203530308\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-8>5.8 <em>HST</em> image region for likelihood computation</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To compute the imaging likelihood, we choose a large enough circular region of the <em>HST</em> image centred on the deflector galaxy in each band so that it contains most of the flux from the lens system in that particular band. The radii of these regions are 4.3, 3.3, and 3.3\u2009arcsec in the F160W, F814W, and F475X bands, respectively. We mask out some of the pixels around the faint blob visible between G1 and G3 to block its light that would otherwise be within the chosen apertures. See the \u2018Normalized Residual\u2019 plots of Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> or <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> for the shape of the likelihood computation regions. In Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec9\">B</a>, we show that this particular choice of likelihood computation regions is not a source of bias in our analysis.</p>                        <a id=\"203530310\" scrollto-destination=\"203530310\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=yoLIx8Ks5b2s0sVLJ1pFqiSEMDxaM9vMoKBT4TQzysIep1k9oAK3q-KtOLxZGE9On-m~iqBQV4PREVojUjXBITCy0n-GClaTMonL~SD15wY2t6HCKeEwU9mxZtYZAj6YKouhX2QC1c-uqcuwUDv6PE2RNKMMeo-0OnE-A9XMO13bvjb-bm47yL6Jqwrp2Y5JHi4FqeSn1fcblpmBZYYJDYV3tajKBW03h2e~7BC6gk3HEq0kushh0ssXb4jSxYIaQrT4U11tJmhGBl-xR~B-EIWyH3uH686iZ5DAHAB1nPxzdpAu0bDLyy8qJ-CMgQHXYnnh4Kp8EGPge4-wgfEq1w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The most likely lens model and reconstructed image of DES J0408\u20135354 using the power-law model. The next three rows show the observed image, the reconstructed image, the residual, the reconstructed source in order from the left-hand side to the right-hand side for each of the HST filters.
