class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Properties of the quasar accretion disc used to compute the microlensing time-delay maps.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Quantity<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Value<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Black hole mass, log<sub>10</sub>(<em>M</em><sub>BH</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub>)\u00a0</td><td>8.41\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.27\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Eddington ratio, log<sub>10</sub>(<em>L</em><sub>bol</sub>/<em>L</em><sub>Edd</sub>)\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.48\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.27\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Accretion disc size, <em>R</em><sub>0</sub> (cm)\u00a0</td><td>3.125\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Accretion efficiency, \u03b7\u00a0</td><td>0.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Central wavelength for light curve observation, \u03bb (\u03bcm)\u00a0</td><td>0.668\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Average foreground stellar mass, \u2329<em>M</em><sub>\u22c6</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub>\u232a\u00a0</td><td>0.3\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Quantity<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Value<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Black hole mass, log<sub>10</sub>(<em>M</em><sub>BH</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub>)\u00a0</td><td>8.41\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.27\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Eddington ratio, log<sub>10</sub>(<em>L</em><sub>bol</sub>/<em>L</em><sub>Edd</sub>)\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.48\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.27\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Accretion disc size, <em>R</em><sub>0</sub> (cm)\u00a0</td><td>3.125\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Accretion efficiency, \u03b7\u00a0</td><td>0.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Central wavelength for light curve observation, \u03bb (\u03bcm)\u00a0</td><td>0.668\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Average foreground stellar mass, \u2329<em>M</em><sub>\u22c6</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub>\u232a\u00a0</td><td>0.3\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/203530356\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We account for the microlensing time-delay effect in the measured time delay by sampling from the microlensing time-delay distribution and adjusting the measured time delay as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ60\" content-id=\"equ60\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\Delta t_{\\rm XY, adjusted} = \\Delta t_{\\rm XY, measured} + t_{\\rm X, micro} - t_{\\rm Y, micro}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(60)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The microlensing time-delay effects is small compared to the uncertainty on the measured time delays. Thus, accounting for this microlensing time-delay effect does not shift the effective time-delay distance by more than 0.1 per cent (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>). We only perform this step as a check and we do not include this effect in our inference of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530359 id=\"203530359\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3>6.3 Inference of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The cosmological distance posterior contains all the cosmographic information. We infer <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> from this distance posterior for a flat \u039bCDM cosmology with priors <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> \u2208 [0, 150] km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup> and \u03a9<sub>m</sub> \u2208 [0.05, 0.5]. We take these priors for consistency with previous H0LiCOW analyses (Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). The \u03a9<sub>m</sub> prior is based on our knowledge from various observations that the Universe is neither empty nor closed. We take a kernel density estimate of the distance posterior as the likelihood function for cosmological parameters to retain the full covariance between <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\Delta t}^{\\rm eff}$|</span> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>. Similar to Birrer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), we take the bandwidth for the kernel density estimation to be sufficiently narrow so as to not affect the resultant posteriors of the cosmological parameters. We infer <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$74.2_{-3.0}^{+2.7}$|</span>\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121\u2009</sup>Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup> in the \u039bCDM cosmology, which is a 3.9 per cent measurement (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>). In this 3.9 per cent uncertainty, we estimate that the time-delay measurement contributes 1.8 per cent, the external convergence contributes 3.3 per cent, and the lens modelling and other sources contribute the remaining 1 per cent uncertainty. As a systematic check on our model weighting scheme, we infer <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> by combining all the models with equal weight as done in the first few analyses of the H0LiCOW lenses (e.g. Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). For this most conservative weighting scheme, we find <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$H_0 = 74.8^{+2.7}_{-3.0}$|</span> km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, which is a 0.8 per cent deviation from our quoted <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> above. We summarize the various systematic checks performed in this paper and their corresponding impacts on the inferred <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec13\">F</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"203530361\" scrollto-destination=\"203530361\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=fctjUt4WS5cqTq20gULfKAtNLIfTxN7U765jwf~29lIPCwfTe3vgXQANR1tniQGtjgphIQNP9PMxicPWgFL1WJHdkrdezguXmI~nAelHB8qWVmh0QbuP4Zsml0K-laipMa-0~lPp~oDe24qLyjWhhqgPXIvOksAD82hq6mGCF4AThVC1dcGgT4tBK08-L99MJOuO0Iyeq6r87T59dQ2KcxHkKWYicQmZbAEStbbCHbtTgrzDXx4E0buSBHO1FrHxPtF71Bkxg8ernX1wz2unvGaUeXtlwDDi5vi0RhlCeHNeHgVTEjgi3UeA1f8BgdG3zrryWy-aEw-QiGOxoWiViA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Posterior probability distribution functions of H0 and \u03a9m in the \u039bCDM cosmology for the 2D distance posterior in Fig.\u00a09. The inferred Hubble constant is H0 = $74.2_{-3.0}^{+2.7}$\u2009km\u2009s\u22121\u2009Mpc\u22121.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530361/staa828fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530361\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=IhrjamQvEeQ1QIcpcHrVEB4GZ5EdDHkkkrvuvEXMbx~mR9NLJ-SfdwwhbmZPLCRtUI0BijYe9YPoNBZhE4ljblXhVDA5Q20Q9Ow-F8zC2WUkVjQjJxM6CWRXqyd4IQqRGPFAeHN3YUwmhKzQhxDZrpT9BBEq7jZS0xXfll8s3bW6ZEOTLWsZQmBb2Du0MxBepT5KndedF8mUOZI3vCmNrnGFjXlP7WDkKOfYHJilIxb236tR-3rMPJjFdgvTlBJXkn9b3IRnUpwyfqzmNlZmj6AvrdPTlrW0B~uWncNV59t2j4sBMGhju0d7FF9mQoLu3VBTgQA4ljvwB8-TiL5tTw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530361&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Posterior probability distribution functions of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> and \u03a9<sub>m</sub> in the \u039bCDM cosmology for the 2D distance posterior in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. The inferred Hubble constant is <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$74.2_{-3.0}^{+2.7}$|</span>\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=fctjUt4WS5cqTq20gULfKAtNLIfTxN7U765jwf~29lIPCwfTe3vgXQANR1tniQGtjgphIQNP9PMxicPWgFL1WJHdkrdezguXmI~nAelHB8qWVmh0QbuP4Zsml0K-laipMa-0~lPp~oDe24qLyjWhhqgPXIvOksAD82hq6mGCF4AThVC1dcGgT4tBK08-L99MJOuO0Iyeq6r87T59dQ2KcxHkKWYicQmZbAEStbbCHbtTgrzDXx4E0buSBHO1FrHxPtF71Bkxg8ernX1wz2unvGaUeXtlwDDi5vi0RhlCeHNeHgVTEjgi3UeA1f8BgdG3zrryWy-aEw-QiGOxoWiViA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Posterior probability distribution functions of H0 and \u03a9m in the \u039bCDM cosmology for the 2D distance posterior in Fig.\u00a09. The inferred Hubble constant is H0 = $74.2_{-3.0}^{+2.7}$\u2009km\u2009s\u22121\u2009Mpc\u22121.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530361/staa828fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530361\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=IhrjamQvEeQ1QIcpcHrVEB4GZ5EdDHkkkrvuvEXMbx~mR9NLJ-SfdwwhbmZPLCRtUI0BijYe9YPoNBZhE4ljblXhVDA5Q20Q9Ow-F8zC2WUkVjQjJxM6CWRXqyd4IQqRGPFAeHN3YUwmhKzQhxDZrpT9BBEq7jZS0xXfll8s3bW6ZEOTLWsZQmBb2Du0MxBepT5KndedF8mUOZI3vCmNrnGFjXlP7WDkKOfYHJilIxb236tR-3rMPJjFdgvTlBJXkn9b3IRnUpwyfqzmNlZmj6AvrdPTlrW0B~uWncNV59t2j4sBMGhju0d7FF9mQoLu3VBTgQA4ljvwB8-TiL5tTw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530361&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Posterior probability distribution functions of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> and \u03a9<sub>m</sub> in the \u039bCDM cosmology for the 2D distance posterior in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. The inferred Hubble constant is <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$74.2_{-3.0}^{+2.7}$|</span>\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup>.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203530362 id=\"203530362\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 DISCUSSION AND SUMMARY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we analyse the lens system DES J0408\u20135354 to blindly infer the effective time-delay distance from the observed time delays. We model the mass profile of the lens system using high-resolution <em>HST</em> imaging from three bands. We combine the time-delay and kinematic likelihoods with the lens model posterior, and factor in the statistically inferred external convergence to obtain the cosmological distance posteriors in the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\Delta t}^{\\rm eff}$|</span>\u2013<em>D</em><sub>d</sub> plane. We perform a thorough check for systematic effects arising from model choices, and we marginalize over them to account for this source of systematic uncertainties in our analysis. As a result, we constrain the 2D joint posterior of the effective time delay distance <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\Delta t}^{\\rm eff}$|</span> and the angular diameter distance to the deflector <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> that fully incorporates their covariance. The marginalized estimates for these two distances are <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$D_{\\Delta t}^{\\rm eff}=$|</span><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3382_{-115}^{+146}$|</span> with 3.9 per cent uncertainty, and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> = <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1711_{-280}^{+376}$|</span> with 19.2 per cent uncertainty. These constraints translate into <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>= <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$74.2_{-3.0}^{+2.7}$|</span>\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup> with a precision of 3.9 per cent. This estimated value of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> is consistent with from the previously analysed sample of six lenses by the H0LiCOW collaboration, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$H_0 = 73.3^{+1.7}_{-1.8}$|</span>\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121\u2009</sup>Mpc<sup>\u2212</sup><sup>1</sup> (Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). It is also consistent with measurements of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> based on the local distance ladder (Freedman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Riess et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>), reinforcing the tension (Verde et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) with the inference from early Universe probes (Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Planck Collaboration VI <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The one presented in this paper is the first of two independent cosmographic analysis of the lens system DES J0408\u20135354, which is based on the lens-modelling software <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstronomy</span>. A second independent and blind analysis using the lens-modelling software <span class=\"small-caps\">glee</span> will be presented in a future work (Y\u0131ld\u0131r\u0131m et\u00a0al., in preparation). In this future paper, we will compare the results from the two modelling efforts and quantitatively evaluate the systematic uncertainty that may arise due to using different softwares and adopting different modelling choices by different investigators. The posterior probability distribution function of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> from DES J0408\u20135354 will be combined with previous measurements by the H0LiCOW team after the second analysis is complete, so as to include this modelling systematic uncertainty in the combination.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The analysis presented in this paper can be improved in the future. Due to a multitude complexities required in the lens model of DES J0408\u20135354, we fix the distance ratios between the multiple lens and source planes in our analysis using a fiducial \u039bCDM cosmology to make our analysis computationally feasible. We show that the choice of fiducial cosmology has negligible impact on our inference within the \u039bCDM model. However, it would be ideal to treat the distance ratios as independent non-linear parameters in the model. We leave this improvement to be implemented in future works, where more general cosmological models will be considered. Furthermore, the precision on the inferred <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> can be improved in the future with the help of spatially resolved kinematics (Shajib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Y\u0131ld\u0131r\u0131m, Suyu &amp; Halkola <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib129\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib129\" data-open=\"bib129\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the modelling, more general mass profiles can be used in the composite model \u2013 e.g. the generalized NFW profile, or a mass-to-light ratio gradient in the stellar component (e.g. Zhao <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib132\" data-open=\"bib132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). However, these types of generalized mass profile had been computationally intractable for lens modelling in the elliptical case until only recently (Shajib <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Given the computational cost of this study (\u223c10<sup>6</sup> CPU h) already pushing far beyond the typical case of modelling endeavours for a single lens system, we leave the explorations of more general mass models and estimation of the corresponding impact in the inference of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> for future studies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Improving the precision on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> measurement from each single lens system, increasing the number of systems to \u223c40, and investigating the presence of yet unknown systematic errors are all necessary steps towards reaching 1 per cent precision from time-delay cosmography (Shajib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The analysis presented in this paper took one step in each direction.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=203530368 id=\"203530368\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank the anonymous referee for helpful comments that improved this manuscript. id=\"203530380\" class=\"backreferences-title\" data-legacy-id=ref1>REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Abbott</div>  <div N.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">2018</div>, <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">859</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">138</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.3847/1538-4357/aabf3e\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.3847/1538-4357/aabf3e</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.3847/1538-4357/aabf3e\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.3847%2F1538-4357%2Faabf3e\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.3847%2F1538-4357%2Faabf3e\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib130\" data-legacy-id=\"bib130\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib130\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib130\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib130\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Yuan</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">W.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Riess</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A. G.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Macri</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">L. M.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Casertano</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">S.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Scolnic</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">D. M.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">2019</div>, <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">886</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">61</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.3847/1538-4357/ab4bc9\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.3847%2F1538-4357%2Fab4bc9\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.3847%2F1538-4357%2Fab4bc9\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib129\" data-legacy-id=\"bib129\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib129\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib129\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib129\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Y\u0131ld\u0131r\u0131m</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Suyu</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">S. H.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Halkola</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">2020</div>, <div class=\"source \">MNRAS</div>, <div class=\"volume\">493</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">4783</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/mnras/staa498\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1093%2Fmnras%2Fstaa498\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1093%2Fmnras%2Fstaa498\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib131\" data-legacy-id=\"bib131\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib131\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib131\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib131\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Zahid</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">H. J.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Geller</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">M. J.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Fabricant</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">D. G.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Hwang</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">H. S.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">2016</div>, <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">832</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">203</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.3847/0004-637X/832/2/203\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.3847/0004-637X/832/2/203</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.3847/0004-637X/832/2/203\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.3847%2F0004-637X%2F832%2F2%2F203\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.3847%2F0004-637X%2F832%2F2%2F203\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib132\" data-legacy-id=\"bib132\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib132\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib132\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib132\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Zhao</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">H.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">1996</div>, <div class=\"source \">MNRAS</div>, <div class=\"volume\">278</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">488</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/278.2.488\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.1093/mnras/278.2.488</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/mnras/278.2.488\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1093%2Fmnras%2F278.2.488\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1093%2Fmnras%2F278.2.488\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530382 id=\"203530382\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>APPENDIX A: IMPACT OF FIDUCIAL COSMOLOGY IN THE LENS MODELLING</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We check the impact of fixing the distance ratios between the lens and the source planes with a fiducial \u039bCDM cosmology with density parameters \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.3 and \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.7. For this purpose, we run two separate lens models with the same model setup for the power-law mass profile, but with the cosmological parameters (\u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.1, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.9) and (\u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.45, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.55) to fix the distance ratios. Within this wide-range of \u03a9<sub>m</sub> values within the flat \u039bCDM cosmology, <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> only shifts by \u2272 1 per cent (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa1\" data-open=\"figa1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>). As this shift is much smaller than the precision of the measured Hubble constant allowed by the quality of our data, we conclude that our inferred cosmological distance posterior on the <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub>\u2013<em>D</em><sub>d</sub> plane is effectively independent of the choice of cosmological parameters within the flat \u039bCDM cosmology.</p>                        <a id=\"203530384\" scrollto-destination=\"203530384\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figa1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=lWVxD6FAfVxJynVtvcap-E9erBX4oDjDuFJV4j0MGnHf0~F8KNBJO3ZQizETLJvvhXeVdAEY6Td6s8WJroVGO~ijtnye2Cd0Kop4bp1rsNvblklJCr2idRKkZi~AmxXZ1n9SdX9Rb0427PgFYQP2GMwd1RbpvvepeMh4c64GLs9B36fYkjM9YopFZg1bhyQlNHDJzAnxE2Yl1nydaS3p6TCo5yUK0MzIx6yFbY9pqlr-PYbBVcdvdlWVArloSDJi4F99j3Oyasrb~On-tehqxvkx50WQIq4u0F9QWS1vbk8K3E27h4OwuTHQl7s7lqt4~Kaxa40bAPdxxmiPj33WPw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the distance posteriors and inferred H0 for different fiducial cosmologies within the flat \u039bCDM model. We compare between three set of cosmological parameters: \u03a9m = 0.3, \u03a9\u039b = 0.7 (orange), \u03a9m = 0.1, \u03a9\u039b = 0.9 (green), and \u03a9m = 0.45, \u03a9\u039b = 0.55 (purple). The distance posteriors are from identical lens model setups with the power-law mass profile except for the fiducial cosmology. H0 shifts by less than 1 per cent within these wide range of \u03a9m values. This shift is much smaller than the precision on H0 allowed by our current data quality. As a result, we can treat the distance posteriors inferred from our analysis to be independent of cosmological assumptions within the flat \u039bCDM cosmology.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figa1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530384/staa828figa1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figa1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530384\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=ud5Jl5OK8JniHz~YL-fjFUY-8UQVLUOcFgOel-mHo9qjjPWOnnT-wSO-yXnsa30K~pps1Btc7QtTc09CLx1slWtZfZ80xD979mn7ng6fD1~QqV4pZRsnXOxjDI6uhSuxgUqfuvabbFOYl9UT10Ty8~1P2Cj6E06RL-GlR8s6hzNW5BhRjvjuHwEW-l7fQbjWUAAlLRU08Jr7w9o8ATLun21Fsz1vaNfy-cXl3n8BXc~mYCJ-Om09nH7gH4fZU5TDG88naHx~I90ke-9BPzYJAiecbDjis3iUZKW08xYGHTBIk7F9Qgr8UFaWnKBLDryQecgdw1cqkKv3gUCgABIkDw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530384&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figa1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the distance posteriors and inferred <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> for different fiducial cosmologies within the flat \u039bCDM model. We compare between three set of cosmological parameters: \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.7 (orange), \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.1, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.9 (green), and \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.45, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.55 (purple). The distance posteriors are from identical lens model setups with the power-law mass profile except for the fiducial cosmology. <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> shifts by less than 1 per cent within these wide range of \u03a9<sub>m</sub> values. This shift is much smaller than the precision on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> allowed by our current data quality. As a result, we can treat the distance posteriors inferred from our analysis to be independent of cosmological assumptions within the flat \u039bCDM cosmology.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figa1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=lWVxD6FAfVxJynVtvcap-E9erBX4oDjDuFJV4j0MGnHf0~F8KNBJO3ZQizETLJvvhXeVdAEY6Td6s8WJroVGO~ijtnye2Cd0Kop4bp1rsNvblklJCr2idRKkZi~AmxXZ1n9SdX9Rb0427PgFYQP2GMwd1RbpvvepeMh4c64GLs9B36fYkjM9YopFZg1bhyQlNHDJzAnxE2Yl1nydaS3p6TCo5yUK0MzIx6yFbY9pqlr-PYbBVcdvdlWVArloSDJi4F99j3Oyasrb~On-tehqxvkx50WQIq4u0F9QWS1vbk8K3E27h4OwuTHQl7s7lqt4~Kaxa40bAPdxxmiPj33WPw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the distance posteriors and inferred H0 for different fiducial cosmologies within the flat \u039bCDM model. We compare between three set of cosmological parameters: \u03a9m = 0.3, \u03a9\u039b = 0.7 (orange), \u03a9m = 0.1, \u03a9\u039b = 0.9 (green), and \u03a9m = 0.45, \u03a9\u039b = 0.55 (purple). The distance posteriors are from identical lens model setups with the power-law mass profile except for the fiducial cosmology. H0 shifts by less than 1 per cent within these wide range of \u03a9m values. This shift is much smaller than the precision on H0 allowed by our current data quality. As a result, we can treat the distance posteriors inferred from our analysis to be independent of cosmological assumptions within the flat \u039bCDM cosmology.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figa1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530384/staa828figa1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figa1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530384\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=ud5Jl5OK8JniHz~YL-fjFUY-8UQVLUOcFgOel-mHo9qjjPWOnnT-wSO-yXnsa30K~pps1Btc7QtTc09CLx1slWtZfZ80xD979mn7ng6fD1~QqV4pZRsnXOxjDI6uhSuxgUqfuvabbFOYl9UT10Ty8~1P2Cj6E06RL-GlR8s6hzNW5BhRjvjuHwEW-l7fQbjWUAAlLRU08Jr7w9o8ATLun21Fsz1vaNfy-cXl3n8BXc~mYCJ-Om09nH7gH4fZU5TDG88naHx~I90ke-9BPzYJAiecbDjis3iUZKW08xYGHTBIk7F9Qgr8UFaWnKBLDryQecgdw1cqkKv3gUCgABIkDw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530384&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figa1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the distance posteriors and inferred <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> for different fiducial cosmologies within the flat \u039bCDM model. We compare between three set of cosmological parameters: \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.7 (orange), \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.1, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.9 (green), and \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.45, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.55 (purple). The distance posteriors are from identical lens model setups with the power-law mass profile except for the fiducial cosmology. <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> shifts by less than 1 per cent within these wide range of \u03a9<sub>m</sub> values. This shift is much smaller than the precision on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> allowed by our current data quality. As a result, we can treat the distance posteriors inferred from our analysis to be independent of cosmological assumptions within the flat \u039bCDM cosmology.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, we find that the inferred distance posteriors depend on the fiducial cosmology within the <em>w</em>CDM model. If we adopt the fiducial <em>w</em>CDM cosmology with <em>w</em> = \u22121.06, \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.3, \u03a9<sub>de</sub> = 0.7, then the inferred <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> shifts by approximately 3 per cent from that inferred from the cosmology with <em>w</em> = \u22121 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa2\" data-open=\"figa2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A2</a>). We adopt the shift \u0394<em>w</em> = 0.06 for comparison, as this range is in <em>w</em> is the joint precision from the <em>Planck</em> with CMB lensing, SNIae, and baryon acoustic oscillation measurements (Planck Collaboration VI <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). This significant shift in <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> demonstrate that our double source plane treatment is sensitive to the dark energy equation of state parameter <em>w</em> (e.g. Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Collett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Collett &amp; Auger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Therefore, our distance posteriors should not be used to constrain cosmological parameters in extended cosmologies other than the flat \u039bCDM model. We leave the computation of a posterior distribution function valid in more general cosmologies for future work.</p>                        <a id=\"203530386\" scrollto-destination=\"203530386\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figa2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828figa2.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=lR9bR89YgkFeQwJ7Euef~gQaKpmPTJujyB3DsVo-2JLHDtWSbjKIpX63Z8Z3ThWBTh6iIVfF96BDp0NT0sqZDLpj0gdjF1N-Q99269Hp8VRzpFrKKb--Wo6yVAJtf15UW9qU6NFouIKqzrKA7rwjw5FbkZ6TYP0DYXhZ4zyJMOGpFKsoWihAashNRtfcAzu~7oYu4F46QqwFUvyrAk-8B3GgPLPKuC1lq8b95gx714kpHRLSmaWNErmo8LPdJrsVlqIcoV4yTL6EojyHf2C9CPGrk~vKtQJbvRDwbFyS2s983XarZLbrb5DS~X5pYx2AY1vz1Pwb8FlxJ2hlSTUgJA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the distance posteriors and inferred H0 for different fiducial cosmologies within the wCDM model. We compare between three set of cosmological parameters: w = \u22121, \u03a9m = 0.3, \u03a9\u039b = 0.7 (orange), and w = \u22121.06, \u03a9m = 0.1, \u03a9\u039b = 0.9 (green). The distance posteriors are from identical lens model setups with the power-law mass profile except for the fiducial cosmology. H0 shifts by \u223c3 per cent for a shift \u0394w = 0.06, which is approximately the joint precision on w from the Planck with CMB lensing, SNIae, and the baryon acoustic oscillation measurements (Planck Collaboration VI 2018). This shift in H0 shows that the double source plane treatment in our analysis is sensitive to the dark energy equation of state parameter w (Gavazzi et\u00a0al. 2008; Collett &amp; Auger 2014). As a result, our distance posterior should not be used to constrain parameters in cosmologies that extend the flat \u039bCDM model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figa2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530386/staa828figa2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figa2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530386\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828figa2.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=YEwCfxpPvwOSOECV~kHPq1Mh4xNeO0bPo4rL-nWyoifkI47SLOzw75vOjGz~nU4GKn9W5C6H1Wq~WagFDrRrJ5t~gYbVYlRP-IaHVz~UpCGh864K7Zno1zxPwbpFkfCAUTM~Ito8NQxo74n3wkUhM56-tD2K6LK4OMgVqQdDPqTMGB2vkNRVGOZsPkVmmkzHnXUmhsVgmfqxA~3I8HJpBkCd1stRVAocNJmx8ouA7IPA6TSueMKqPW3gfaBvdPlffvS1mIjkTXlY3lbrR3981kbSyIx9iANzc~f8SzxjQ3GnOawrxZurUAXqc3VOgxMeOwgaHYtx3Xi2PVoFaaR2iw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530386&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figa2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the distance posteriors and inferred <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> for different fiducial cosmologies within the <em>w</em>CDM model. We compare between three set of cosmological parameters: <em>w</em> = \u22121, \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.7 (orange), and <em>w</em> = \u22121.06, \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.1, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.9 (green). The distance posteriors are from identical lens model setups with the power-law mass profile except for the fiducial cosmology. <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> shifts by \u223c3 per cent for a shift \u0394<em>w</em> = 0.06, which is approximately the joint precision on <em>w</em> from the <em>Planck</em> with CMB lensing, SNIae, and the baryon acoustic oscillation measurements (Planck Collaboration VI <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). This shift in <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> shows that the double source plane treatment in our analysis is sensitive to the dark energy equation of state parameter <em>w</em> (Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Collett &amp; Auger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). As a result, our distance posterior should not be used to constrain parameters in cosmologies that extend the flat \u039bCDM model.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figa2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828figa2.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=lR9bR89YgkFeQwJ7Euef~gQaKpmPTJujyB3DsVo-2JLHDtWSbjKIpX63Z8Z3ThWBTh6iIVfF96BDp0NT0sqZDLpj0gdjF1N-Q99269Hp8VRzpFrKKb--Wo6yVAJtf15UW9qU6NFouIKqzrKA7rwjw5FbkZ6TYP0DYXhZ4zyJMOGpFKsoWihAashNRtfcAzu~7oYu4F46QqwFUvyrAk-8B3GgPLPKuC1lq8b95gx714kpHRLSmaWNErmo8LPdJrsVlqIcoV4yTL6EojyHf2C9CPGrk~vKtQJbvRDwbFyS2s983XarZLbrb5DS~X5pYx2AY1vz1Pwb8FlxJ2hlSTUgJA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the distance posteriors and inferred H0 for different fiducial cosmologies within the wCDM model. We compare between three set of cosmological parameters: w = \u22121, \u03a9m = 0.3, \u03a9\u039b = 0.7 (orange), and w = \u22121.06, \u03a9m = 0.1, \u03a9\u039b = 0.9 (green). The distance posteriors are from identical lens model setups with the power-law mass profile except for the fiducial cosmology. H0 shifts by \u223c3 per cent for a shift \u0394w = 0.06, which is approximately the joint precision on w from the Planck with CMB lensing, SNIae, and the baryon acoustic oscillation measurements (Planck Collaboration VI 2018). This shift in H0 shows that the double source plane treatment in our analysis is sensitive to the dark energy equation of state parameter w (Gavazzi et\u00a0al. 2008; Collett &amp; Auger 2014). As a result, our distance posterior should not be used to constrain parameters in cosmologies that extend the flat \u039bCDM model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figa2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530386/staa828figa2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figa2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530386\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828figa2.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=YEwCfxpPvwOSOECV~kHPq1Mh4xNeO0bPo4rL-nWyoifkI47SLOzw75vOjGz~nU4GKn9W5C6H1Wq~WagFDrRrJ5t~gYbVYlRP-IaHVz~UpCGh864K7Zno1zxPwbpFkfCAUTM~Ito8NQxo74n3wkUhM56-tD2K6LK4OMgVqQdDPqTMGB2vkNRVGOZsPkVmmkzHnXUmhsVgmfqxA~3I8HJpBkCd1stRVAocNJmx8ouA7IPA6TSueMKqPW3gfaBvdPlffvS1mIjkTXlY3lbrR3981kbSyIx9iANzc~f8SzxjQ3GnOawrxZurUAXqc3VOgxMeOwgaHYtx3Xi2PVoFaaR2iw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530386&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figa2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the distance posteriors and inferred <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> for different fiducial cosmologies within the <em>w</em>CDM model. We compare between three set of cosmological parameters: <em>w</em> = \u22121, \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.7 (orange), and <em>w</em> = \u22121.06, \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.1, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.9 (green). The distance posteriors are from identical lens model setups with the power-law mass profile except for the fiducial cosmology. <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> shifts by \u223c3 per cent for a shift \u0394<em>w</em> = 0.06, which is approximately the joint precision on <em>w</em> from the <em>Planck</em> with CMB lensing, SNIae, and the baryon acoustic oscillation measurements (Planck Collaboration VI <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). This shift in <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> shows that the double source plane treatment in our analysis is sensitive to the dark energy equation of state parameter <em>w</em> (Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Collett &amp; Auger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). As a result, our distance posterior should not be used to constrain parameters in cosmologies that extend the flat \u039bCDM model.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530387 id=\"203530387\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec9>APPENDIX B: IMPACT OF LIKELIHOOD COMPUTATION REGION CHOICE</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We check if our adopted region for imaging likelihood computation can be a source of systematic bias in the lens modelling. We perform the modelling procedure for two different region sizes keeping every other settings in the model the same for a power-law model. The regular region sizes are 4.3, 3.3, and 3.3\u2009arcsec in radius for the F160W, F814W, and F475X bands, respectively. The larger region sizes are larger by 0.2 arcsec in each band. The median of the effective time-delay distance shifts by less than 0.1 per cent and the median of the angular diameter distance shifts by less than 2 per cent between these two choices of the likelihood computation region (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figb1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figb1\" data-open=\"figb1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"203530389\" scrollto-destination=\"203530389\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figb1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828figb1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=IhHhyEhPyjuE-7rUVfJC3VZv8-HlWFlX3-QWlVTVRjfDhmlOUqkvyvTXuhuDWJbo684dAKT~VqjRkKBGFG1er5IazMeomG57aYcaK7YOV34iPRG8f~9FWCxNkA-jvnoDxyEfReyvOxzkvz2Z6IJWUXm1XEHVcUH~qZPmSqADYg1-AhbM3WnYMpx9QMgLn1EHS~wZ57PtMg0USIz3PxIZdo5gh5AE6TwmGdgO5AywdRhMTfX4hsq3~9YjGOtr95DRICTjow~jmMON6on1-flxTlOXDYw07q8vItZL4-SjYyUrOP3UhP1OB7aXjPc-j1BB0zqQQUsAn7U6FR60NQWItg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the distance posteriors from the power-law lens model for two likelihood computation region sizes. The smaller regions have radii 4.3, 3.3, and 3.3\u2009arcsec in the F160W, F814W, F475X bands, respectively. The larger region sizes are 4.5, 3.5, and 3.5\u2009arcsec in the same order. All the other model setups are same between the two runs. The distance posteriors are almost identical. Therefore, the choice of likelihood computation region has negligible impact in our analysis.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figb1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530389/staa828figb1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figb1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530389\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828figb1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=Tg2Rb4LAoNCI-7UOVD9KS9DM913J1QrcOMdijmUOUeeYhv5TJxa4Okh9A5V1lWXjNJNmcpSEnIebB33cq3gMHuOMGxnchdDF2bkjxLMJauqZq10JcASMBvposwamzrHCVp2-3l6X1dBKLqZTmrGN2~thsAUJCvn49VqkNvF8~v1s6BKy16lChhWEvgsavGAEqtFBAIUXLfSgDnzu0p-blOkGzUF92h2rxgT2V2K3Ebva8AWpG-d1fIDeJ114X7KezWzeas4Azp~tCTfIkVKnMhO9B-ZvRKCOlniq1f423t~XhmHTv-4IiT4Ogi2TWrv2AJAamLAHkrkzyigQbBH4SA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530389&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figb1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the distance posteriors from the power-law lens model for two likelihood computation region sizes. The smaller regions have radii 4.3, 3.3, and 3.3\u2009arcsec in the F160W, F814W, F475X bands, respectively. The larger region sizes are 4.5, 3.5, and 3.5\u2009arcsec in the same order. All the other model setups are same between the two runs. The distance posteriors are almost identical. Therefore, the choice of likelihood computation region has negligible impact in our analysis.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figb1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828figb1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=IhHhyEhPyjuE-7rUVfJC3VZv8-HlWFlX3-QWlVTVRjfDhmlOUqkvyvTXuhuDWJbo684dAKT~VqjRkKBGFG1er5IazMeomG57aYcaK7YOV34iPRG8f~9FWCxNkA-jvnoDxyEfReyvOxzkvz2Z6IJWUXm1XEHVcUH~qZPmSqADYg1-AhbM3WnYMpx9QMgLn1EHS~wZ57PtMg0USIz3PxIZdo5gh5AE6TwmGdgO5AywdRhMTfX4hsq3~9YjGOtr95DRICTjow~jmMON6on1-flxTlOXDYw07q8vItZL4-SjYyUrOP3UhP1OB7aXjPc-j1BB0zqQQUsAn7U6FR60NQWItg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the distance posteriors from the power-law lens model for two likelihood computation region sizes. The smaller regions have radii 4.3, 3.3, and 3.3\u2009arcsec in the F160W, F814W, F475X bands, respectively. The larger region sizes are 4.5, 3.5, and 3.5\u2009arcsec in the same order. All the other model setups are same between the two runs. The distance posteriors are almost identical. Therefore, the choice of likelihood computation region has negligible impact in our analysis.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figb1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530389/staa828figb1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figb1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530389\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828figb1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=Tg2Rb4LAoNCI-7UOVD9KS9DM913J1QrcOMdijmUOUeeYhv5TJxa4Okh9A5V1lWXjNJNmcpSEnIebB33cq3gMHuOMGxnchdDF2bkjxLMJauqZq10JcASMBvposwamzrHCVp2-3l6X1dBKLqZTmrGN2~thsAUJCvn49VqkNvF8~v1s6BKy16lChhWEvgsavGAEqtFBAIUXLfSgDnzu0p-blOkGzUF92h2rxgT2V2K3Ebva8AWpG-d1fIDeJ114X7KezWzeas4Azp~tCTfIkVKnMhO9B-ZvRKCOlniq1f423t~XhmHTv-4IiT4Ogi2TWrv2AJAamLAHkrkzyigQbBH4SA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530389&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figb1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the distance posteriors from the power-law lens model for two likelihood computation region sizes. The smaller regions have radii 4.3, 3.3, and 3.3\u2009arcsec in the F160W, F814W, F475X bands, respectively. The larger region sizes are 4.5, 3.5, and 3.5\u2009arcsec in the same order. All the other model setups are same between the two runs. The distance posteriors are almost identical. Therefore, the choice of likelihood computation region has negligible impact in our analysis.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530390 id=\"203530390\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec10>APPENDIX C: IMPACT OF THE CONVERGENCE FROM THE GROUP CONTAINING G1</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We estimate the convergence at G1\u2019s centre from the galaxy group containing G1 [group ID 5 in Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>)]. We randomly sample haloes from the centroid and velocity dispersion distributions estimated as described in Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). However, we use a uniform prior to obtain the velocity dispersion for the halo, whereas Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>) adopt the Jeffrey\u2019s prior. We convert the group\u2019s velocity dispersion into halo mass using the scaling relation <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ61\" content-id=\"equ61\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\log _{10} \\left[h(z) M_{200}\\right] = 13.98 + 2.75 \\log _{10} \\left(\\frac{\\sigma _{\\rm group}}{500\\ \\text{km s}^{-1}} \\right)\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(C1)</span></div>(Munari et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). We weight this halo mass distribution using the halo mass function from Tinker et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) corresponding to our fiducial cosmology and the lens redshift. We obtain the concentration parameter distribution using the theoretical <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>\u2013<em>c</em> relation from Diemer &amp; Joyce (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) with 0.16\u2009dex uncertainty. We also apply 10 per cent uncertainty on <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> to remove any strong dependency on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> through the fiducial cosmology. We compute the convergence distribution at G1\u2019s centre due to this distribution of the halo masses and we apply a cut in the group\u2019s shear distribution \u03b3<sub>group</sub> &lt; 0.1 to remove haloes that are inconsistent with the model predicted shear (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figc1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figc1\" data-open=\"figc1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">C1</a>). The median of the group\u2019s convergence distribution is 0.004. As we are explicitly accounting for the group\u2019s convergence here, we re-estimate \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> after removing the galaxies in this group from the number count statistic of Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). The re-estimated \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> decreases by 0.005 for the power-law mass models and by 0.008 for the composite mass models. As a result, explicitly accounting for the group\u2019s convergence decreases <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> by approximately 0.4 per cent. This shift is negligible compared to the 3.9 per cent uncertainty in our estimated value of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>.</div>                        <a id=\"203530392\" scrollto-destination=\"203530392\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figc1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure C1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828figc1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=TRtlxUy-vkuq3D8AiIklhoV5mt6S5lYajAB5cLmTp1MX3babVIiD6EK8Ogj4F9SMOYIykQfuoR~pDgGFIF2imR4Vnq-fL~HXv7cII1ZDSJXScNRUWufk79f4hBqktBN~6qVl7AKlTGdBnETb4G2SRaJpsAgvQSG0RIvtg9XtYYxEKGnaJPoN2~sNGxkzYmXCe7q8j7mCkv8~joaR1BO7-2zMqfO7WNXpzq2wY51CytUFXBycLIC~Ozdk9hCkXOZVw-GsiH1RQvF4OcjazQGlrP-7~CZwnlCGfKyFhy33mcmNbOBdwiP24yaqM4yurDYn3-oRym4OR4x8TnWoajCSTQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of the convergence at G1\u2019s centre from the galaxy group\u2019s halo containing G1. The distribution p(\u03bagroup) is estimated for the estimated centroid and velocity dispersion of this group in Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (2020).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figc1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530392/staa828figc1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figc1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530392\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828figc1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=gJcBRqKNbofFI4JBu0JGT7ZorClFFFee8Vbyy-hVY2NHufa9pGMVLrsD4BolWM~ychAKWPNEdjJ4URNTjVQBbB8PxdbRuhhDCcrRexL~CbFBfulHLIAk~V2AA8sz5AjmJf2ter0zGDB5wka49zwWQjUKzXRlf6SSSRCGuFqdRk1LE4~ZGD8zSOJH8c9pjYC75fz9G0KsyxMoFuvNojUHM0PsGM0-yQzHGV70AntMWLQF6grmQsc9Qw7Jbbz7MSvn9JHzVVdoEOuIItstngm7vXUA8iAJYGJITKwtvHTrzaP8Ob32Paht5ihsC~GjZ9TAhgKE3kyZ6PyvIs6DbH8rtQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530392&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figc1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of the convergence at G1\u2019s centre from the galaxy group\u2019s halo containing G1.
