(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figc1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure C1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828figc1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=TRtlxUy-vkuq3D8AiIklhoV5mt6S5lYajAB5cLmTp1MX3babVIiD6EK8Ogj4F9SMOYIykQfuoR~pDgGFIF2imR4Vnq-fL~HXv7cII1ZDSJXScNRUWufk79f4hBqktBN~6qVl7AKlTGdBnETb4G2SRaJpsAgvQSG0RIvtg9XtYYxEKGnaJPoN2~sNGxkzYmXCe7q8j7mCkv8~joaR1BO7-2zMqfO7WNXpzq2wY51CytUFXBycLIC~Ozdk9hCkXOZVw-GsiH1RQvF4OcjazQGlrP-7~CZwnlCGfKyFhy33mcmNbOBdwiP24yaqM4yurDYn3-oRym4OR4x8TnWoajCSTQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of the convergence at G1\u2019s centre from the galaxy group\u2019s halo containing G1. The distribution p(\u03bagroup) is estimated for the estimated centroid and velocity dispersion of this group in Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (2020).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figc1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530392/staa828figc1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figc1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530392\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828figc1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=gJcBRqKNbofFI4JBu0JGT7ZorClFFFee8Vbyy-hVY2NHufa9pGMVLrsD4BolWM~ychAKWPNEdjJ4URNTjVQBbB8PxdbRuhhDCcrRexL~CbFBfulHLIAk~V2AA8sz5AjmJf2ter0zGDB5wka49zwWQjUKzXRlf6SSSRCGuFqdRk1LE4~ZGD8zSOJH8c9pjYC75fz9G0KsyxMoFuvNojUHM0PsGM0-yQzHGV70AntMWLQF6grmQsc9Qw7Jbbz7MSvn9JHzVVdoEOuIItstngm7vXUA8iAJYGJITKwtvHTrzaP8Ob32Paht5ihsC~GjZ9TAhgKE3kyZ6PyvIs6DbH8rtQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530392&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figc1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of the convergence at G1\u2019s centre from the galaxy group\u2019s halo containing G1. The distribution <em>p</em>(\u03ba<sub>group</sub>) is estimated for the estimated centroid and velocity dispersion of this group in Buckley-Geer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1_660_1586904219717\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" data-open=\"bib1_660_1586904219717\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>).</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530393 id=\"203530393\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec11>APPENDIX D: CHECKING FOR THE EXISTENCE AND IMPACT OF A DARK SUBSTRUCTURE</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) propose a possible dark subhalo near image D toward the North\u2013East direction. We check the impact of such a dark substructure in our analysis by including a mass profile for the substructure in our lens model. We check with both SIS and spherical NFW profile for the substructure. We take a broad uniform prior of 0.8\u2009arcsec \u00d7 0.8\u2009\u2009arcsec for the centroid of the mass profile to encompass the possible position of the substructure given in fig. 9 of Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For both of the SIS and NFW profiles, our lens model constrains the possible position of the mass profile for the potential substructure (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figd1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figd1\" data-open=\"figd1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">D1</a>). Interestingly, the constrained position is consistent with the proposed position by Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), although the model had the freedom to offset the position by \u223c0.4\u2009arcsec from the constrained position. We estimate the SIS velocity dispersion of this possible dark substructure to be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{\\rm SIS}=33.7_{-1.3}^{+1.9}$|</span>\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. From the model with the NFW profile for the dark substructure, we estimate the halo mass <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log _{10} (M_{200}/M_{\\odot })=10.65^{+0.10}_{-0.06}$|\u2060</span>, halo radius <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm 200}=45.7^{+3.5}_{-2.1}$|</span> kpc, and concentration <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$c_{200}=12.2^{+4.1}_{-2.2}$|\u2060</span>.</p>                        <a id=\"203530396\" scrollto-destination=\"203530396\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figd1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure D1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828figd1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=aiyVz-fAzsMDavbrN1SMEGD-SPXI~NSxOe753c4ZLtVzkguqxSuGvr-vd6y9CBIB-s3-5i~RlWtPJwGPEJ3DYhSPH6TLwdIIZEwVLj5xwTJLhzuJoh4r0yR9RgnjVt33n5uV8bIuTYKcQf8CFYnoN-Hz7Z~OIn3B~4W2-aPnAJXprQz4HBPC4YFTSd07cCATNOoqiPqNgcc8m0JU4qTHlIQ2PXPQF5JEc1jeQr196lSofbtsWaubrUHvNfjR-6QG8qXP~wlkBR-DaKc-IE42kG~tGJKG9mWBr8puNXXuZera7tqnWkChU7rR9BxmDiAnthQclEcYfIlA41YdTSfk8g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Constraints from our lens model for the position and NFW halo properties of the dark substructure proposed by Agnello et\u00a0al. (2017). Left-hand panel: 2\u03c3 credible region for the position of the dark substructure in our lens model assuming the SIS profile (the orange contour) and the NFW profile (the yellow contour) for the substructure. Right-hand panel: The constraint on the M200\u2013c200 plane assuming the NFW profile for the dark substructure. The purple contours show the 1\u03c3 and 2\u03c3 credible regions. We show a comparison with the theoretical c200\u2013M200 relation for our fiducial cosmology from Diemer &amp; Joyce (2019).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figd1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530396/staa828figd1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figd1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530396\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828figd1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=4bxLGfDyxcIKq4RwOTp4xFBvn3C51eFcqRJel7GhARw4ndiqUnYnA58aQbgdxEBgR-PXJHOn8IUXdzJuY4NOh05FRno6RuLlRhB0mOwd0t7lsDALVmYYmyxYuqDDgMwZRvqO~wMARZ2UTqrPZcEzhHSESyYrKdjtjwnHGqv1fID~sTar5xXz1xDOn2lAV4A6y73~9qzpArNYp8QV2H0W9akenf02OhGnweqNodongvowKgpmB-AZ0IPZGXVkNGhVQb5uZDriWPsfHug7WQg6buTPMvZpzwdvESk~v1nQ2EddrdQ8lycT5RiPo~Dz0UFi9HO0tSB3XvVvq0EExR9iLA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530396&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figd1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Constraints from our lens model for the position and NFW halo properties of the dark substructure proposed by Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Left-hand panel: 2\u03c3 credible region for the position of the dark substructure in our lens model assuming the SIS profile (the orange contour) and the NFW profile (the yellow contour) for the substructure. Right-hand panel: The constraint on the <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>\u2013<em>c</em><sub>200</sub> plane assuming the NFW profile for the dark substructure. The purple contours show the 1\u03c3 and 2\u03c3 credible regions. We show a comparison with the theoretical <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>\u2013<em>M</em><sub>200</sub> relation for our fiducial cosmology from Diemer &amp; Joyce (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figd1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure D1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828figd1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=aiyVz-fAzsMDavbrN1SMEGD-SPXI~NSxOe753c4ZLtVzkguqxSuGvr-vd6y9CBIB-s3-5i~RlWtPJwGPEJ3DYhSPH6TLwdIIZEwVLj5xwTJLhzuJoh4r0yR9RgnjVt33n5uV8bIuTYKcQf8CFYnoN-Hz7Z~OIn3B~4W2-aPnAJXprQz4HBPC4YFTSd07cCATNOoqiPqNgcc8m0JU4qTHlIQ2PXPQF5JEc1jeQr196lSofbtsWaubrUHvNfjR-6QG8qXP~wlkBR-DaKc-IE42kG~tGJKG9mWBr8puNXXuZera7tqnWkChU7rR9BxmDiAnthQclEcYfIlA41YdTSfk8g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Constraints from our lens model for the position and NFW halo properties of the dark substructure proposed by Agnello et\u00a0al. (2017). Left-hand panel: 2\u03c3 credible region for the position of the dark substructure in our lens model assuming the SIS profile (the orange contour) and the NFW profile (the yellow contour) for the substructure. Right-hand panel: The constraint on the M200\u2013c200 plane assuming the NFW profile for the dark substructure. The purple contours show the 1\u03c3 and 2\u03c3 credible regions. We show a comparison with the theoretical c200\u2013M200 relation for our fiducial cosmology from Diemer &amp; Joyce (2019).\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figd1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530396/staa828figd1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figd1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530396\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828figd1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=4bxLGfDyxcIKq4RwOTp4xFBvn3C51eFcqRJel7GhARw4ndiqUnYnA58aQbgdxEBgR-PXJHOn8IUXdzJuY4NOh05FRno6RuLlRhB0mOwd0t7lsDALVmYYmyxYuqDDgMwZRvqO~wMARZ2UTqrPZcEzhHSESyYrKdjtjwnHGqv1fID~sTar5xXz1xDOn2lAV4A6y73~9qzpArNYp8QV2H0W9akenf02OhGnweqNodongvowKgpmB-AZ0IPZGXVkNGhVQb5uZDriWPsfHug7WQg6buTPMvZpzwdvESk~v1nQ2EddrdQ8lycT5RiPo~Dz0UFi9HO0tSB3XvVvq0EExR9iLA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530396&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828figd1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Constraints from our lens model for the position and NFW halo properties of the dark substructure proposed by Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Left-hand panel: 2\u03c3 credible region for the position of the dark substructure in our lens model assuming the SIS profile (the orange contour) and the NFW profile (the yellow contour) for the substructure. Right-hand panel: The constraint on the <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>\u2013<em>c</em><sub>200</sub> plane assuming the NFW profile for the dark substructure. The purple contours show the 1\u03c3 and 2\u03c3 credible regions. We show a comparison with the theoretical <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>\u2013<em>M</em><sub>200</sub> relation for our fiducial cosmology from Diemer &amp; Joyce (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, we do not add the potential substructure in our final lens model as the addition of the dark substructure shifts the estimated <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> by less than 1 per cent. Moreover, it is not clear if the constrained parameters for the additional mass profile to account for the dark substructure indeed reflect the existence of the substructure. A similar effect can also arise if the additional source component S2 lies at a redshift between the quasar and the central deflector G1. The proximity of the constrained position of the dark substructure and the lensed position of S2 hints this scenario to be a possibility.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) use the dust-corrected and delay-corrected flux ratios observed in the DES data as a constraint for the lens model and propose that the existence of a dark substructure fits the data better. We check if microlensing can be a possible source for the deviation of the flux ratios from a smooth model observed by Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). We derive the amplitude of microlensing in images A, B, and D by comparing their MUSE spectra. Microlensing is stronger in the continuum than in the broad emission lines. Therefore, we can isolate the microlensed fraction of the spectra if we assume that microlensing is more important in one of the lensed images under scrutiny and derive a lower limit on the amplitude of microlensing effect in the continuum emission (e.g. Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). This procedure reveals substantial differential microlensing between the continuum and the broad lines when we consider image pairs A\u2013D and B\u2013D, but not A\u2013B. The data are compatible with a microlensing demagnification of image D by at least a factor of 2. This demagnification translates into a mircrolensing corrected flux ratio \u0394<em>m</em><sub>AD</sub> = 0.25 mag. This estimate, however, may be affected by systematic errors caused by intrinsic variability. From the past light-curves of this system, we estimate that over the period corresponding to the time delay between images A and D, this systematic error could reach up to 0.2 mag. Therefore, we cannot definitively attribute the observed \u2018flux-ratio anomaly\u2019 to microlensing. In summary, whereas we cannot find strong evidence for the existence of the potential substructure, we also cannot rule out its existence. Since the presence or the impact of the dark substructure is not significant in our analysis, we omit it in our lens models for simplicity.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530399 id=\"203530399\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec12>APPENDIX E: NESTED SAMPLING SETTINGS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this Appendix, we provide our adopted settings for the nested sampling software <span class=\"small-caps\">dypolychord</span> and validate that the numerical requirements for our analysis are met.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We choose the <span class=\"small-caps\">dypolychord</span> settings <span class=\"monospace\">ninit</span> = 100, <span class=\"monospace\">nrepeats</span> = 30, <span class=\"monospace\">nconst_live</span> = 140, , <span class=\"monospace\">dynamic_goal</span> = 0.9, <span class=\"monospace\">precision_criterion</span> = 0.001 [see Higson et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>) for explanation of these settings]. To check the appropriateness of these settings, we run two sampling runs with the same lens model and sampler settings (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fige1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fige1\" data-open=\"fige1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">E1</a>). We find that the posteriors PDFs of the parameters are consistent within 1\u03c3 between the two runs, therefore we accept the chosen settings to be appropriate for sufficient exploration of the prior space. However, we find the estimated evidence values to differ by more than the estimated statistical uncertainty. This difference indicates that there is a systematic scatter in the computed evidence value. To estimate this scatter, we run a second set of nested sampling runs for 17 different lens models with <span class=\"monospace\">precision_criterion</span> = 0.01. We choose a lower <span class=\"monospace\">precision_criterion</span> for this second set of runs to make the sampling run terminate faster. A lower <span class=\"monospace\">precision_criterion</span> does not largely impact the evidence values, although it may affect the posterior estimation (Higson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). As we are only interested to obtain a conservative estimate of the scatter present in the computed <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\mathcal {Z}$|</span> values, this lower <span class=\"monospace\">precision_criterion</span> is sufficient for this purpose. By taking the mean of the evidence difference between runs from the two sets with the same lens model, we estimate the scatter in the evidence value as 24. Therefore, we take <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma ^{\\rm numeric}_{\\log \\mathcal {Z}}$|</span> = 24 as the numerical error in the computed evidence values. Albeit, if we increase <span class=\"monospace\">nlive_const</span> or <span class=\"monospace\">nrepeats</span>, we can decrease the error in the computed <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\mathcal {Z}$|</span> values in the exchange of a higher computational cost. However, as we down-weight the relative evidence ratios to account for sparse sampling of our models from the model space, this numerical error in <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\mathcal {Z}$|</span> is a subdominant factor (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.1</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"203530402\" scrollto-destination=\"203530402\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fige1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure E1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fige1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=qOXx182rpTCLfoktmL-N369dnfHQ6uQSI25JtVc852yIMkQD9FMuCerE2cfh9J8hNY9hqt4a4a9HpW4JfCvr~d3OXC9tKhqTrMTuyzb41jL7iHchoRIdoL6aKRZlH2fo~pmNX~lWvlI5lMAiYN7rTtQu3xceuUGqcdlqOPPybLad0Hb5e~tXESRVsOM-ghub~vvc9nuMFz3q~yQTK~NDVvjwzd8tplcESDGU-XNoBnxnBhkI0Rz-yuK2MSnpymkgL-Vyz40O4xtHspa9sVbTd83H3u9ohuPMVgGbYEqod0Ul1a7Hb9IoeIh55AeP2ImUDtqAGYg~WklGBYk3qL6iSg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"nestcheck diagnostic plot showing samples\u2019 distributions in two different runs with the same lens model for our chosen sampling settings. The top right-hand panel shows the relative posterior mass as a function of log\u2009X, where X is the prior volume fraction. The next three panels show the progressions of sampling (right to left) for three of the main lens mass parameters. The black solid and dashed lines show the evolution of one random thread of the dynamic nested sampler. The left column shows the posterior distributions of each parameter. The coloured contours represent the iso-probability credible regions of the probability density functions. The posteriors of the parameters are consistent within 1\u03c3, therefore we accept that the chosen settings allow for sufficient exploration of the prior volume.\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fige1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/203530402/staa828fige1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fige1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"203530402\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/staa828fige1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&Signature=mVdLiQwoA7K3mnbLBQ-YfF8ZO9yiMU4HvHSbcfnimvaOZy8yI-9rQ8A1BjV2PuXVxRP~QRRYVlw5N3V~X6XwRnvNN~zTB7QPOOK~vU3aBS30WqMzXZ0jR8d1vVhfRJ4dwaBxya-y5RWGrCunKwMdKQT-jMyPI8~tLsGW6lrvHdN0WfY4UzwZ4aTbhV-XR-nr7UCtvkg7jyXz5p2NBvtu6gBq2Z89U7-a6~3tYNPKvDYrMYtch1AFPeCoWUJ7scJ2GxfaxAvXa~k31PZbMYQFBcmW6HXdzOwEb7A3KjcTtG-NbHk3aZBVQWhxWQny0UTrFfo~bYa8vkLFkN-RwZ3BCw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=203530402&ar=5813265&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"staa828fige1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"small-caps\">nestcheck</span> diagnostic plot showing samples\u2019 distributions in two different runs with the same lens model for our chosen sampling settings. The top right-hand panel shows the relative posterior mass as a function of log\u2009<em>X</em>, where <em>X</em> is the prior volume fraction. The next three panels show the progressions of sampling (right to left) for three of the main lens mass parameters. The black solid and dashed lines show the evolution of one random thread of the dynamic nested sampler. The left column shows the posterior distributions of each parameter. The coloured contours represent the iso-probability credible regions of the probability density functions. The posteriors of the parameters are consistent within 1\u03c3, therefore we accept that the chosen settings allow for sufficient exploration of the prior volume.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fige1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure E1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/494/4/10.1093_mnras_staa828/1/m_staa828fige1.jpeg?Expires=1611464439&amp;Signature=qOXx182rpTCLfoktmL-N369dnfHQ6uQSI25JtVc852yIMkQD9FMuCerE2cfh9J8hNY9hqt4a4a9HpW4JfCvr~d3OXC9tKhqTrMTuyzb41jL7iHchoRIdoL6aKRZlH2fo~pmNX~lWvlI5lMAiYN7rTtQu3xceuUGqcdlqOPPybLad0Hb5e~tXESRVsOM-ghub~vvc9nuMFz3q~yQTK~NDVvjwzd8tplcESDGU-XNoBnxnBhkI0Rz-yuK2MSnpymkgL-Vyz40O4xtHspa9sVbTd83H3u9ohuPMVgGbYEqod0Ul1a7Hb9IoeIh55AeP2ImUDtqAGYg~WklGBYk3qL6iSg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"nestcheck diagnostic plot showing samples\u2019 distributions in two different runs with the same lens model for our chosen sampling settings. The top right-hand panel shows the relative posterior mass as a function of log\u2009<em>X</em>, where <em>X</em> is the prior volume fraction. The next three panels show the progressions of sampling (right to left) for three of the main lens mass parameters. The black solid and dashed lines show the evolution of one random thread of the dynamic nested sampler. The left column shows the posterior distributions of each parameter. The coloured contours represent the iso-probability credible regions of the probability density functions. The posteriors of the parameters are consistent within 1\u03c3, therefore we accept that the chosen settings allow for sufficient exploration of the prior volume.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=203530403 id=\"203530403\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec13>APPENDIX F: SUMMARY OF UNCERTAINTY BUDGET AND SYSTEMATIC CHECKS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In xref-sec\">5.6</a>)\u00a0</td><td>+0.95\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Accounting for Tie &amp; Kochanek (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>)\u2019s microlensing time-delay (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.2.3</a>)\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Total systematic shift</strong>\u00a0</td><td><strong>\u22120.92\u20130.08</strong>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/203530406\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 (arcsec)\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {U}(-0.97,\\ -0.93)$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image A\u00a0</td><td>\u0394\u03b1 (arcsec)\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {U}(1.940,\\ 1.948)$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image A\u00a0</td><td>\u0394\u03b4 (arcsec)\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {U}(-1.576,\\ -1.568)$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image B\u00a0</td><td>\u0394\u03b1 (arcsec)\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {U}(-1.819,\\ -1.809)$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image B\u00a0</td><td>\u0394\u03b4 (arcsec)\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {U}(0.263,\\ 0.290)$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image C\u00a0</td><td>\u0394\u03b1 (arcsec)\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {U}(-1.935,\\ -1.926)$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image C\u00a0</td><td>\u0394\u03b4 (arcsec)\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {U}(-0.954,\\ -0.940)$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image D\u00a0</td><td>\u0394\u03b1 (arcsec)\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {U}(0.096,\\ 0.110)$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Image D\u00a0</td><td>\u0394\u03b4 (arcsec)\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {U}(1.385,\\ 1.392)$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Differential dust extinction\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\tau _{0}^{\\rm F814W}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {U}(0.1,\\ 2.0)$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/203530410\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To make the nested sampler efficiently explore and integrate over the high-dimensional (\u223c60D) prior volume in our models, we narrow down the width of the uniform priors for some of the parameters more than that would be known purely <em>a priori</em>. We choose these prior bounds by looking at the posterior PDFs for the lens models from the initial exploratory phase of this study and we further adjust these prior widths through trial and error. We check that the posterior PDFs of the parameters are fully contained within the chosen bounds for our final lens models, unless we specifically set the bound using an empirical or physical prior. Below we explain some of the parameters from Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl10\" data-open=\"tbl10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">G2</a> that were not introduced within the main body of this paper.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The amplitude of the Chameleon convergence profile is parametrized with the deflection angle at 1 arcsec, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\alpha _1^{\\rm Chm}$|\u2060</span>. The ellipticity parameters <em>e</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>e</em><sub>2</sub> in the relevant profiles are related to the axial ratio <em>q</em> and the position angle \u03d5 as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ62\" content-id=\"equ62\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\begin{split} &amp;q = \\frac{1 - \\sqrt{e_1^2 + e_2^2}}{1 + \\sqrt{e_1^2 + e_2^2}}, \\\\\r\n&amp;\\tan 2 \\phi = \\frac{e_2}{e_1}. \\end{split}\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(G1)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Parametrizing the ellipticity with <em>e</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>e</em><sub>2</sub> avoids the periodicity in the polar coordinate \u03d5 and makes the sampling more efficient. The centroids <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(\\theta _1^{\\rm c}, \\theta _2^{\\rm c})$|</span> of the relevant profiles are relative to the coordinate RA 04:08:21.71 and Dec \u221253:53:59.34. We take a uniform prior <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {U}(-5\\times 10^4, 5\\times 10^4)$|</span> for the amplitudes of the shapelet components \u2013 which are linear parameters \u2013 to compute the evidence using equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ35\"></span><a href=\"#equ35\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">35</a>).</p>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-metadata-standalone-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n\r\n        \r\n                    <h2 class=\"authorNotes-section-title\" The relative offsets of the observed centroids for G3\u2013G6 are computed from the coordinate RA 04:08:21.71 and Dec \u221253:53:59.34. The tabulated uncertainties for the velocity dispersions are statistical uncertainties. However, we adopt a 20\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> uncertainty for each measurement to account for the typical systematic uncertainty for kinematics obtained from MUSE spectra (Gu\u00e9rou et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span>2017). The redshifts are precise up to the specified decimal point.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Galaxy<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Redshift and stellar velocity dispersion for the line-of-sight galaxies G3\u2013G6 and S2. The relative offsets of the observed centroids for G3\u2013G6 are computed from the coordinate RA 04:08:21.71 and Dec \u221253:53:59.34. The tabulated uncertainties for the velocity dispersions are statistical uncertainties. However, we adopt a 20\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> uncertainty for each measurement to account for the typical systematic uncertainty for kinematics obtained from MUSE spectra (Gu\u00e9rou et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span>2017). The redshifts are precise up to the specified decimal point.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Galaxy<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n The total convergence \u03ba, the stellar convergence \u03ba<sub>\u22c6</sub>, the shear \u03b3<sub>shear</sub>, and the magnification \u03bc are obtained from the best-fitting composite model. As the local slope of the composite model at the image positions can deviate from the 3D slope \u03b3 = 2 of an isothermal profile, \u03ba and \u03b3<sub>shear</sub> are not necessarily O. Box 500, Batavia, IL 60510, USA)"], "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "cosmological parameters", "distance scale", "cosmology: observations", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2020MNRAS.494.6072S", "volume": "494", "Title": "STRIDES: a 3.9 per cent measurement of the Hubble constant from the strong lens system DES J0408-5354", "abstract": "We present a blind time-delay cosmographic analysis for the lens system DES J0408-5354. This system is extraordinary for the presence of two sets of multiple images at different redshifts, which provide the opportunity to obtain more information at the cost of increased modelling complexity with respect to previously analysed systems. We perform detailed modelling of the mass distribution for this lens system using three band Hubble Space Telescope imaging. We combine the measured time delays, line-of-sight central velocity dispersion of the deflector, and statistically constrained external convergence with our lens models to estimate two cosmological distances. We measure the 'effective' time-delay distance corresponding to the redshifts of the deflector and the lensed quasar $D_{\\Delta t}^{\\rm eff}=$ $3382_{-115}^{+146}$ Mpc and the angular diameter distance to the deflector D<SUB>d</SUB> = $1711_{-280}^{+376}$ Mpc, with covariance between the two distances. From these constraints on the cosmological distances, we infer the Hubble constant H<SUB>0</SUB>= $74.2_{-3.0}^{+2.7}$ km s<SUP>-1 </SUP>Mpc<SUP>-</SUP><SUP>1</SUP> assuming a flat \u039bCDM cosmology and a uniform prior for \u03a9<SUB>m</SUB> as $\\Omega _{\\rm m} \\sim \\mathcal {U}(0.05, 0.5)$ . This measurement gives the most precise constraint on H<SUB>0</SUB> to date from a single lens. Our measurement is consistent with that obtained from the previous sample of six lenses analysed by the H<SUB>0</SUB> Lenses in COSMOGRAIL's Wellspring (H0LiCOW) collaboration. It is also consistent with measurements of H<SUB>0</SUB> based on the local distance ladder, reinforcing the tension with the inference from early Universe probes, for example, with 2.2\u03c3 discrepancy from the cosmic microwave background measurement."}}
